Rich and chock full of lobster pieces. I soaked up every last bit with bread, which was also very fresh and tasty. If you plan on going there, the lobster bisque is also a must.

For our entree, we ordered the fish special which was recommended by the waiter. I can't recall what type of fish it was, but it was yummy, and the vegetables that were cooked with it accented the fish very well.

They lose one star only because the fish was not completely cooked at the bottom and had to be sent back for a few more minutes in the oven. I didn't see this as a big deal. I'm sure others would scowl at having to do that, but for me, it's didn't ruin the experience. We both agree that it does happen, even at the best restaurants and when it came back to the table it was perfect and extremely delectable.

It was a bit cold in the restaurant, but then again it was freezing outside and we were sitting by the door. Not crowded at all and it has a warm, charming atmosphere. It's definitely our go to place for oysters from now on.

Go get yours!
author: Seth M.

description: Very Pleasant Experience :) Went for the oysters. Happy Hour $1 each is a great deal!  Didn't read the fine print in reviews, so thought it was full-bar, but wine and beer only, with wine "cocktails."  Entrees were different and cooked by an expert. Staff changed after Happy Hour, so it felt like we were forgotten, a bit. But overall a nice evening.
author: Vicki L.

description:
To say I'm disappointed would be a bit of an understatement.

I came here last Saturday (or maybe the one before that) and was super excited since I've been wanting to try this place for a while now. My boyfriend made reservations for 8pm but we got there super early cause we thought it would take us FOREVER to find parking, but we were lucky. Usually parking around this neighborhood would take a good 30 mins to find.. Good thing they were nice enough to seat us even though we were about an hour early for our reservation.

**We were seated at 7:10pm.
**7:25pm - the waiter finally came to take our order.. that's pretty long considering they really weren't that busy. We ordered the oyster mixed plate to share - I had the lobster bisque and the white sea bass, the bf had the clam chowder and the pork chops.
**7:45pm - the oysters came. there were 3 different kinds but our waiter never told us which one was which so I had no idea what the oyster I liked was called.
**8:10pm - our soups came. the lobster bisque was decent, not the best I've had though. The boyfriend's clam chowder tasted like over-priced progresso.
**around 8:30pm was the highlight of my already disappointing experience.. another lovely waiter knocked over a glass of water while trying to clean the table next to us and how lucky am I to have it splashed all over my shoes and feet? GUESS IT WAS MY FAULT, SINCE THE WAITER DIDN'T EVEN BOTHER TO APOLOGIZE.

At that point, I just wanted to leave.
We took the entrees to-go, paid for our check and left.

My entree was supposed to be a "herb marinated white sea bass and vegetables wrapped and baked in paper" the waiter told me it was delicious, he lied.
I got paper, burnt vegetables and a bitter slab of fish.

1 star for the oysters, they were at least decent.
The only thing I would come back for would either be to try out their happy hour oysters or maybe if my feet needed a little splashing.
author: Lily K.

description:
My boyfriend took me here for my birthday. We were really lucky and got the last seat in the restaurant, and it was right by the window so it was great for people watching and the cable car goes right by us. 

We started off with the lobster bisque and that was SO GOOD. It was nice and creamy, with lots of lobster meat, and it was just an explosion of yumminess. 

Our waiter was super nice. Our water glasses were always full and the basket of bread was never empty (and we were starving so we ate a LOT of bread. ps the bread with the lobster bisque, soooooo good). 

We got 3 entrees, the best one was the seafood fettucini (I can't remember what it's called) It's got chardonay white sauce and tons of seafood. The pasta was well-prepared, the sauce was flavorful and creamy. It's got loads of shrimp, scallops, salmon, lobster, and crab. The shrimps were amazing, they were perfectly cooked. The scallops were small and chewy, and there were way too much scallops. It would've been perfect if there were more shrimps and less scallops. The really nice thing they did was that they brought it out to us in 2 plates, portions pre-separated and everything so we don't have to do it ourselves.

The other two entrees were kinda disappointing, it was a good thing that the pasta was delicious. 

The Baked Stuffed Rainbow Trout (lobster, scallops, shrimp & crab meat stuffing). The trout was really tender, but on the bland side in my opinion. The stuffing was nice.

The Cioppino (clams, mussles, scallops, fish, crab meat & prawns in marinara sauce) was okay. It wasn't as tomato-y as we were expecting. 

Oh and we got some margaritas. They were awful. Don't get cocktails here.

Overall, it was a nice restaurant, nice ambiance, nice service, I would go back and try their oysters!
author: Erica L.

description:
I just got back from Hyde Street Seafood House and Raw Bar and I just got off the toilet.  I'm going to write this review in bullet point style b/c I have a lingering feeling that tells me a second trip is imminent.

POSITIVES

Nice Waitstaff
- Our waiter had good knowledge of the menu and when we finished the meal and brought the check, he thanked me by using my name and asked if we needed a cab.

Decor
- The decor was nautical, which is great as I'm from New England and quite enjoy a good nautical vibe.

Music
- They had some good golden oldies playing.  Lots of Sinatra.

NEGATIVES

Food
- The food was meh.  The Caesar salad was very average.  I got the Blue Nosed Bass (recommended to me), which I had never tried before.  It had a tough consistency, almost like lobster, that I wasn't expecting.  Perhaps that is how BNB is though.  My girlfriend got the Salmon and said that it was bland.  I actually liked the light seasoning.

Effect of the food
- As stated above, I recently got off the toilet.  It was a little rough in there.  It kind of took me back to childhood b/c I experienced the type of gas pains I used to get when I was a kid.  The kind that you would call your mom in for to rub your belly until the feeling passed.  I asked my girlfriend to come in and give the ole constitution a rub, but she wouldn't do it.

CONCLUSION

I'm a little bummed that HSSHRB wasn't better.  I just moved into an apartment a half block away and it would've been rad to have a good place close by.  I may go back, but it may only be to get drinks at the bar, which looked cool.  Maybe they have a good happy hour.
author: Erik L.

description:
Came here on a friday night around 7:30pm and didn't have to wait long at all. I wish I would have known the oysters are much cheaper at happy hour cause we paid $12 for a half dozen. They were very good and fresh, just a little pricey when you know they are half the price an hour earlier!

The ciopinno was very good. I like it when they serve it in a large bowl with a lid. This one came on more of a soup bowl, which was a little shallow making it cool off fast. The fish and the scallops in it were very tasty. The Caesar salad was very good and it had a nice anchovy taste in the dressing without being overpowering. Overall the service was good, just very busy. Price is right if you get a starter and split the ciopinno. It was big enough for 2!
author: Natalie N.

description:
Came for their oyster happy hour and I was impressed!  What's not to love about $1 oysters?  There were three kinds of oysters to choose from and unfortunately the local (Marin) ones were just not cutting it...we much preferred the fanny bay and steamboat oysters.  The steamboat oysters were especially buttery and juicy...YUM.

In addition we got bread and butter, even for happy hour.  Service was excellent, which I was not expecting, since they knew we were ordering happy hour deals.  Water and bread refills were prompt, the staff was very pleasant, and they never kept us waiting on those oysters!  I would definitely come back to enjoy their dinner fare at a later date...the smells from other tables were tantalizing!
author: Cathy Y.

description:
I can't believe my sister lives around the corner from this place.  That lucky ****.  As many other Yelpers mentioned, oysters are 12 for $12 during happy hour.  What makes this deal amazing is that this place isn't a dive; it's actually a nice restaurant.  Highly recommend getting an assortment, unless you're partial to a particular type of oyster.  Sorry that I can't comment on anything else...when you have 4 dozen delicious oysters in front of you, it's hard to pay attention to anything else on the table.

Looooooooooove.
author: Nancy C.

description:
This was so disappointing.  4 of us went out for dinner and the food was really just not up to par.  we started with a few bowls of lobster bisque which were actually pretty good.  after the soup, i was pumped for dinner.  we ordered shellfish en papillote, salmon en papillote, cioppino, and steak.  the shellfish was nasty- the prawns were good but the rest of the stuff was so bad she had to spit it out.  the salmon was overcooked.  the cioppino was ok i guess but underwhelming to say the least.  the steak was probably the best bet but i guess also the most forgiving.

i would come back for happy hour for the raw oysters deal, but definitely not for dinner.
author: Lisa C.

description:
updaaaate!
as of a couple of weeks ago, the happy hour (7days a week) is as follows: 
$14.95 for a dozen oysters (instead of $12). 
$3.50 for pints o beer (instead of $2.50). 

still a great deal. still THE BEST LOBSTER BISQUE EVER!
author: Kaylan S.

description: Really nice neighborhood spot. Reasonable prices and portions. The stuffed trout and garlic prawns were fine but pretty basic. Service was very nice and friendly
author: Paul D.

description: Wanted to have some seafood while in town, yelped Hyde Street Seafood House..we had the Lobster Bisque, Clam Chowder, stuffed trout and stuffed shrimp.  The trout and shrimp were very good, trout was a bit dry for me, and the red potatoes were tetering on lukewarm..however, the Lobster Bisque and Clam Chowder will bring me back.  I am not usually a soupy, chowder type of guy - but this stuff was off the frigging hook..I would have been content with a bowl of each and some bread.  Tad pricey but worth it, bill came to about $70 with tip, which included three beers.  It is obviously a family owned and operated business, everyone was super friendly and the conversations were sincere.  Very nice experience and they have earned my repeat business when I am in town.
author: David S. Y.

description:
Entrees from 15-20$
Appetizers are a little pricey but you can share one.

We tried the prawns fetuccini and the béarnaise prawns. Very good, lots of flavors, fulfilling. The cook does a great job at preparing seafood.
The restaurant by itself is pretty, service is a little long but in a timely fashion.
author: Victor L.

description: Great service! Family owned! BEST LOBSTER BISQUE! Great wine selection. We had 3 dozen fresh oysters and a dozen of fresh clams.  So yummy. And I couldn't get enough of the garlic bread!!  I ordered the escolar aka butterfish that was made wrapped in parchment paper. The restaurants specialty. Nice array of veggies, potatoes, and a nice portion of fish. It was all cooked to perfection and very tasty!! Love this place and would definitely come back! Only bad thing I can say is that parking is very difficult in that area so give yourself more time to look for parking.
author: Gina S.

description: We were happy with the quality of the happy hour oysters. Cozy place but we chose to have dinner elsewhere. We would return for happy hour any day. An excellent value for San Francisco.
author: Joel N.

description: Great happy hour spot!  The staff is so nice and always remember me. :)  The oysters are fresh and not overpriced.  This is the place I tried my first fresh clams.  It was great!  I typically order the escolar (butterfish) which can be difficult to find.  It is prepared en papillote and is so fresh and full of flavor.  The food is great but I believe it's family owned which makes it more charming.
author: Deez C.

description:
$1 oysters? Done deal. I ordered 3 dozens and perhaps i ate a bit too much b/c umm the rest of my week made me really believe oysters are truly an aphrodisiac food....haha

Oh btw you get to pick from 3 different types of oysters and i highly recommend the ones from WASHINGTON!!! Those were the best ones mmmm SLURP!!!
author: Diana N.

description:
I love oysters. And there's no better place than Hyde Street Seafood to fulfill your desire for oysters. 

They have a happy hour from 5-7 pm every day and I've been at least 5 times in the last 2 years. Oysters are $1 and my friends and I usually get at least 2 dozen... each! At 10 calories per oyster (I googled it), this is hardly a problem. 

Their oysters are fresh and they do a great job of shucking and not leaving any shell bits inside. I pair the oysters with a few draft beers on the happy hour list and you've got the perfect happy hour! 

I recently had the lobster bisque which is extremely flavorful, creamy, but not too thick. I highly recommend that too.
author: Keiko T.

description:
Words cannot describe what a fabulous experience my husband and I shared at this restaurant in early July.

We were in San Francisco for our honeymoon. It was nearing dinner time, and we had been walking all day. We could not find a place to eat, and we were walking up and down Hyde Street in search of a place for dinner. 

We were both in tennis shoes and hoodies (and I was sporting a backpack), so we were initially leery about dining here. However, once we were seated (we did not have reservations, and only had to wait about 15-20 minutes on a Friday night), all of that worry melted away.

I ordered wine. I never order wine. Call it the curse of Napa, still sticking with me . And my husband ordered a delicious beer. Our meal was already off to a banner start, as far as I was concerned.

A few days earlier in South Lake Tahoe, I had discovered seafood bisque. Still carrying that craving into the Bay area, I ordered the lobster bisque for dinner. Between the bisque, the served bread, and the wine, I knew I would be set. And boy, was I. This bisque was so fantastic, I couldn't get it out of my head for days after. It had a fantastic, semi-thick consistency with small clumps of succulent lobster... oh boy, if you come here, you must indulge (calories-wise) in the lobster bisque. It's a can't-miss culinary experience.

My husband ordered a fish dish. At first it tasted bland, but somehow, later, my second bite was infused with buttery, citrus flavor.

Yum. If we're ever back in San Francisco, this is where we're going to relive that delicious evening.
author: Erin O.

description:
Service was great with a charming waiter who was free with giving out advice on what to order. We started with lobster bisque (which was not quite traditional, but still tasty) then two of us ordered the seafood cooked in parchment. Mine was the shrimp and scallops (I opted for skipping the clams and mussels - I am not a big fan). The scallops were cooked well but the shrimp was a little overdone. The vegetables were really tasty and probably the favorite part of the dish. 

Overall, I really enjoyed the evening. Unpretentious, tasty and a good experience.
author: Sheridan S.

description: This place is great.  If you make it to the happy hour before 7 pm, you can grab a dozen oysters on the half shell for 14 bones; an amazing deal.  The lobster bisque is also delicious, too -- generous with the lobster pieces and highly tasty.  Good, chill ambiance during the week as well!
author: Mel G.

description:
Nothing too impressive...

Oysters - during happy hour are $1 each, good deal if you just stop by for oysters and wine

Our main course dishes were nothing special:

Salmon en Papillote - the "en Papillote" is supposed to be their special amazing dish... there really wasn't anything special about it. It was still just steamed fish and vegetables and the spices/flavors were boring. I dare say we could make it better at home.

Potato Crusted Salmon - way too much of a crust, too much like shredded hash browns. the potato was a little burnt on the outside and mushy next to the fish. The sauce it was served with was really good, but I still would never order this again.

Overall, the service was decent, but there was nothing special about our main courses and they weren't worth the price. We'd come back for a glass of wine and some oysters during happy hour though if we were in the neighborhood already.
author: Emily C.

description:
I've been here twice now so it's time to write a review. This place is one of the many gems on Hyde St. I loved the Cajun shrimp/scallop dish but thought did fish in parchment did not live up to the hype. Had a fabulous waiter on my second visit- he gave great advice on both food and wine decisions and wasn't shy about being honest.  

Tip: Come here for the oyster happy hour special!
author: Priya N.

description:
The Halibut En Papillote (halibut was the catch of the day special) was outstanding. Perfect balance of herbs, and the veggies and potatoes were great consistency. Other people in my party got the swordfish and king crab, which both were pretty standard... nothing to write home over. Lobster and Crab Bisque were better than average. Wine list was a little weak, and our server did not know much about the wines. I would actually recommend bringing a bottle ($15 corkage fee). 

Cozy atmosphere, and great location. I'll be back!
author: Amanda B.

description:
An amazing gem hidden off of Hyde Street. Very friendly service with an outstanding menu. 

As an appetizer, we had oysters which were absolutely amazing. During happy hour, they are 50% off I believe. For an entree,I had the swordfish which was cooked perfectly, very moist with peppercorns on top to accentuate the flavor. The vegetables had a tangy twist to them and were cooked to perfection. 

The wine selection was great and the server even offered a taste of a couple of the wines prior to getting a glass to ensure I would be happy with it. 

From the charm of the restaurant to the excellent service to the amazing quality of the food, I would definitely be back many times in the future.
author: Pierce B.

description:
The restaurant is located in a pleasant part of SF, getting off at the BART at Powell street, take the 27 to Hyde and Jackson.

The restaurant has a comfortable seafood restaurant feel.  Has a bunch of maritime related decor, giving it a little classy feel.  Restaurant was not too crowded during happy hour, though more people came in around dinner time. 

Went in here for happy hour, ended up staying for dinner too!

Me and a couple friends went originally for happy hour.  We sat down, ordered a few beers and two dozen oysters at $15 / dozen.  The oysters were good, and pretty fresh!  Don't expect these to tie you over for long, we were still pretty hungry, so we ordered dinner.

I started with the lobster bisque, which was pretty good.  The lobster to soup ratio was very good, while the soup was just the right amount of creaminess as a usual bisque should have.  

They claim to be known for their fish wrapped in parchment paper, (a French style preparation), it was not bad.  The squash, zucchini, potatoes and fish sat in the juices that the bag helped contain, keeping everything moist and flavorful.  Though the salmon was a little undercooked in the middleish, i didn't really mind it all too much, but then again i really like sushi and really hate over cooked, dry fish =P

The service was very attentive, and the waiter was very pleasant.  Water glasses always filled, and bread basket never empty, us three ate like 25+ pieces (silly college kids).
author: Devon J.

description:
Good deal on the happy hour oysters. But fast forward to 2 hours after dinner, and i was sitting on the toilet with a really bad case of you know what. I've been here before and never had a problem; maybe its just this one instance ??

Good luck to you brave soul if you do try!
author: natassia s.

description:
food and service are decent.
don't order the ceaser salad
author: Nick F.

description: Everything was so fresh & wonderful!! Delicious oysters!!!! We also had the special of lobster & shrimp ravioli plus the pan seared sea scallops with ginger cream sauce....everything was perfect!!!!! The staff was so courteous and didn't rush us, we enjoyed a leisurely 3 hr dinner talking among great friends!!!! Fabulous place!!!
author: Mindy N.

description:
This is a 3.5 star place that I'm going to bump up to 4 stars?  Why?  Excellent service and the daily $1/Oyster Happy Hour from 5pm-8pm.

It's not the busiest place during happy hours so if you're an introvert, that's a great time to get there and avoid the noise.  This restaurant is located in the romantic area of San Francisco off the cable car track on Hyde St. on top of Nob Hill which is a haven for locals because most tourists go right by these three or four blocks en route to Fisherman's Wharf/Ghiradhelli Square.

The interior is warmly lit and not too dim or bright.  The sounds travel awkwardly and there are a couple of tricky small steps between the upper area and the bar area that leads to the restrooms.

They offer a decent selection of beers at a reasonable price.  The anchor steam is very good.  They also offer 3 types of oysters, fanny bay, marin bay, and another one that I can't remember.  Tip: if you like raw oysters, just get as many of the Fanny Bay's as possible.  While the other two taste pretty good, they are tiny in comparison to the Fanny Bay's which are delicious.

I'd only come here during the happy hour.   So my 4 stars is that of this place only during that time and of the oysters.  I cannot remark on the dinners or cioppino.
author: Tony U.

description: Happy hour oysters are a great deal. Food is not remarkable. Dining room has been dead the couple times I've been here.  Parking is tough.
author: Michael S.

description:
A gem within a big city like San Fran...
Aside from the Oysters, which of course were delish, Lobster bisque was out of this world...seriously- the best I have EVER had. The restaurant is quite, romantic and somewhat dreamy...My bf and I were visiting from LA and I am so glad we stayed away from all the tourist trap restaurants and found this amazing place...
author: Eva B.

description: My wife and I just enjoyed a wonderful dinner here. We had the lobster bisque and seafood ravioli. Our only negative is they seemed a little short staffed.
author: Robert H.

description: 14$ for 12 oysters during happy hour (5-7), Best lobster bisque my wife and I have ever had. Crab Cakes were crunchy on the outside but very soft on the inside and actually tasted like crab. What else is there to say. We were visiting for a weekend and I was trying to find a spot where the locals would dine. This is not a tourist trap.
author: Brad S.

description: They are known for en papillote fish at Hyde Steet Bar and I could see why.  To top off the great meal was some of the nicest service I've ever experienced.  I'm very glad I tried this place out.
author: Brian S.

description:
Was disappointed with the experience.  The oysters are good though very limited in selection, and they go well with a couple cold pints of beer.  But the clam chowder was lacking in flavor, and gritty in texture.  The steam clams tasted fresh, though again very light in flavor, and very small in portion.  After these 3 dishes, we decided to not stay for dinner.   And since we didn't order oodles of food, the servers didn't bother checking on us.

I'd rather head to Swan Oyster Depot down the street or Hog Islands.
author: Yayu L.

description: I enjoyed my dinner here tonight!  Johnny, one of the owners and who works the front house, was totally knowlegable about the menu and the wine and cocktails.  He was full of pep and energy and smiles for us besides his brother, Brian.  I tried the recommended lobster bisque.  OMGosh!  Divine with the bits of lobster meat in it and they weren't skimpy with the meat.  I had the stuffed prawns bermaise.  They were fresh and delicious.  I couldn't resist dessert so I had the key lime pie.  I'm usually not a pie eater, but it was perfect, not too sour as a lot of them are.  I loved the contrast of the raspberry sauce garnish with it.  My cosmo was not too strong and hit the spot.  I need to work on my hubbie to take me back.
author: Kekumukula N.

description:
Fresh beer and oysters.
A cable car rounds the bend...
a new memory.
author: Nathan K.

description: Great local happy hour spot! The oysters were delicious - a dozen for $14! Great beer specials for happy hour, as well. Service was very friendly. I will be back!
author: Anastasia N.

description:
This review is ONLY for HAPPY HOUR 5-7pm

$12 oysters (3 diff types) - fresh
$2.50 beers only

what we ordered that's no HH:

$6 lobster bisque - yummy
$7 NE clam chowder - ok
$12 steamed mussels - (counted 12 mussels) -meh..

4 stars bc there's no Happy Hour food or menu.  Parking is difficult around 5pm.
author: Anna W.

description:
One of my favorite happy hour haunts!

Me and Shea Z wandered into this place since Clint's Pad is right up the street. Side note: Clint's pad is my spot, earning it's namesake after none other than Clint Eastwood himself who filmed the Dirty Harry Magnum Force movie there back in the day! Right off Leavenworth & Jackson. 

Anyway, what can I say that's not novel-length about Hyde Street Seafood? The nautical-themed decor won me over right away, not to be outdone by their fab oysters! What a killer selection! Try those, as well as the papillote, which is a parchment-wrapped fish dish. It's also great to come in and see Johnny and Sofia -- they're both very friendly!

I've never lived it up foodwise as much as I have since moving to this city, and I must say, this place has paved the way for my growing love of seafood. And hatred of having a car and no place to park it...Do yourself a favor and don't drive here! Or anywhere in Nob & Russian Hill for that matter!
xo
author: Anita A.

description: Quaint place with a nautical theme. I need my pashmina afgan. Food was decent, but not amazing. My fancy beer was just a 25 cl glass -- not the bottle as promised. The trout was properly cooked, but not particularly well chosen. Oysters were pricey, but the I-forget-which-ones were delicious. Would be three stars but the rather excellent quality of our Friday night, no reservation service bumped it up -- especially when they were amenable to entree-weaponizing my bacon-wrapped scallops appetizer.
author: Rob R.

description:
This review is specifically for their happy hour.  A couple of my friends have been here before and it was a suggested for a Friday happy hour so I decided to give it a try.  Trying to drive out there and find parking is ridic so I wouldn't advise it if you can avoid it.

The place was small but not too busy during happy hour which is nice.  The main attraction here were the $1 oysters.  I order 12 assorted oysters for myself.  They were from three different places: Fannybase (sp?), Hog Island, and Steam Boat.  The first one, which I'm sure isn't the right name, were the largest but probably least tasty.  Hog island were smaller but much tastier, but the smallest steam boat ones were the best in my opinion.  Next time I go back, I would skip the first.  Complimented my oysters with some beer and you can't really ask for much else!

The restaurant was nice and clean.  Pretty simple decor with a nautical theme and the service was nice.  The dinner menu looked pretty pricey so I don't know if I would come back for that, but I'd definitely stop by again for another HH get together!
author: Tom Y.

description: Valentines dinner prefixe menu. Not worth it!  Lots of confusion on the orders, food lacked flavor and the price didn't compare to the value of meal. Very disappointing and expensive experience.  :-(
author: Lydia D.

description:
on a recent visit to san francisco, we had the privilege of discovering this gem of a restaurant after trekking a mighty hill on a quest for swan oysters...upon discovering the line for swan out the door, and the patrons inside elbow to elbow...on top of the fact they were about to close (at 530? kind of inconvenient!)...a short walk via the bigfoot bar (another diamond!) we ended up at hyde street seafood during happy hour!

oysters and beer on special, we partook of both and in multitude. oysters were fresh and sweet and the beer was cold and refreshing on this exceptionally sunny san francisco weekend.

also of merit, the lobster bisque...wow. so perfectly sweet with the taste of the sea and thick with chunks of lobster. i also had the stuffed shrimp...delicious!

our server johnny was funny and quick and very attentive. we would DEFINITELY make our way back here...but maybe we'd drive next time.
author: becky d.

description:
I heard so much about this place and always wanted to try it.  I finally got the chance one night for dinner with some friends.  

for those of you who don't really know this area, parking is really really really difficult.  I was somewhat lucky since I found parking after 10 minutes of  driving but it was at least 3 blocks away.  for those that know me I usually don't park more than a block away.  =)

I had to deduct one star because it was really cold inside.  I guess their heater was broken since they had several space heaters everywhere.  it still didn't help, I was freezing...  

we started out with a dozen oysters, 3 different kinds.  it was pretty good but not great.  it didn't help that a few nights earlier I had kumamoto oysters.  YUM!  next up was the lobster bisque.  again, it was ok, a little too salty for me.  at least the bread went really well with it.  for my entree I ordered swordfish while my gf ordered the steak.  I was quite disappointed after hearing so many good things about this place.

would I come here again?  I can't say.  would I take my gf here?  no, maybe we're just too stuck up and our tastes is too refined.  ;)
author: Samson M.

description: The best seafood I have tried in SF so far~ Came at their happy hours, Freshly Shucked Oysters dozen for $14 (6 for $12)~ Highly recommend the Lobster Bisque~
author: Sabrina Z.

description:
Let me just say, the King Salmon en papillote is delicious! Who knew parchment paper could make food taste so good? Now if I could only find my college diploma, i might be able to replicate that dish at home.

But the parking situation in this neighborhood is absolutely crappy.  We were circling around for 30 minutes trying to find a spot on the street, and we had no luck whatsoever.  So, save yourselves the trouble of looking for street parking and park in the public lot on Sacramento between Polk and Van Ness for all of $10. Then maybe you'll get to enter the restaurant with a healthy appetite, instead of starving so badly that you're willing to eat the fish hanging on the walls.
author: Meg P.

description: I have been here several times over the past few years and love it every time. The staff is friendly and the prices are reasonable for the fresh seafood. Great happy hour- everyday with $1 oysters and deals on beers and wine. I love the lobster bisque! Would recommend for a romantic dinner when you are not in a rush to go anywhere. Only negative would be trying to find parking if you do not live in the area.
author: Nicole S.

description:
YUM! The 4 stars are for the oysters!
My bff found this place on yelp and decided to take me here and a couple others for my 20th birthday. We were really late, but still made it for happy hour! (5pm-7pm). $1 oysters (ordered by the dozen) and $2.50 for a pint of beer. Awesome! The 6 of us ordered 3 dozen delicious oysters. They were very fresh and didn't leave the yucky after taste I've tasted with other raw oysters. We finished the 36 oysters no problem. The entrees we ordered were just mediocre; nothing really stood out for me. But I'd definitely come back for the oysters!
Service was really good! Our waitor (& possibly the owner/manager?) let us order more oysters/beer even after hour happy was done =) (like 10-15 minutes past 7:00). 
The atmosphere was very nice; it's like a cute little elegant restaurant. Small, but very pretty. A good place to dress up for! :)
author: Kim D.

description: We flew into San Francisco and were looking for a good, low-key seafood place to eat. We read the reviews on Yelp and figured to give it a shot. We were sooo happy with the food. I ordered the papillote seafood place and wife got the butterfish that was amazing (and I don't like fish!) and my son got the Cioppino pasta that was awesome. I would recommend this place to anyone who likes seafood that isn't dipped in 2 pounds of batter and fried.
author: Pablo R.

description: Came here for dinner with a big group--my parents and brother and his family visiting from out of town.  We all loved our choices--starting with fresh perfectly dressed salads and the steamed mussels in a fragrant broth. I had the halibut with scallops--a special for the day. It was perfectly prepared--with a light creamy sauce. The ambience was perfect--cozy and intimate. The prices were extremely reasonable. The service was very attentive and friendly. I'll definitely return!
author: Jin L.

description:
DROOOOOOOOL. I had a FANTASTIC Valentine's Day dinner here. My boyfriend and I had:

- Crab cakes: Amazing!!!! The best crab cakes I've ever had -- not too salty or rich, but with lots of interesting flavors and served with horseradish sauce, yum.
- Oysters: Very fresh
- Lobster ravioli: Rich and delicious, served with creamy champagne sauce and lots of other seafood. Very filling -- I probably could've split this with someone else and have been full + an appetizer.
- Halibut, Prawns & Scallops En Papillotte: Kind of a mix of different seafoods, cooked inside parchment paper. Lots of interesting spices and flavors, and also very, very filling -- definitely split.
- Creme brulee: Average, very sweet.
- Chocolate truffle torte: Also average.

I hope to come back for the crab cakes, just thinking about them is making me hungry! In the future I would skip the dessert and go down the street to Swensen's for some ice cream.
author: Jackie C.

description:
After drinking a huge glass of wine for only $3 from across the street, my mom, grandma and I moved over here to hit up their happy hour and wait for the rest of our family. 

My sister immediately order the oysters upon arrival-happy hour 12 oysters for $12- which you can mix and match between locals and others. I am constantly faltering between whether I like oysters or not and I think this place made up my mind. They were excellent served with lemon and a perfect sauce including horseradish. One was so large and buttery I refused to believe it even was an oyster, the texture was so soft it melted in your mouth. The local ones were great too. I decided I need to become a regular oyster eater. By the time my dad arrived there were no oysters left so we HAD to order more. Hehe.

The waiter was very attentive and helpful although we were there quite early and the restaurant was sparsely occupied. Bread and water were abundant along with wineglasses and napkins which tells you a lot about this kind of place. It's a little classy.

My sister, grandma and I all ordered the stuffed trout which was two layers of fish with a bread crumb sort of mixture stuffed in the middle. It came with your choice of fresh vegetables and potatoes. They were accomodating of my request for all veggies. It was really good even though the stuffing was a bit salty but they were generous with the amount of fish they serve. I finished all of mine and my grandma finished about a 1/4 of hers. Typical. 


This place is a bit pricey for my taste which isn't to say the food was bad, it was really good! I would definitely come back for the happy hour oysters which were the highlight of my dining experience.
author: Rachel G.

description:
Solid four-star joint.  Tempted to go a little lower, because they really need to figure out their heating system.  It was blasted COLD near the windows, and I saw space heaters scattered about, so I'm guessing it's not just the window area that is a problem.  But, on to the food...
Coming from Michigan in February (one can only have so much lake trout), we were all about some dungeness crab.  And their garlic roasted whole crab did not disappoint at ALL.  Oh, so tasty.  Would have liked more than three tiny potatoes and one anemic asparagus spear & mini carrot to accompany it, but all in all, it hit the spot.  My husband loved his kumamoto oysters and was very happy with the server's recommendations in that area.  The lobster bisque was very tasty.  I would certainly recommend this place for a great seafood meal and a fair price.  Wear a coat.  One that you plan to keep on all night.
author: Jennifer R.

description:
This review is only for their Oysters and Lobster Bisque. 

After not being able make it to for Swan's Oyster Bar, we came here in search of oysters. 
Best Happy Hour Oyster deal I've seen to date. 

$12 for a Dozen. They had 3 different kinds, from different areas, you can mix and match. 

Got here right when it opened for dinner, around 5:30 or so, wait staff was extremely nice, and were quick to bring us drinks and bread to start. 

Oysters were very fresh. Brother and I each ordered a dozen to start, and quickly made our way around. Since they were so delicious, we ordered another round, and they came out as quickly as the first. 

After stuffing ourselves with oysters, we were still just a bit hungry, so we ordered the Lobster Bisque (since so many yelpers recommended it).

It was a good sized bowl, and it had me at first spoonful. Rich, creamy and full flavored, with just a touch of congac/brandy, it's everything you thought a bisque should be. But wait, there's more! They blended it with  real crab meat so there was plenty of crab and lobster flavor through every gulp. It's not your traditional smooth bisque, but hey, it was damn good. 

Swan's will still be my favorite to get Clam Chowder but I will definitely be back for the Oyster Happy Hour and Lobster Bisque! :)
author: Kathy C.

description: It has the best oyster I've ever had! We also ordered the whole crab and the garlic prawn. They are awesome! Definitely going back and recommending to my friends!
author: Anthea X.

description:
If I could live on any street in the city, it would be hyde.  And that's just for the ambiance.  All of the amazing food is just icing on the cake (although there are no bakeries, I should take note of this).  Tim and I were looking for a place to go on a Wednesday night and this was the winner since I didn't want sushi and he was feeling fishy.

The waiter suggested another item to tim when he ordered an item that was apparently not good at all.  He explained to us why and thoughtfully recommended the house specialty. It did not disappoint.  I had the stuffed prawns, it was like shrimp scampi on crack, in a good way.  The special was mixed seafood in papioltte.  For how simple it was, the flavors were amazing and everything was perfectly done.

I will definitely come back here to try everything else on the menu, except the pork chop.  Our waiter also told us to stay away from that one.  Thanks waiter!  You're the best.
author: jessica b.

description:
Good neighborhood spot.

Appetizers:
Oysters - good (and the price great for happy hour).  

Dinner
Sea scallop - ok.  The veggies were great, the scallops were good.  Nothing spectacular, but good

Friend ordered the snapper.  I didn't hear any complaints.

The service was great!  They are attentive and pleasant.
author: brandie y.

description:
Just got off a week of work, and I was in serious need of a happy hour.  Not because work sucks; no, work's awesome.  I'm just  never going to get use to these hours.

Anyways, I headed over to this place because I was craving oysters.  I walked by last week and saw the $12 dozen special, so it made sense to come back.  Let me tell you, this place was not at all what I expected.  It was classy, like New England style homes; I mean the walls were creatively adorned with nautical paraphernalia like maps and model sailboats and other than the happy hour special, things weren't looking too cheap.

Fast forward 30 min, I walked out happy as can be.  12 oysters (BC were my favorite) and a Stella really did do the trick.  And for only about ~$17 including tip, it can't really be beat.  I've only lived in SF for 2 weeks, so this definitely begins my quest for the best seafood in town.
author: Nick W.

description:
best kept secret in san francisco :)
ABSOLUTELY MY FAVORITE HAPPY HOUR OYSTERS PLACE!!! couldn't stop raving about it

beats Hogs Island ANYDAY. I came saturday at 5 pm. No line, no wait, fast service. LOVE IT!

Happy hour from 5-7 EVERYDAY, $1 oysters, $2.50 beer is a very very good deal. Plus french bread+ butter mmmm. The oysters were SOOOOOOOOO fresh. I was drooling throughout the entire dinner. 

These are the three types of oysters for happy hour:

Skookum (Washington)- creamiest oyster on the platter. medium size, just perfect.

Hama Hama (Washington)-  sweetest of them bunch, smaller in size. 

Fanny Bay (B.C)- Biggest in size. Fresh and sweet as well. 

Now for the sauces, they were absolutely PERFECT. I actually really love the sauces they had on the side. Cocktail sauce and red wine/vinegar/onion sauce goes with the oysters sooooo well. damn it was like a taste of heaven. 

Lobster Bisque was perfect. Bits and pieces of lobster in every spoonful of creamy bisque. Sweet and savory. 

i loved all the oysters. I suggest ordering a mixture of all, trying them and see which one you like. My favorite is the creamiest, which is the Skookum. mmmmmmm =)'''' best oyster experience ever. I would definitely come back.
author: Juan C.

description:
This place had all sorts of funny/tacky kitsch on their walls, which is pretty rare in San Francisco, land of the spare and fashionable.  It was kinda fun.

I really enjoyed the food.  I had snapper en papillotte, which was cooked perfectly and had lots of great steamed veggies.  I also had the seafood chowder, which was also really good, with more milk and less flour in the soup.  The entree seemed reasonably priced, too, which is always nice.

The service was terrible though.  There were three people serving customers for too many tables.  Everything seemed to come late.  While the servers weren't rude, they just seemed so informal and untrained in table dining that I could have been in a taqueria.  They should work on this.

The wine selection was nothing special, so I had beer.
author: Reuben S.

description:
First went into the Restaurant and no hosts to greet us or no waiters around.

Went in to check out their Happy Hour menu. Delicious food. The $12 dozen oysters and it was great!

I would def recommend getting the bacon wrap scallops that was on the happy hour menu. I don't like eating bacon AT ALL, but I tried it this time and I WOULD get this again in a heart beat!

The waiter was very friendly and always checked up on us to make sure everything was fine.
author: Rachel J.

description: Went for happy hour on Labor Day, great place.  It was recommended by our hotel concierge desk.  Oysters were phenomenal. Service and attention were great. We tend to enjoy our oysters with crackers, they didn't have any. The group of 18 behind us were a little annoying and distracting. Very disrespectful to the staff, but the staff managed the situation very well!  Highly recommend this place for oysters!!
author: Deepak T.

description:
4.5 stars!! We had the most charming waiter.. He was friendly, incredibly knowledgeable and told us that our selections sounded like a yelp review.. hahaha He's obviously a fan. 

The food at Hyde Street SH&RB was fantastic.. Such a pleasant surprise! Our friends were in town from Toronto... Why does everyone always want a seafood rest when they visit SF. Thanks to yelp I found this gem!

The lobster bisque was spectacular! One of the best I've ever had... 

D and I shared the Dungeness Crab.. Others at the table had the pork chop - he loved it, the oysters - you cant go wrong with these.. and the stuffed prawns..he was salivating..

This is an absolute recommend! I love this place!!
author: Monica S.

description:
Took my Mom here last Friday who was visiting from out of town. Still my favorite seafood place in SF! Great neighborhood gem for those who want to get a feel for SF. 

We had mussels & clams to start, followed by cioppino, stuffed prawns, & butterfish. All entrees came with fresh vegetables & fresh bread. Completely delicious! We loved it AGAIN!
author: Kim D.

description:
-1 star for the hostess/our waitress.  Since, the place was absolutely empty around 5pm on a monsoonal weeknight, with only 2 other tables occupied by couples, we asked to be seated at the window 4 person table (as a party of 2) informing them we'd be in and out. The hostess refused (which is a-ok) but was very rude about it, to the point that in retrospect we would have left, given her disgusted and offended facial expressions at the sheer thought of our request (BLASPHEMY, right?).

We ordered lobster bisques and fish, both of which were brought out promptly.  The fish was prepared simply and had delicious flavors, I would order it again IF I ever go back. We were out of there in 45min, and not a single other party was seated while we were there.
author: Sara S.

description:
$1 oysters? I'm sold! 

I came here after going to Hog Island. It's great but it was $30 for a dozen. We yelped and found this gem. Happy hour is 5-7pm everyday. Super fresh oysters and delicious cocktail sauce too. The staff is awesome--very friendly. LOVE this place.
author: Khanh P.

description: Not bad for a seafood place to bring out of town guests (the cable car zips by every few minutes!) but the food is just okay. I had a garlic prawn dish, which was done well, but not memorable. To me, the SF seafood snob, it was like a nicer version of a shrimp scampi. This fared well with my friends from out of town, but there are just so many good seafood places in SF that do a better job with this dish. The seafood baked in parchment was pretty good, though. Probably should have gone with that one. Maybe next time...
author: Cindy S.

description:
As beautiful as the service was and as nicely everything was done. I am not sure that I would come back. The food was just alright. I'm not sure that I was too convinced by a seafood restaurant that gave me decent seafood.

The mussels were good, but nothing memorable.

I received the rainbow trout as my entree and while it was delicious, a strange part of it made me sick. Perhaps it was the strange mix of filler in the filet. I'm unsure.

I would suggest the parchment cooked fish because it looked delicious and I could've only hoped that I would've gotten one of those before my rainbow trout.

All in all, I thought it was ok as a restaurant and disappointing for a seafood place...
author: Winè C.

description:
First off, I have never been here for a formal dinner, but I have been for happy hour at least ten times. The place has a very neighborhood feel, the service is friendly, and we always sit at a table. Almost every time, we order the oysters, beer and lobster bisque. The oysters and beer are both excellent values, but the lobster bisque is the scene stealer - simply one of the best in the City.

The happy hour is more of a couples and/or group event, rather than a singles place. If you are looking to eat, drink and chat with friends, this is a place I would recommend.
author: Daniel S.

description: It was alright nothing great there are better places to eat in the city. I guess if you live in the area and want dim lighting with a warm ambiance then sure. But this was Chinese cooking with an American twist. What happy hour special??? All I saw was $14 for 1/2 dozen oysters. Didn't get them. Had the onion soup which was more like cheese soup with sauteed onions, mussels which didn't taste too fresh, steak which was ALRIGHT and stuffed prawns. The portions were small bill came out to $100 with wine. I won't go back but I appreciate the experience. The waiter was friendly but he was the best part. Everything else was eh.
author: J C.

description: The food was ok, but not worth the price. I got the escolar, which was fantastic, and the scallions, which were terrible. I paid $35 for a meal that was worth maybe $20. The service was slow, but very friendly.
author: Sarah S.

description:
My absolute favorite restaurant in SF! My husband and I have been coming to Hyde Street Seafood for almost 10 years now, and have never had a bad meal. Happy Hour from 5-7 is the best time to stop in. A dozen oysters will only set you back $12.50, and beers are $2.50 for pints of Anchor Steam. When I have had two dozen oysters and a beer, you have made me a very happy girl in SF. 

We stopped in this past Friday for two dozen oysters, a Caesar salad for two, lobster bisque (which is creamy dreamy), along with entrees. Everything was fab as per usual. My husband had the seafood combo special of Escolar, Shrimp, and Scallops. All of the selections were awesome. I had the seafood stuffed trout which was hearty and light tasting at the same time. I love Hyde Street, and I would highly recommend it to anyone.
author: Erin M.

description: I visit SF once or twice a year and this is the one place I HAVE to go to at least once during every visit.  Neighborhood restaurant feel.  Upscale casual environment.  Half price oysters and beer specials for happy hour are a great value.  Check their website for HH hours before you go.  Best Chioppino I've had in the area with large chunks of seafood and a light tomato-base sauce with a great blend of spices.  The lobster bisque is very good too.  I wasn't too impressed with their baked fish in paper that they are known for, but it may be because I'm not a fan of baked fish in general.  The trolley stops right in-front of the restaurant, which is very convenient.  The service has always been courteous and friendly (they seem to have kept the same staff for over three years now - WOW!).  Highly recommended.
author: Maria B.

description:
Cemile A. is right about the wait time. We had reservations and wejust stood there while people scrambled around us. They need to figure out how to work the door a little bit and pace the seating...the way they sat the tables  was totally Chinese restaurant style ("Everybody down! You ready to order everything now?? No? Ok, See you in an hour if I remember you're here.") and led to our poor experience there.

So yeah, we got sat. I noticed that they had sat 2 4-tops a 3 and three more deuces along with us at the same time in an effort to clear their door. That's nineteen menus up, for all of you at home who are counting, and that's bad. Sometimes that just means everythings going to go wrong at one table, but usually it just means something goes kinda wrong at every table.

Note to readers: when you see a bunch of tables get dropped at once in a *seafood* restaurant, LEAVE. You may feel inclined to think to yourself, "Oh, great, they're really doing their best to move the line here/minimize the wait-how hospitable!" and although that is a pretty natural reaction, it actually causes big problems. When a bunch of tables get sat at once, it means the kitchen's about to get punched hard. That usually leads to your seafood being undercooked (almost always). Trust me. As an ex restaurant manager, I was far more willing to have people get in my face about a wait because I was pacing the kitchen than to have them get in my face about raw fish. No one remembers a wait if there's great food at the end of it. Everyone remembers f'ed up seafood, no matter what the wait was.

From the beginning we were rushed. We waited 20 min at the door with reservations and then another 15 min at our table just to be acknowledged. When we were, it was "You ready to order?" How about selling me a bottle of wine? And I knew it was going to be one of those dinners because at this point -of course- everybody's freaking slammed. 

Anyway, we got some oysters...they were good. We wanted another round of 6 but, our waiter never returned to see if we liked the first six. Finally (I think he was a manager) noticed my bobbing head and he put another oyster order in for us.

Finished our wine, no one's coming back to find out if we want more, I finally have to go back to the door to get a wine list. Ended up getting a glass instead of a bottle because our meals will be half done by the time we order and get it anyway.

My wife and I both got fish en papillote (the specialty here). They're both totally raw in the middle. No one even bothers to ask if we're enjoying them (but the catch 22 of seafood is that the undercooked part is never the first 3 bites, so even if a server had come back to check on us we wouldn't have known). In fact our server never came back at all. The person who came back to take our plates just asked "You all done?" and took our plates, ignoring the chunks of raw fish left on our plates with everything else eaten. 

To be fair, we probably should have gotten up and grabbed a server as soon as we noticed that, but we were both getting full, and what we had was pretty good. We considered the business of the place and what we had experienced up to that point and decided it wasn't worth it because we both already knew we weren't coming back. There's too many great restaurants in our neighborhood to even stress on it.

Finally, we asked for a check and waited for 15 minutes. I honestly figured that we could have walked out and no one would have noticed that we didn't pay and in the chaos probably assume that we had. Thought about that hard but finally asked again and it came...then when the charge came back, there was no pen! Total DIY dining experience.

I know, I know, I should put it on whitewhine, but seriously...the kitchen is able to cook good food, that much is clear. It's the service that is killing it. Bummer...won't be back ever.
author: Sbicy Meatball J.

description:
This review is for their happy hour only. 

This place is my personal favorite dollar oyster joint in the city.  Happy hour runs everyday 5-7 with $1 oysters (must order by the dozen) and $2.50 beers.  It offers 3 types of oyster everyday and usually the type varies depending on the day you go.  We typically start with a combo plate, figure out our favorites and go from there.   It also comes with two dipping sauce (cocktail and house vinaigrette) along with the usual lemon and tobasco.

Another favorite that my friend swears by is the lobster bisque.  I haven't had lobster bisque too many times outside of this, so no point of comparison.  But every time he offers me a spoon, I find myself hard to not go for seconds.  That must count for something right?  
 
Only drawback: the bread.  Just skip it.  Don't even touch it.  I know it's tempting, in between your beer and oysters, but please.  You'll just regret it.  

The best part about this place is that due to its location, barely anyone seems to know about the oyster deal, so its never packed (unlike Hogs Island, where you're practically hovering over strangers).  Parking can be hard, but it's never been too bad.  From the server's attire and ambiance, the place seems to normally draw an older neighborhood clientèle.  But I'm just here for my oysters and beer, so who cares.
author: Christina D.

description:
I've had a very very sick man running to the bathroom all day after eatting here bad oysters nothing really more I can say 

I wish it hand't been the case as the reviews for this place look pretty good overall 

I
author: Sarah jane D.

description:
Definitely a fan of $12 for a dozen oysters.  And $2.50 for pints......sweet

But to walk up that insane hill then reaching at the top and huffin and puffin.....yah, its kinda worth it.  

I didn't come here for dinner, but did make it for the happy hour and the $12 dozen oyster special.  Compared to Hog Island, I think their oysters are bigger and less rushed.  Its nice to just enjoy an oyster or 12 for me and my girl on a nice Tuesday evening.  Me sipping on my Stella and she on her white wine.  (NO Special on wine!), but I forgive you.  jk

So yah, maybe if I'm ballin enough, I'll actually stay for dinner some time.  But that day has not come yet, so in the meantime, oysters are all I want.
author: Vincent K.

description: I had the lobster bisque for my first course. Let me start off by saying, the food here is cooked with a lot of butter and cream in a very conspicuous way. I think if this is your idea of comfort food and you like seafood this is the place to go. But, I wouldn't go back because it's not my style. The lobster bisque was really creamy, good, but nothing exciting. Then we had a fish course, to be honest, I can't remember what kind of fish we had. Again, I thought it was good, but not great. I wondered if I ordered all the wrong things. The place was getting crowded as we left (popular place I supposed) and the service was nice.
author: G F.

description: Great food and atmosphere.  It was my roommate's birthday and she wanted oysters, so I thought this would be a great time to try Hyde Street Seafood House and Raw Bar.  We ordered a dozen of the mixed oysters on the half shell, half a dozen Kumamoto oysters (my personal fav!) and another half dozen of the clams.  I have to say, that was my first time having clams on the half shell.. and they were delicious!  I don't know why I haven't had them before!  Crisp, fresh, and slightly chewier than oysters -- they had great flavor.  We also had the lobster bisque, the Halibut En Papillote, and the seafood fettuccine.  All were delicious.  I particularly loved the Halibut En Papillote.. the fish was cooked to perfection and the vegetables were fresh and crisp.  Definitely not the cheapest place, but for a casual night out with friends -- definitely worth it.
author: Joanne K.

description:
Freshest seafood I have ever had.

We came here on a Saturday night, so food was a bit slow. Despite that, the staff was very friendly, and checked on us several times before and after the food arrived. I had their raw oyster, bacon wrapped scallop, and sea bass en papillote, all of which were excellent.
author: Wei L.

description: I wanted to like this place based on all the great reviews but the shrimp in two different entrees were not good. The sauce on my mixed seafood tasted straight out of the Knorr package. I wouldn't go back. Cute decor but on a Saturday night dinner out...this just should have been better.
author: Sarah M.

description: I was yelping a good seafood place in San Francisco, when I decided to come here. I was not disappointed. Got the happy hour $1 oysters.. MAGNIFICENT! Got the lobster bisque and the red snapper en papillotte (wrapped in paper) Everything was wonderful, great service too! Will come back again, next time I'm in town.
author: Melanie E.

description: Not bad actually... their butterfish was especially good... although I wasn't too fond of the Salmon... really? Potatoes ON fish? Urgh... Soju drinks are cheap and yummy... but besides that, the Raw bar is kind of misleading... 4 kinds of oysters and everything else is cooked? Not very raw... I'd say pass on this and find some truly raw bars with not only oysters but other raw yummy fishes...
author: Nathan D.

description:
Good price.  
The oysters were ok, but the fish (wrapped in paper) we ordered wasn't that great.  Cioppino was pretty good.
author: Elena L.

description:
I'm really rethinking my order last night. 

The stuffed rainbow trout really made me sad. I expected something stuffed, not a rainbow trout sandwich. 

The good thing is, the sis ordered the cioppino so I was able to get some of that into my system. 

Bread and butter came from a fischer price play set. 

Not to mention, after being served copious amount of water, and needing to empty bladder...the toilet seat was decorated with abstract fecal art (shit, man)!
author: Stef Y.

description:
A great little neighborhood spot.  If you want well-prepared seafood without having to deal with the lines of Swan Oyster Depot or the cramped noise of Bar Crudo or Yabbies, this is a good spot.

The oysters were fresh and the happy hour prices won't break your wallet.  I ordered the butterfish cooked in the parchment paper and it was one of the best fish dishes I've had in SF.  It sealed in the flavor along with the butter and herbs to make a perfect compliment to the cold, saltwater taste of the oysters.

In terms of atmosphere, we had a cozy table right in the window.  Several yelpers have complained about the temperature.  They must have fixed that problem because I am VERY sensitive to cold restaurants and I found it to be quite pleasant.  I would gladly go back to this place.
author: Tom R.

description:
I can't really find a reason to give this place anything other than five stars. We ate a lot of food, the service was great, the wine was good, you don't need a reservation, and the list goes on (well in my mind it does, but it stops here in writing)
Anyway, definitely try this place. Try the Raw Oysters even if you have never tried them before (it was my first time). Everything was delicious and I'll go back again.
author: Jack C.

description:
Not the most innovative menu ever, but it's conventional seafood done very, very well.

I brought my visiting parents here tonight.  They are old school New Englanders when it comes to seafood, so Pesce and Farallon might have been a little too weird for them.  Hyde Street Seafood turned out to be just right.  

Dad and I loved the clam chowder, Mom andI liked the prawns stuffed with lobster, crab, and scallops.  I would order both again.  

We all loved our desserts which included key lime pie and chocolate cheesecake.

The atmosphere is great, it's quiet, but there's enough energy in the room that it doesn't feel dead.  The decor is a lot of old sea navigation maps, and I loved the lighting and lighting fixtures.  

The restaurant is located on that stretch of hyde with white christmas lights in the trees. the cable car whirls around the corner every few minutes and, well, if you know Hyde Street at all, you know it's a pretty amazing block.

I lived about four blocks away from here for three years and wish I'd discovered this gem of a restaurant then!
author: Dave M.

description:
Happy hour is a great deal, the oysters are very fresh. 

We came again for dinner.

the food was *pretty* good. I ordered the stuffed trout which is not actually their specialty. My boyfriend got cioppino which is generally hit or miss. 

the bread was super good and the butter was even better. special butter? not sure but it's great. 

the ceasar salad was good as well, not drenched in ceasar dressing, and they serve theirs with anchovies which I always love.

the service was slow but the waiter was great but just really busy.
author: Claire b.

description: This is a great restaurant. I remember visiting my brother in SF in 1986 and going to this restaurant the first time and have been there a few times since. They had recently opened and the couple that owned it at that time were from New England. I believe somebody else in their family owns it now but the food is delicious. Over the years the excellent quality has been maintained. I loved the Papillotte style and usually order the seafood wrapped in a special paper that keeps the flavor in and it was absolutely delicious. Parking is a bit difficult in this area so keep that in mind when visiting this restaurant.
author: Anthony L.

description:
One dozen oysters for $12, two dozen oysters for $24. yum times twenty four! oh yea, beers were $2.50.

the place is cute, split level with a bar, with a huge stuffed sailfish.

the service was excellent. very attentive, and even said "happy hour ends in 5 minutes, do you want to put in another order of oysters at happy hour pricing?"

i'll most likely be back for another dozen between 5-7pm
author: Ameer N.

description:
It's three blocks from where I live, but that can't make up for the ridiculous mediocrity that is this restaurant.

I suppose the first bad sign is that they advertise outside that they're featured in the hotel guides, so they cater to tourists. Don't savvy tourists know to avoid those things and try to pick up flavor from locals instead?

And the second warning flag is that it's next to the cable car line. I mean, that's no automatic disqualification, but it sure makes it easy to become a tourist trap, no?

Yes, we went in sans reservation, but they seated us quickly! That was the last quick thing all night. It took - wait for it - 14 minutes from when we sat down until got our first acknowledgement from any server. We ordered and waited - wait for it - wait for it some more - 26 minutes for the food. Is that unreasonable? I don't know, I'm hungry!

The bread and butter were offensive. Cold, hard, and - in the case of the butter - slightly rancid. My goodness. It's not hard to get bread and butter right.

My dish? "Potato Crusted King Salmon with pinot noir sauce". Sounds great! When it finally arrived, it looked pretty good, too. At first glance. I've seen dishes with sauce under the food instead of on top - yeah, it's a presentation thing - but here, the (delicious! wonderful!) sauce was daintily spooned around it, which would become a problem.

And the crust? Yes, hash browns. Except the part on top wasn't brown, it was limp. Limp and soggy. The fish? Overcooked to the point of bone dry. I was nearly begging for more sauce by the time I got to the end of it.

The vegetables on the side were simply steamed (broccoli and carrots) and roasted (potatoes). Good, but lacking in a certain department...

The worst part about the plate was that I had to do something I haven't done in a restaurant for many years. I reached for the salt shaker. Because my dish didn't seem to include any.

Really, the place isn't so bad for what it's trying to be, but the experience I had there was just such a load of failure. It's a shame; it's clear that what goes in is good stuff, but I'm disappointed that they don't make better use of it.
author: Jim P.

description:
It would be hard to find a more charming spot on which to place a restaurant than Hyde Street.  It would be hard to find a more poorly prepared meal than I had at this place.  Ouch!

I started with an appetizer of crab cakes that came with mixed greens.  I couldn't taste the crab in the cakes.  The dressing was unevenly applied to the greens: a taste of vinegar here, undressed greens there.

Mahi mahi En Papillote, baked in paper.  A horror.   The food in the parchment is supposed to be steamed through and therefore fresh and tasty.  Here the preparation was inept.  The unevenly cut fish was a bit overcooked at the edges and absolutely raw elsewhere.  In other words stringy and disgusting.  The potatoes were mushy at the edge and crunchy near raw in the center.  Ugh!   

Service was OK.  But I deserved better for my money and the food deserved better for its sacrifice.  Come to think of it I sacrificed as well.
author: David D.

description:
I came here after a recommendation for a seafood place.  It's a lovely neighborhood and parking was surprising easy on a Friday evening at 6pm.

That's as far as my luck went.  We were greeted with unhappy faces but we got seats with little delay.  We ordered 3 dozen oysters and a seared tuna.  The tuna and salad was ok.  The oysters however were not good.  The first couple tasted fine.  But then I started noticing more and more shell flakes on the oyster.  And then some did not taste that fresh.  They even skimped out on the lemon slices.  I got about 5 drops of lemon juice, definitely not enough to cover up the taste.  And then there was one big oyster that I bit into that was really foul.  I instantly went for the bathroom to spit it out.  After I came out, I asked for the check and left.
author: Larry L.

description:
A hidden gem here it in the city.  The decor in the place is very interesting and unique.  You feel like you are inside a ship with maps lining the wall.

We started out with the raw oysters.  They were extremely fresh and came with a variety to sauces to top it off.  Of course we also had the lobster bisque.  I felt like it had just the right consistency and the lobster chunks were just the right size.

For my main course I had the Baked Stuffed Rainbow Trout which is stuffed with lobster, scallops, shrimp & crab meat.  Some of the best seafood you can get in the bay area.

The staff here is extremely helpful and friendly.  Another rarity in the city.
author: Danny P.

description:
I absolutely adore this place. This is genuine, heartfelt, praise from Lisa W., here...

If you're looking for a great date spot... BINGO. It's sitting quite possibly on the cutest effing corner in all of Nob Hill, if not the entire city. With Christmas lights perpetually twinkling in the trees outside, big storefront windows, and the cable cars zooming by...

The walls of the side room are papered with old nautical charts: an obsession of mine. My dad taught me to navigate the Great Lakes by hand using nautical charts and a compass when I was a kid (rest his enginerdy soul), and there's something so comforting about dining on seafood in a room surrounded by artifacts of old salts like my father.

Everyone who's ever waited on me here has been equally charming. The kind of waiter who makes me want to order one more Anchor Steam, because I'm enjoying my meal that much...

But the best part about Hyde Street isn't it's raw bar -- which is just okay. It's their fantastic en papillote dishes -- seafood cooked with vegetables in parchment. It's a light, healthy way of preparing fish that mingles the flavors of everything inside the parchment in an interesting, thought-provoking way. The same way a chart of Cuba and its surrounding waters across from my table gets my brain tingling.

An easy pick for the 2-year anniversary dinner with SuperBF.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Made a reservation for 9pm on 2/11/2011. We get there right at 9, the place is about 3/4 full. 

We wait for about 15 minutes to be acknowledged by a server or host. Several walk by multiple times, but no one looks at or says anything. At that point two seats at the bar open up and we sit down to wait for a table. Bartender does not acknowledge us or offer water, even though we're the only ones at the bar. I brought a bottle of sparkling wine with me and I ask the bartender if he could chill our sparkling for us. He brusquely tells us he'll put it in the fridge and send it out in a bucket when our table is ready. Not sure why he didn't start chilling it right then. . .   

While sitting at the bar, I notice that the two servers, bartender, and manager are all bussing glassware to the bar, carrying dirty glasses from above with their fingers inside. Not ideal. Quite disgusting, in fact.  

Another 10 minutes, our table is ready. I ordered the clam chowder and the stuffed shrimp bearnaise. My girlfriend orders the caesar salad and the potato crusted king salmon. 

Our server brings our bottle of sparkling out in an ice bucket. I look inside, and there is only about one inch of water and ice in the bucket. They have some pitchers of water sitting around, so I top it up. 

The clam chowder is good. The caesar had no actual caesar dressing. Instead it was a tasteless mixture of oil and vinegar with lemon. 

After another 10 minutes, our server offers to open the bottle. He pulls off the cage while talking to us, we duck for cover as he points the uncaged bottle around the room. The wine is a 1999 Schramsberg reserve- 10 years old. 

When opening old bubbly, it is very dangerous not to keep your hand over the cork at all time. Due to age, the corks lose the flange that keeps them tightly wedged into the neck, and can shoot out immediately. I've opened many bottles of 10-year old bubbly that would have done just that if I had not kept a firm grip on the cage and cork. 

He then manages to break the cork off, with the bottom half stuck in the bottle. Rather than twisting it gently, he had yanked it over to one side and it split. He brings out the corkscrew at this point, and I tell myself that if my $120 bottle of wine fizzes everywhere due to his lack of wine training, I'm going to lose it. 

Thankfully, he manages to get the cork out and we resume our dinner. 

Our food arrives. My stuffed shrimp is not in a bearnaise as on the menu, but rather straight-up clarified butter. The potato crust on the salmon is limp and greasy, and totally bland and unsalted. 

Moral of the story, I will never go back to this place. Between the unsanitary conditions, lack of basic service, the general indifference of the manager, and the mediocre food, there are far better places to spend my money.
author: Michael H.

description:
i could make this a 4 star but ultimately decided to go 3 star.  We would go back but will look for other options.    the food was good.  I had the mushroom app and my gf had the scallops wrap.  We both really enjoyed them.  they came with a side salad which was fresh and was tasty.  dinners included the filet mignon with scallops and the seafood mix.  the filet was fresh, cooked as requested but came with no sauce to augment.  i would recommend some sauce, the vegs were good.  The seafood mix was nice and healthy but lack a bit of taste.  My GF liked it but not loved it.  the bread was less that quality (plain white bread that was served cold).  

dessert was the star. We shared Ice cream and cookies (solid choice) and the banana bread pudding (outstanding, just completely satifying).

Service was solid and friendly.

atmosphere was nice but got loud quickly.
author: Tim F.

description:
Hyde Street Seafood is one of my favorite restaurants in SF. 

Service is friendly, attentive, and unpretentious, there is an extensive wine list and the atmosphere is perfect for a date or intimate night with friends. You typically can walk in on weekdays without a reservation, and nothing beats sitting outside on Hyde on a warm night.

Anything 'en papillilote' is fantastic - fresh fish cooked within in a paper parchment swimming with delicious, buttery veggies and sauces. The halibut, butterfish and salmon all melt in your mouth. 

If you are looking for fish in Nob/Russian Hill, look no further.
author: Tory F.

description: Parking is a PAIN!  Do not drive here!!  I got Shellfish Combination En Papillote and it was flavorless. Service was slow.  The restaurant had a cute atmosphere in a nice part of the city, but overall I was left underwhelmed.  If you're in San Francisco, you can do better.
author: Jen H.

description:
Yummy oysters for $1 each during happy hour? Check.

Yummy lobster bisque? Check.

Yummy pint of draft beer for $2.50 (another happy hour special)? Check.

Yummy shellfish cooked en papillote style? Check.

Attentive owner? Check.

Only minus was slow service and our unfriendly server. The owner came over to service us more often than our server and was much more friendly.

Came to this place because our original plan of going to Hog Island Oyster Company for their happy hour was FOILED.
author: Christina C.

description:
I fell in love the moment I walked in.  The place was just opening for the night, and my family and I were warmly greeted.  Johnny was our server, and couldn't have been more gracious.

The lobster bisque is one of the best I've ever had, and believe me, I know my stuff: I am a seafood fiend, and a family member runs the best seafood store in the Chicago area.  The food here is amazing. We had scallops in a ginger cream sauce, stuffed prawns in bearnaise sauce, as well as a smoked salmon appetizer.  Washed it down with a nicely chilled Chardonnay.  

I want to load the place up and ship it, lock stock and barrel, back to Chicago.
author: Kitty K.

description: Delicious seafood, very attentive waiter, upscale yet homey environment. Can't wait to go back.
author: Danny W.

description:
I'm sad I don't come here as much as I used to.  I live a little further away than before, so it's harder to come around.

They have great oysters there.  The barmaid, the wait-staff, they all know their seafood, and they are very friendly.  Their oyster selection is excellent, and they are very good about talking about the world of oysters (big vs. small, briny vs. creamy, East Coast vs. West Coast, Texas vs. California, etc.).  That French thing they do of baking seafood in silicone paper is also a very tasty way of roasting seafood while keeping it moist.  

But it's the friendly crew working there that I liked the most.

During a visit there on a solo dining night, I spent a little bit of time chatting them up over oysters and anchor steam.  A few months later, on another solo dining night, they remembered me by name, and made me feel like I hadn't been gone more than a week.  

I only wish I had more time and more solo dining nights that I could spend there.
author: Stan C.

description: Lobster Bisque was amazing. Oysters very fresh, and the ambiance was homy and classic.
author: Jenny M.

description: Service was good.  Food was just ok.  Lobster bisque was the highlight.
author: Jay H.

description: love their oysters during HH.  Great varieties and top notch freshness!
author: Mike C.

description:
I live right down the street from here, so have been here numerous times. I do like their food, but for the lack of service and price, it's not always worth it. The people are nice, but they are always rushing around and I've gone too long without water in my glass.

If you go, I definitely recommend going for happy hour when it's $14 for a dozen oysters.
author: Sarah K.

description:
I've been here a half dozen times and loved each visit. Usually I take advantage of their incredible Happy Hour special -- a dozen oysters for $12 and a pint of draft beer for $2.50 -- and then supplement it with their delicious bread and lightly-salted, fresh, creamy butter. Sometimes I also spring for the fish cooked in parchment paper -- a preparation style where fish is wrapped in a packet of parchment with olive oil, spices, and vegetables, then gently steamed (allowing all the flavors to steep and stew into the fish) and then cut open at the table -- but mostly I go for the oysters + beer deal. 

If you get the oysters, ask for Fanny Bay as they are, imho, the biggest and most flavorful of the ones offered. If you don't specify a particular oyster, you'll just get a mixed selection of the three oysters available, which is good for a first-timer, but not for repeat offenders :).
author: Annie M.

description:
Probably because I had such high hopes for this place, I was really disappointed at the end. It wasn't a very busy night, but our food took forever to come. The raw oysters were good and the waitress very nice, but that was about all the good things I could say about this place.
