We order the infamous Lobster Bisque and it was just ok. Not much lobster taste but it wasn't bad. Chesear salad for two came and the portion was a bit small. I ordered the Escargot in butter and it had no taste. Then came the main dishes of a seafood salad with shells in it, fish with no taste, potatoes uncooked, and Cioppio that my mother-in-law could make better in her sleep. 

My sister said it best...Yelp has failed us for the very first time with Hyde Street Seafood.
author: Joy F.

description:
What wasn't good from this place?!?! From point A to point B was beyond awesome! A zillion stars to them!

Our waiter made our night, he was funny, helpful, and joked along with us. Can he be our personal waiter everywhere?

Free sourdough bread with yummy creamy butter? Yes please!

Lobster bisque: I've never had lobster bisque so I can't compare it to anything else, but it's gon be tough to have anything else compare to this.

New York steak: sauce was the cherry on top.

Stuffed prawns: read the description it's like 4 diff't kinds of seafood together. Every bite you take u can taste the difft kind of crustaceans in it.

Ok I'm gon stop drooling. For the quality of the food it's worth the money. Actually we didn't think it was expensive at all. Next time I come to SF this is a definitely a must visit.

And we had a bday thing here I brought in cupcakes and a stand they were willing to hold it for me.
author: Shirley T.

description: Excellent gem for seafood in the Nob Hill area. Came here to celebrate three birthdays in the month of October. This place is own and staffed by a Chinese family. There was no problem making a reservation on the night of the dinner. My party ordered the cold seafood sample platter and a dozen oysters as appetizers. Everything tasted fresh and well prepared. The subsequent entrees were very presentable. Most of us order the baked fish on parchment paper. The flavors of the seafood and seasoning were not lost and well balance, with nothing overpowering the other. I highly recommend this restaurant to locals and visitors.
author: Ben W.

description: Craving oysters so we found this place and gave it a try.  I don't recall much of the food, but ate a bunch of oysters.  They were good!  If it weren't for the parking dilemma, I'd come back way more often.  Now, we buy the kumamoto oysters at the Asian supermarket and shuck them.
author: Carrie-C N.

description: Yuck. The lobster bisque was just ok and so was the seafood pasta. All too much cream. The decor didn't help...it was dated and old. We sat next to an old space heater and the the fabric covered seats were soiled. The only saving grace was the fresh oysters.
author: Kosin H.

description:
I had the local snapper "en papiotte" and it was great! The veggies it was cooked with were amazing; covered in fresh herbs and LOTS of butter. MMM.

My Dad had the lobster bisque, and thought it was great. Unfortunately, my sister's shrimp salad was way overcooked, and the shrimp were not de-veined. My mom had a green salad with seafood, and the shrimp definitely came from a can, and the thousand island dressing from a bottle. It was bright orange and pretty nasty.

If you're going, order whatever the fresh special is, and the bisque, but I can't 't recommend anything else.
author: Lauren R.

description: Went here last night, nov19,2011.  Got food poisoning. Had steak& shrimp, definitely wont be going back
author: chris g.

description:
I'm currently lying on my bed in a food coma while typing this review.  It's either a food coma or food poisoning ..but I don't really care.

I never really venture around Nob Hill, but it was a first date and I really had no choice but to meet him there (I mean, it'd be mean for me to just not show up, right?).  It was a super cute, kitsch little place and even though his reservations were at 7:30, we arrived around 7 and they gave us our table early.

Super cute and kitsch on the inside as well - the walls were papered with old maps and there were nautical decorations around the room.  There was a candle at each table and it wasn't too dim or bright.  Great ambiance, and my only complaint was that the tables were somewhat close to each other, which doesn't really make for good conversation.

He had the ahi tuna, I had the snapper en papillotte (wrapped in paper and baked) - it was absolutely amazing.  The fish was amazingly tender and very well-seasoned.  The jullienned vegetables were also tasty, although the potatoes were a bit dry and unflavored, and I had to swirl them around in the juices in order for them to be somewhat palatable.  We also shared 6 raw oysters (which I think gave me the food poisoning, ouch) ..oh so delicious.

The dessert menu was meh, so we opted to walk a few blocks to Swensens for ice cream.  The service was super attentive and nice.  The comparable restaurant would be Pacific Cafe, which is farther away, but the perk is that they give free wine while you wait.
author: Tori S.

description:
This place was a happy accident.  We stumbled in early tonight and were pleasantly surprised by the happy hour special on a Saturday! $12 for 12 oysters and $2.50 beers.  The Fanny Bay oysters were large and mild, and out of the 3 options on the menus, these were my favorite.  

The sourdough bread was a nice touch and the salmon wrapped in parchment paper was moist and nicely seasoned. I was very happy with the food.  The service was a little sparse though.
author: Nita K.

description:
Along the Hyde Street Cable Car line, between a series of one-lane-one-way streets zig-zagging up & down Russian Hill lies the Hyde St Seafood House.

A close friend having her going-away dinner here prompted my first visit. After braving the daunting task of trying to find parking nearby, I arrived to a warmly illuminated interior with historic nautical decor- appropriate for a seafood & raw bar in Russian Hill.

I enjoyed a delicious lobster bisque and scallop, butterfish & shrimp special.

I was pleasantly surprised by the reasonable prices on their entrees and look forward to visiting again. By taxi.
author: John Eric S.

description:
Cute, quaint little neighborhood place on the other side of Nob Hill (that's what I call it, anyway). As it's been said before, oysters are a buck during happy hour. We were there for dinner but we still took full advantage of the happy hour oysters! We got 3 different kinds & I loved them all. The folks weren't big oyster fans so they got the crabcakes that looked delish. We also had to try the lobster bisque since everyone raves about it. I'd have to say they are right! 

For dinner I had the New Zealand seabass en papillote. It was cooked to perfection with fresh, crunchy veggies. Not a lot of seasoning, but I liked it that way. The portions are huge as fish portions go but everything was so light it wasn't overfilling. Everyone else had different types of fish (the halibut was the best in my opinion) and we ate it all. Topped it all off with a bottle of chardonnay. I have to say that the desserts were nothing to write home about so go elsewhere for your sweet fix. We were going to head to Ghirardelli Square for some sundaes but it got too late. Wah! 

The service was great, no need to ever flag anyone down for anything. It may be difficult to get to this place by public transport unless you take the cable cars (they go right by the restaurant). But since they cost $5 these days you are better off taking a cab. The server was nice enough to offer to call us a cab without us even asking. The cab arrived less than 5 minutes later. Now THAT'S service!
author: Erin S.

description:
Happy hour is cool. Cheap beer and oysters are fun. The service was just caca.

I ordered my second beer well before the end of happy hour. It took 15-20 minutes to get my beer, and was told I was being charged regular price since it wasn't happy hour anymore.

Food is alright, but service just plain sucks.
author: Bo G.

description:
I came here for dinner and was definitely disappointed. I'm telling you, this is not a 5 star place. 

1) We had a reservation, but they made us wait at the bar for 10-15 minutes because no table was ready.

2) The bartender was so rude to my boyfriend! My boyfriend was trying to order a drink, there was some miscommunication about the availability of the drink, and when my boyfriend politely asked -to clarify- if they were out of the beverage, the bartender replied snidely, "Yeah. That's what I just said." It was totally unprofessional and I feared my boyfriend might punch the little a-hole in the face. 

3) The food: Not so impressive. The best thing I ate was the Cajun shrimp and scallop appetizer, but it was coated in butter and totally overpriced, which tainted the experience. I am not an idiot- I can tell when a scallop has been cut in half- so we were paying $8 for 1 scallop and 2 shrimp. At this place? 

I read so many good things about the bisque, so I figured, "when in Rome," and ordered it. (Normally I don't like cream as an appetizer) Anyhow, it was not as good as everyone makes it out to be. It's far from an authentic lobster bisque and sure, it's heavy on the cream and filled with bits of lobster meat, but the meat tasted like surimi (fake crab). If this is the best lobster bisque you've ever had, I need to take you some places! 

Our main dishes were alright. I liked my boyfriend's parchment papered sea bass, but my escolar special tasted like it was bathed in bottled chili sauce. It wasn't refined or amazingly well-executed, although neither of the fish dishes were fishy. 

Finally, my boyfriend had the creme brulee, which was super melt-y and apparently tasted like a vanilla milkshake. Either they gave it the blow torch for too long, or it was not chilled long enough. Whatever the cause, it was a definite fail on a rather easy to prepare dessert.

4) Overall analysis: Skip it. Butter and cream can make anything taste palatable, but it has nothing to do with the quality of a restaurant.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Oysters are oysters ... yeah $12 for a dozen so great deal... but that's it. 

We went right at 5pm and it was dead. We were the only party there. 

Waitor was a sweetheart, tried to conversate about life and making us laugh. 

I wouldn't go back for happy hour ... BORING!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I feel bad giving this place a bad review as the staff was super sweet and attentive...and from the get go i didn't think it looked like an especially nice place (compared to the many quality options along hyde street...).  As a seafood fan, and my dad in town, we were looking at all the menus along polk and hyde..hyde street bistro was closed...and my father picked this one.  I was hesitant, but oh so accomodating...

They were relegating everyone to the back room, when the front room was a bit cuter and less crammed tables, but since the place was virtually empty (also not a good sign), that wasnt a huge deal.

As a liquor drinker, the menial cocktail menu (with soju mind you) was somewhat disappointing, so i skipped any beverages.  

My father got the caesar salad to start, and I got the cajun shrimp and scallops appetizer--also keep in mind my father and i thought we would share this appetizer..hmm..for $12ish it was literally 2 tiny scallops and 2 shrimp, in about an inch of butter.  Not a fan of heavy butter myself, I can't say that this was a good start.

My father got the paper fish or what not ,"En Papillote" (having never tried, i didnt want to risk it), and enjoyed his meal, and i asked between the potato crusted salmon and the stuffed trout which the waiter recommended--mentioning that i am not a big potato fan.  He said DEFINITELY the salmon, and that it was similar to hash browns...hmm..not too appealing being that i dislike hash browns and am not wild about potatoes.  I decided to try the stuffed trout, although ive only tried a stuffed fish once before (which was amazing, in nola).

The presentation again was subpar--the plates looked like cafeteria style, and my stuffed fish and side items (potatoes. yet again. with green vegetables--which i avoid) were both very dry.  I found a bone in my fish, and perchance should have pretended to choke on it and sue...kidding...

My father did enjoy his meal, and thought you get more for your money at an establishment such as this one, so at least one of us was impressed...and the staff again was quite nice (although i did want to say, no, i'm not enjoying it, this sucks.).  I guess if you want more for your money (although i'm not convinced thats the case) and friendly service, and don't care especially about presentation or the freshest fish/nicer ambiance, then this would be a good choice...but if in the area looking for seafood there are certainly better options. =(
author: Danielle J.

description:
HMM.. Just ok..

$1 Dollar Oysters were a bit warm... (1 star)
ordered the Pork Chops and was good. (2 Stars)
ordered Chocolate Cheesecake for dessert (1 star)

paid $5.00 for parking... (delete one star)

overall.. I won't be back, but thank you Hyde Street for a nice experience. Probably worth it if you live in the area.

I'd prefer Hog Island $1.00 anyday over this..
author: Emily L.

description: This place was really not impressive. The food was bland at best, mostly mucky and brown. The one high point was the clam chowder. The restaurant was packed, so maybe we just ordered wrong. We had the lobster bisque (eh), the fish en papillote (eh), some seafood pasta dish which was also bland and fishy and the clam chowder (worth eating). I probably won't go back here even though it is a block from my apartment, there is fantastic seafood to be had in SF and this really isn't it.
author: Kristen A.

description:
I had really high hopes for this place after seeing reviews. The service was very friendly and attentive. However, I was really underwhelmed with the food. I feel that for the quality and taste, it was very overpriced.

I had the stuffed rainbow trout. It was mediocre at best. I had to add a lot of pepper to get it decent and even then I only ate half of it. The vegetables were something I could have made at home. The potatoes, despite having claims of being flavorful on the menu, were quite plain. Another reviewer described it as "cafeteria style" and I have to agree.

My boyfriend had the garlic shrimp and although I did taste garlic in it, again, it was something I could make at home. I can only cook things halfway decent. So if I'm at a place like this, I am expecting something more than halfway decent!

Perhaps I should have ordered a parchment paper dish, but I probably won't bother coming back anyhow since I was so underwhelmed by the food.

Hyde Street Seafood House is trying to present itself as something more, and it's service meets that standard but the food does not.
author: Crystal C.

description:
My little sister was in town and she wanted to have some seafood so I found this place on Yelp.  It was awesome; freash seafood and good service, although the price isn't cheap but hey you get what you pay for.

We had oysters on the half shell -- which were extremely fresh and tasty (no Marin Miyagis though), perfectly cooked and seasoned crab cakes, and the stuffed prawns which were epic.  All that plus a bottle of bubbly, the only thing we weren't feeling were the curry scallops which were over cooked.
author: Ryan F.

description:
A friend took me here because he lived a few blocks away, and we were expecting good things - in a tree-lined neighborhood rife with wine bars, it's a "tourist-friendly" neighborhood that nevertheless still has charm. 

We left decidedly more disappointed.

To be fair, our server told us they were short-staffed for the evening - which explained the 15-minute wait time to be served once we'd been seated, made especially surprising by the fact that we were seated right away without reservation. It took twice as long to receive our food once we ordered, and as I'm a stickler for presentation, I was left severely wanting. The food was displayed unimaginatively, and while my stuffed fish was tasty, it could have used a good deal more color and showmanship. Make me want to eat this fish! 

The atmosphere was clever, at the the very least: I loved the wall behind the bar, lined completely with nautical maps. Now that's something I want for my own place.
author: J.T. T.

description: Great food in a lovely setting I had seafood and julienned vegetables in parchment paper -excellent
author: lyn m.

description:
$12 for the dozen oysters is unbeatable.  The oysters are so fresh and quality.  The two sauces that they serve (horseradish/cocktail sauce and red vinegar/garlic sauce) are a great addition to the mollusks.

Their current selection of happy hour oysters are: Steamboat, Fanny Bay, and Hama Hama.

- The Steamboat oysters are by far the best tasting oysters.  The best way to describe them, as the restaurant does, is "creamy".  They are large but very smooth.
- The Fanny Bay oysters are also a good alternative.  They have a little more texture and flavor.
- The Hama Hama are a little on the mediocre side.  Even if they were good, they are so small that you barely even get to taste them.  They are disappointingly small and some are really runt sized.

If I were to get a dozen, I would say get 8 Steamboats and 4 Fanny Bay.  Skip on the Hama Hama, they aren't worth it.  If none of these are in stock, just ask for the "creamiest" oysters.  I know, it sounds a little weird, but you'll thank me later.

Oh yeah, $2.50 pints.  Stella, Anchor Steam, Sierra Nevada, and Spaten on tap... they are all PERFECT to wash down some quality oysters.

The staff is also very attentive.  It is not a busy happy hour (I went on a Friday).  Just by the pure quality of the fresh oysters,  I will go here for dinner sometime soon.  Next time its a warm day, I am for sure enjoying happy hour here outside.
author: Joey S.

description:
Once again, yelp came thru!!!

I came here with my bf and my father for Father's Day, and I was pleasantly surprised to find that they were not packed, which meant a calmer environment for us to talk and visit.  Also, my Father requested a Seafood restaurant so I think this was exactly what fit the bill.

My dad got the sea bass in parchment paper, my boyfriend got the cippiono (sp?) and I got the seafood fetticine.

We were all satisfied with our meals and we even got some beer to go with it.  I loved my pasta a lot because there was seafood (shrimp, smoked salmon, and scallops) in every bite, yum!

Also they were very generous with the bread as well.  I notice they have a happy hour with their oysters so I know my boyfriend and I will definitely be back to get our oyster grub on!
author: Jaime P.

description: Hyde Street Seafood House and Raw Bar was awesome!! Especially the British Columbia oysters!! Will frequent this winner of a restaurant!!
author: Heidi B.

description:
Service was Excellent - the server was very knowledgeable in the wine selection which i think sometimes it's more important then giving advice on food. 

Food was Excellent and Super Affordable - we ordered 2 dozen oysters amongst 4-5 ppl. Lobster bisque was yummmm......and the seafood salad was good but not the best I've had. For entrees we ordered the seafood cioppino, pepper crusted steak and stuffed prawns. 

For dessert we had tiramisu and bread pudding = SMILES!! 

WARNING!!! It's really hard to find parking so I suggest you find a parking lot on Polk St after circling around the block.
author: Deb C.

description: I love this place. They have some amazing salads *try the crab louis* and their lobster bisque is to die for. Really great salmon and the key lime pie aint bad either. I order from WOW so I can not comment on their service in-house, but the food is killer! I highly recommend you give em a try!
author: Bella B.

description:
A good place to get some good seafood and escape most of the tourists in San Francisco.

A tourist myself, I wanted try something not too touristy and this fit the bill.  Very friendly service and near the cable car route.  I would suggest going with their main dishes.  I got one of their simple fish dishes cooked in parchment paper and was a little disappointed.  Really not a lot of flavor.

My friend got the potato crusted salmon and that was excellent.  I was jealous of her dish.  We also tried the raw sampler as an appetizer, which was good.  The smoked salmon was the winner there.
author: David C.

description: Food was good but service was very slow (Saturday night).
author: Frank A.

description: The food is great...I loved the shellfish combo which was offered on special my first time with lobster.  I have also tried the crab which is delicious.  Upon another visit, we tried the cajun prawns and scallops.  The oysters are fresh and good and everyone there is very friendly.
author: Janelle C.

description:
Visiting SF for a weekend. a grlfriend found this place with $1 oysters for Happy Hour M-F from 5-7.  We arrived at a little after 5 the place was quite empty, the beers on tap are all $2.50 and they have specialty drinks like margaritas, cosmos and other mixed drinks which are $6 throughout the day.  I started with the margarita and my friends with a Stella.  

Oysters - the waiter recommended that we start with all three types: local (hog Island), some kind from London something and then the Pebble beach.  The London ones were the biggest, the Pebble beach the medium and the local hog island ones were the smallest.  We ordered 3 round, each round we narrowed our choice, and decided we all liked the pebble beach ones the best.  By the time we got a second dozen oysters, the place was beginning to fill up.  At 7 p.m. the place was PACKED, there were only 3 waiters on staff and no one cared if we wanted more beers...

We sadly departed and looked for another place to drink.  Nonetheless, the overall experience was great, I wish the staff was a little more attentive to us (I think they were more use to having an older crowd rather than a group of rowdy mid-20 year olds)!
author: Linna C.

description: Honestly I am afraid to even tell people how cool this place is. It's already to busy for me to get a seat sometimes. What can I say - The people, the food, the price, the service all ROCK.  The parking sucks.
author: Kevin R.

description:
$1 oysters 7 days a week from 5-7pm ...plus $2.50 pints of some top notch beers! How can you really go wrong.... unless of course the oysters are bad .... and you get sick ... but I digress
. 
This place is a solid 4... the oysters were very good... they even have three different kinds making even a little more exciting. 

All I had was a beer some oysters and the lobster bisque which .. btw ... had more lobster in it than any other lobster bisque I have had. 
Usually it's just a cream based soup with like one little hunk of lobster in the bottom.... not here ..... it's pretty much filled throughout with shredded lobster .. soaking up all that creamy goodness.

Any day you are craving oysters on a recession budget ... let me know .. I may meet you there :)
author: Jeremy R.

description:
Had a craving for fresh oysters and decided to look for a place that had it at a reasonable price. Went to Hyde Street Seafood House after work one day since through the review I found out they had $1 oysters during happy hour. 

Orders a dozen mix oysters (british columbia, local, washington) and the lobster bisque. The british columbia ones were the largest and the juices were a bit creamy. The locals were the smallest and a bit saltier than the rest. The washingtons were medium sized. 
This was my second time having raw oysters so I'm not a pro on how they should taste like but they didn't have any funny taste. 1/2 a dozen or less is my limit but overall it was really good with lemon and cocktail sauce. 
After that we ordered the lobster bisque that everyone was raving about and boy they were right! This is a must try if you stop by, although you can't be quite sure if the meat is lobster since they mince it and throw it in.

Overall I would definintely come back if I'm craving oysters and the oh so yummy lobster bisque!
author: Bunnie L.

description: Great local seafood restaurant only a short walking distance from our apartment. Great oysters and an amazing Lobster Bisque!
author: Nicolas M.

description:
Really great food and nice atmosphere.  Staff is very friendly and professional although they could use a few more servers.  I think it is family-run.

Lobster Bisque is delicious and full of lobster.  Oysters are West Coast and fresh.  Any of the dishes in parchment paper are full of flavor and tender.
author: Andrea L.

description:
We started off with Kumamoto oysters which were very fresh and the lobster bisque was DELICIOUS! Apparently, they are known for the Papillote (parchment paper) entrees so my friend and I both tried that. I had the seabass and he had the shellfish. The seabass could have been a bit more tender as I love it when it just melts in your mouth but it wasn't too bad. The shellfish en papillote was good though. Dessert? Well, let's just say we ended up going elsewhere for that.

Reading other reviews, it sounds like parking can be a pain but we must've been lucky. There was this huge spot just waiting for us. I'm sure that added to the good overall experience we had with this place.
author: Michelle H.

description:
Happy Hour starting at 5pm-7pm everyday!  
Three different kinds of oysters, a dozen for $12.  
While oysters are great by themselves, I never knew how great oysters went with a nice cold $2.50 happy hour pint of Stella. 

The Lobster Bisque was very good.  I believe it was around 7 dollars.  A little more than I would have liked to pay for soup, but at least there were a lot of chunks of lobster.

We also ordered the local snapper en papillote.  The snapper was a little bland and nothing really stood out for me.

The service was great - very nice and attentive.  The restaurant was not as crowded as I expected, which is a good thing.  They had nice jazz music playing..very soothing.  Its not a live band, but definitely adds to the relaxing environment.  Overall, excellent choice for good cheap oysters and a nice beer.  Be sure to try the lobster bisque too.
author: Bert N.

description:
Although I'm semi-allergic to shellfish, I don't know anything about eating in moderation. One week I had lobster four times and broke out in 400 hives--it was still a good week. 

Anyway, I was itchin' and scratchin' for seafood, so my friend and I came here for the incredible Happy Hour: 12 bucks for 12 freshly shucked oysters on the half shell. Three kinds of oysters. Three kinds of sweetness. Three kinds of happiness. I can't believe we only ordered a dozen. Next time I'm living it up with two dozen just for myself. Who cares about cholesterol, let alone hives?

We also had the Lobster Bisque ($6.95). Although a bit salty, it hit the spot on a cold night--hearty and delicious, it was just perfect with the crusty bread. My friend said it was the best soup he ever had in his life, but he's obviously never had my mom's bun rieu (Vietnamese crab meat noodle soup). Ha.

Because we already had oysters and lobster, we decided to get the Stuffed Prawns Bearnaise ($18.95)--just to overdose on shellfish for the night. Although the prawns were big, there were only five of them. That's almost $4/shrimp and utterly unjustifiable, especially since I can get at more than half a pound of shrimp for the same price at the Farmer's Market.

I can't wait to return for more oysters, more bisque, and more seafood, though. When the financial question is "rent or crab?" I will always choose softshell.
author: Liz T.

description: Been here twice during their happy hour. Best things there are the OYSTERS! During happy hour, it's worth it for the oysters. I recommend the BC or Washington oysters. The other thing that I absolutely love is the lobster bisque. I didn't know what it was before but my boyfriend told me that it's like clam chowder. Personally, I think it's way better than clam chowder. Other than that, everything else is so-so. I'll still continue to come back!
author: Cindy L.

description:
Very nice, professional and friendly service... 

The decor (all old boat stuff, ropes, maps and such) has nothing special, but is nice and not pretentious... that goes well with their very decent price.

The dozen oytster for 12 bucks happy hour is a wonderful idea.
Their sample platter was a good way to try everything and the steamed mussels are the best I've had in a while.
The clam chowder was good, but not impressive compared to the rest.
The server (Brian) gave us good wine recomendation and gave us friendly and prompt service, even though the place was quite full.

The only minus is the parking situation, but hey, this is SF...

We will go back for sure... we will try some fish this time!
author: Vithiet L.

description:
The only reason to come here would be for the $1 oysters (by the dozen) during happy hour (5-7).  Unlike most oyster HH places, this deal is available every weekday, which is pretty nice.  You get 3 varieties of oysters, and they were all pretty good and well-shucked.  They also have some $2.50 bottles, including Stella, during HH, and the bread is pretty good.

That's about where the good ends, however.  The rest of their food is very meh, and kind of expensive at that.  We've tried their clam chowder, escargot, steamed clams, and some sort of fish dish.  They were fine, but you could definitely get better seafood elsewhere.

It's also kind of hard to get to, if you don't live in the area.  It's not accessible by rail (so you'd have to bus or cab it).  Parking is also fairly horrendous in the area.  We once got a $250 parking ticket for blocking a wheelchair ramp on an extremely steep hill next to a deserted park in the middle of the night.  

If you do happen to be in the area, though, you can't go wrong with the happy hour oysters and beer.
author: Leslie L.

description: I was in town for a day and wanted to try something away from the tourist areas and found this place.  The local oysters here are about as fresh as it gets... highly recommended.  The rest of the food is ok... nothing out of this world, so you may just want to come here for some oysters.   Service was great.
author: Allen P.

description: 3-3.5 stars; the food is solid, good, fresh - but ordinary.  Menu selection is fair and it's a reasonable place to eat dinner.
author: Rob J.

description:
Dollah oysters and cheap beer! 

Now that I've got your attention, that's all I've ever had here. It's no Hog Oyster, but it's fricking good, and a steal of a deal to boot during the 5-7pm happy hour every day. Yep, even weekends. With this kind of deal, I was surprised to find it empty on a sunday at 5:30. Our party of 8 drooling oyster-and-bargain lovers were seated right away and we had quick efficient service. The fun decor reminds me of a cheesy New England Tourist spot. I'll be back here, and soon, but only between 5-7. Woo hoo!
author: Kelly C.

description:
Had a great time here. We came for the happy hour oysters. it's about $1 per oyster. we had a little sampler of the 3 options. really nice. 

The Caeser was decent. Nothing special but not bad at all. i could actually taste the anchovy in it so i assume it was house made. A little too lightly dressed for me, but i like a little more dressing on my salads than most people do.

Had the lobster bisque. It wasn't really heavy with lobster flavor, but there were lots of meaty chunks. Creamy, sweet with a stronger corn flavor than i expected.

Ordered escargot and that was just ok. Lots of nice garlic and oil, but overall they just didn't hit home. i wouldn't order them again, but if somebody at my table did and offered them up, i would probably have one or two.

Overall nice spot. I will definitely come back!
author: Alland B.

description:
This place reminds me of some great seafood restaurants back home in New England.  The slightly shabby but quaint nautical theme decor provides a great ambiance when you just want a casual meal with friends.  The service is prompt and the prices are very reasonable for fresh, wild-caught seafood.

The fish is perfectly prepared en papillotte, but the real deal is the raw bar happy hour special: From 5 to 7 each weekday you get a dozen oysters for a Dollar each.  Some oysters and a cold beer on a hot afternoon?  Almost perfect.  Add in some steamed mussels and clams, and you've got perfection.
author: Eric H.

description:
Hyde Street Seafood House is in the heart of Russian Hill and they get a lot of tourism from the cable cars, perhaps this is the reason they don't strive for excellence. The service was friendly. Unfortunately, we were not impressed with the food. 

The bread was cold and hard, the Lobster bisque - supper creamy, white and the lobster was chopped very tiny, to the point that we had to ask if we got Clam chowder instead of the Lobster bisque, the special "seafood pasta" which we were told was cooked in wine had such a heavy sauce compound with the lobster bisque was too heavy.
author: Gigi W.

description:
SCRUMPDILLYUMPTIOUS!!!!

Where does one even start when describing this little gem?

Only one place....

WITH THE LOBSTER BISQUE!  The Lobster Bisque is just simply amazing at the Hyde Street Seafood House and Raw Bar.  If there is any one starter on this menu that would keep me from trying any other appetizer, this would be it.  

The Crab Cake is made exactly the way I like them; without fillers and abundant with lumpy crab meat.  They serve it ontop of mixed greens with a remoulade.  YOM YOM!

The oysters from the raw bar are always top grade on freshness.  I have to order at least 1/2 a dozen for myself every trip!  However, I haven't had a chance to try the clams yet.

When deciding which slice of fish to go with, I'd suggest the Sea Bass.  It's absolutely heaven in your mouth.  The buttery fish prepared "En Papillote" just melts with flavor and goes great with the Potato Pancakes on the side.  

If you like a fish with strong texture, the Halibut is an excellent choice too.  From the perfectly cooked Sea Scallops to the Cioppino and Potato Crusted Salmon, it's hard to find anything you wouldn't like on this menu.

Of course, you can't forget about dessert.  I think they change the desserts around, but if you can get your hands on a slice of the Keylime Pie, do not even think about anything else.  Okay, maybe the Creme Brulee too; gotta love that crunchy crust.

Now I have one warning, parking here freaking SUCKSSSS.  I'd suggest parking around Polk and walking a few blocks up.  On a good night, it may take you 15 minutes so allow plenty of time before your reservations.
author: Curt L.

description: Every time I've been here the food has been outstanding, I've tried everything from their en papillote fish, grilled fish and pasta and the food has always been good. You feel very comportable and at home here with their casual yet attentive service. An all-around good establishment.
author: Anna J.

description: This place left me feeling full of bad salmon, and regret that we did not just go to Safeway and cook...and I can't even cook.
author: Leigh F.

description:
What a wonderful find!!  On our last night in SF, my husband and I decided we really needed to get some seafood before returning to our own landlocked home.  I am so glad we came to Hyde Street.  

First off, the decor is awesome!  Dark wood, booths, and tons of vintage maps wallpapering the walls.  Nice and sunny, not too spacious, not too cozy.  Loved it. 

The food.  We started off with dungeness crab cocktail and clam chowder.  The clam chowder had lovely bits of clam swimming throughout, and the crab cocktail was pure crab heaven - it was simply a portion of shelled crabmeat served with cocktail sauce.  Yum! 

Our main meals were thus:  He got the Fijian escolar, and I got the stuffed shrimp.  Please, forget the stuffed shrimp (a bit tough, salty, oily), please get the escolar, or something cooked en papillote, their speciality.  I didn't follow my own advice, but my husband's dish was divine.  The escolar (also known as butter fish, similar to a sea bass) was wonderfully cooked - not tough at all, and just simply the best fish I think I've ever had.  The vegetables served alongside both his and my dish were very nicely steamed, and a great accompaniment to our dishes.  

Topped off with a beer and a glass of wine, our meal was reasonably priced ($100 with tip).  The service was stellar, and I can't wait to visit this place again.
author: Teresa W.

description: The oysters were good (and well priced at happy hour) but the cioppino was awful. Overall, I felt like this place was really overpriced -- the quality was really more on par with some sort of higher-end Chinese take out. With prices like theirs, I'd go elsewhere.
author: Sean A.

description:
OMG! Lobster bisque from heaven! Quite possible the tastiest dish ever. 
Fortunately for me, I was with a regular who is "in" with the staff. We got superb service, great food and phenomenal wine. 

Tucked away in Nob Hill, this place is a seafood gem!
author: Rada I.

description:
There are few things in this world that I FIEND aside from oysters.  I don't know what it is but when I think about fresh, salty oysters and a glass of white wine, my mouth salivates and I kinda get antsy.  And on a mission to make it happen : )

So, thanks to Yelp, I found the BEST happy hour ever!  Not only do they have the much-reviewed oyster & beer special, they also have a quaint tabletop outside the restaurant that is perfect for me and my main man... Gus the pug of course!  We got off work a bit early and snagged that table to house some oysters as the cable car rolled on by.

The menu looked great as well, so we will be back for more.  Might even be a regular now that I made friends with Johnny and the rest of the staff.
author: Tara G.

description: The concierge at our hotel led us to this perfect place for dinner.  It was on the cable car line in a cute little San Francisco neighborhood.  I had the Snapper En Papillote. It was one of the many fish selections on the menu prepared with vegetables, potatoes and sauce baked in parchment paper.
author: Fabian S.

description: A neighborhood gem if you ask me.  It's located on a nice corner on Hyde Street, just down from Nob Hill straddling the Russian Hill border.  An extremely extensive seafood menu (oysters, clams, a number of different fish, including a daily menu, lobster, crab, etc), and very, very reasonably priced all things considered.  Very attentive service, classic decor, and all of the food was top notch.  Really couldn't ask for more and had a great dinner here.  Will be my go-to classic seafood restaurant from here on out.
author: Sean H.

description:
I am such a huge of mussels and clams and I have rarely had a bad experience.  First came the mussels - there was sand in the two I tasted and the second one tasted spoiled.  The waiter was very nice and took them off the bill.  Then came my mail dish the lobster - it was very tuff and  the veggies that came with where less than... it was a small tinny portion.

My partner had a fish dish (lucky her) and it was amazing.  Very moist and not too fishy and the roasted veggies were cooked in garlic butter and were the perfect side.
author: Julie C.

description:
THE BEST PLACE. Small and quaint place is the best. The dinners are for Kings and Queens. Was lucky to meet the owner at a Raiders game and invited my Girlfriend and I to a meal at his restaurant. Turned out to be the best thing I have ever done. I am there number customer. Now living in San Diego, any time in town no matter what I GO. The family that owns it, are the nicest people. 

The food is amazing.  Start with a bowl of the clam chowder, it is very fresh and delicious. With that get the garlic bread, I know you can't have just one basket. All their fish is so fresh, I swear they just got it out of the ocean. My favorite by far is the Sword Fish, it melts in my mouth like butter.  The Salmon cooked in en papillote is so delicious, surrounded by fresh veggies and potatoes. Add a Beer or Glass of wine and you'll be in nirvana.
author: Forrest G.

description:
Solid happy hour deal. -however, not necessarily a place that needs a happy hour. 

I sat at the bar and had a dozen oysters and an anchor steam for 14.50. The oysters were a mix of 3 diff. spec. including Komimotos-and it was great. The bread was bad. 

I was there by myself and the only one at the small bar. I went for the happy hour but kinda felt like an oddball. This is a DATE spot.; white table cloths, tucked away booths, dark wood, double clangs reminding you of the moving scenery... Actually if you are on a date, there is a booth in the window that looks amazing. I would request it if i was going there. It's a little triangular outcrop that looks out into the street. Due to the shape, the two people have to sit on the same side together. 

The local is key. Besides the beautiful walk, there are three wine bars within just a few blocks. 

First date is fun/get to know- second is adventurous/creative- third is romantic/intimate. This is a third date spot.
author: Jake H.

description:
Yummy, Yum!

I went here yesterday with my parents. I wanted to try someplace local and had always been curious about this restaurant.  I took a look at the menu and one of the first entrees I saw:  stuffed prawns. Oh yeah, you heard right. I am pretty much obsessed with prawns, so I knew I had to try them.

Exellent choice if I do say so myself.  I was highly satisfied.  The dish was piping hot and came with a nice little veggie variety (although a little over cooked for me -- I like my veggies al dente) My dad ordered the seafood linguine... mmm so good.  Did I mention, I started with the ceaser salad, which was excellent?

However, one thing I must warn future patrons of:  these dishes are not low in fat.  My prawns (although seemingly healthy) were doused in garlic butter -- which of course you HAVE to sop up with the bread -- and the linguine was cream-based.  

Service was great, servers very attentive and friendly.

So, moral of the story - If you're lookin' for a nice healthy seafood dinner, don't let me order for you. :)
author: Allison N.

description:
Quaint my ass.  This place is a tourist trap!  The food is actually fresh... so rest assured you won't be spending the night in the sh*tter.  However, everything tastes and looks like paste.  Just kidding.  Well, not really.

Can't go wrong with clam chowder or bisque ... raw bar, ok... mignonette needed a bit of help, actually ... and don't bother with the fish en papillotte.  Jacques Pepin's poisson en papillotte kicks their janky-little-asses and then some!  Here they totally talk it up as their house specialty, it appears in effectively a charred paper bag, they cut it open, voila, and NO FLAVOR.  NONE to SPEAK OF.  

DId I check into the FAT FARM?  What part of I'd still like to TASTE my FOOD did they not understand??!!!!!  Are they insinuating that I look bloated and could do with a little less salt in my life?

And dude, what is UP with the GHETTO-ASS seating?!!!

I DARE you to try and sit on a BOARD all night and not have your  ass fall asleep.  I kid you not.  Our "booth-style" seating... was a cramped plank of wood on one side and a random chair on the other.

Oh yeah, and on the way out, I noticed that it is actually one of those restaurants that they feature in "Dining Out" for hotels.  Damned tourist trap.  Come here if you have no taste buds.  Okay fine, it really wasn't that bad.  I was just bitter because my ass hurt.
author: lulu p.

description: The lobster bisque is delicious! Give yourself extra time to find street parking though. We had made a reservations but had to call to say we were running late due to limited parking around the area.
author: Pamela v.

description:
With so many wonderful restaurants in San Francisco, it's hard to narrow it down to two dinners, if you only have a weekend. Do we want italian, steakhouse, seafood, chinese, Mediterranean? Fine dining, casual, kid friendly, tourist trap? So many choices, not enough time.

We chose seafood for both nights. Our first night in the city, I decided on Hyde Street Seafood House and Raw Bar, thanks to a recommendation & Yelp. A few things that made my decision easy, PRICE, LOCATION & RECENT REVIEWS. Practically everything on the menu is under $20. And yes, they have an amazing Happy Hour 5-7(even on weekends).  Our reservation was at 6pm, 12 pick n choose oysters for 12 bucks. We ordered them by the truckload. Our party consisted of 14 and our bill was $400 with beers. Unbelievable. The absolute best Ciopinno, I've had. The broth wasn't watery and spicy like other places I've tried in San Francisco. It was thicker, more flavorful and the seafood was cooked perfectly. The lobster bisque wasn't too creamy like the other reviewer described, it was perfect. Every spoonfull packed with shredded lobster, just the way I like it.  The scallops, steak, butterfish, shrimp and salmon were all cooked per-fect-ly  and tasted delicious. The only 2 complaints on the table were the caeser salad and my friend didn't care for his sturgeon fish.  The waiter forewarned him and recommended other fish, but like a stubborn mule, he ordered it anyway.

The location was a $6 cab from the wharf area. We would've taken the cable car straight up Hyde, but we were late. Hyde Street Seafood House blends right into the residential area with charm. Nautical theme carried throughout the restaurant  and the dining area is very cozy and romantic.

Our server was perfect. Attentive, funny, quick & personable. 

This was not the BEST seafood I've ever had but it was very very good. For under 20 bucks an entree and a 400 buck tab for a big party, this was the BEST seafood restaurant I've ever been to.

I would definitely recommend this place to anyone visiting San Francisco with a large or small party. It seems like a locals only spot, we were the only tourists there. Make reservations in advance. It's very quaint.

4.5 stars
author: Love S.

description: i had a great time here last week during dinner. very nice waitstaff and delicious food. 2 appetizers and 1 entree was more than enough for my boyfriend and i.
author: Cydney S.

description:
A very warm and friendly atmosphere.  We have been trying to get to a lot of the places along Hyde St. lately being as it's just over the hill and we have some friends new to Russian Hill.  We happened into this place on a Friday night and we thought we'd just have some beers and apps.  The service was great and oysters were real nice.  

After finding ourselves cozy we decided to have dinner as well and ordered up a pretty big variety of fish, shellfish, bisque, salads, and more oysters.  The overall consensus from the four of us the next day is that it would be a GREAT place to go back to for the beers and $1 oysters, but probably not for dinner, based on it being just - OK for the prices.
author: Brad C.

description:
Remember the days when mom and dad took you to the pizza parlor and you got so excited to "got out for dinner"? Little did I know that when becoming a grown up, a pizza parlor is the last place to be for an evening out to dinner. I found a spot that has become my "parlor", but a parlor of Fresh Fish! 

My boyfriend and I were walking up Hyde street reading the menu in the windows of a few different restaurants, all of which we thought we would turn around and walk back to until we found Hyde Street Seafood House. As I strolled by, the first thing that caught my eye was the scrumptious platter of fresh oysters. I read the menu and got through the first set of the appetizer description. Simultaneously, my boyfriend and I looked at each other and said this is the one. 

Immediately walking in the restaurant you are greeted by one or all the staff either at the bar or walking by. We were seated straight away and bread was placed in front of us soon after. The ambiance is warm and relaxing. We sat at the window and would watch the Trolley ring by and gives a sense of old San Francisco.

Of course our first order was the oysters, which turned out to be the best I've had yet. We both had a salad and as a main course I had the snapper (I recommend), and my boyfriend had the Mahi Mahi, which we concluded was both a favorite of ours. We ended the meal with a cappuccino. 

The prices are average and you pay for what you receive. For the two of us it was about $70 without ordering wine. Next time I go I expect it to be a bit pricier when wine is selected and their full service bar is consumed.  

The service and food was spectacular. I will continue to visit here and I look forward to introducing to friends and family.  

Cheers!
author: Dee C.

description:
LOVE  THIS PLACE!!
LOVE the OYSTERS!
LOVE LOBSTER BISQUE!!

just go and grab a few dozens of oyster during happy hour and you will be happy and satisfied!!

Service was really good too1!!!
author: Shirley F.

description:
This quintessential San Francisco bistro is a scene out of a Chrasta painting with Tony Bennett singing in the background.

The little dining room, romantic and cozy, does indeed have an understated mariner's theme.  They have booths toward the rear, a little bar in the front room, and white-clothed tables tucked under shopfront windows facing out to Hyde Street.  

The seafood is superb, delicately prepared, and of highest quality. (My date and I shared baked scallops and seared ahi tuna in a blood orange sauce- very nice.)  

The service is buttoned-up and professional, but still personal and very attentive, and you really can't beat the idyllic Russian Hill location on Hyde Street with the cable cars passing by, wonderful if you're craving *that* version of the dreamy San Francisco evening....
author: Rick H.

description:
I love seafood, yet strangely, in the three years I've lived in San Francisco - the city by the Bay - I had yet to find a seafood restaurant (aside from sushi) that I found enjoyable.

My search is now over.

Hyde Street Seafood House and Raw Bar scores on freshness - the oysters are excellent, the entrees are wonderful and creative.  The bill is reasonable - I went there with three people and we had a full dinner w/several bottles of wine for under $200.

I liked it so much the first time, I had my birthday party there this year - they accommodated me and twenty of my friends with ease, even catering to my NYC friend who is vegan, and made us all feel like we were having a warm, fun gathering in an intimate setting.

I love the ambiance, the food, the service.  It is a go-to restaurant which everyone from your Great Aunt Tillie to your hipster friends will enjoy.

Thumbs up!
author: Kate R.

description: If Hyde Street Seafood House had an elevator pitch it'd take only one second and two words: paper fish.  Get the halibut.
author: Kristen S.

description:
Went ehre with the fiance and a couple friends . . . had a great time.  We had two happy hour orders of oysters, beer and wine.  Then ordered dinner.  I got the stuffed shrimp and everyone else got a fish dish prepared "En Papillotten", which is baking the food in parchment paper.  

My stuffed shrimp was good, what it should be from a seafood house with mid/high pricing.  But the parchment paper baked fish meals were terrific.  The location was nice, the decor was decent but casual.  The service was great and the staff was very upbeat and fun.  

We will definitely be back and I'm going to get a parchment baked dinner next time!
author: Sam S.

description:
For a neighborhood Seafood spot, this place is pretty darn good.  I'm super stoked I live nearby because that means I can partake of the awesome happy hour more often.  $1 Oysters plus cheap beer?...I can't complain about that. And the waiters are always especially cool and friendly even though their specials tend to keep the checks low  (and potentially tips) during the afterwork crowd.  I have had other things on their menu, but usually I stick to their shellfish, either oysters or clams or mussels.  Hey, it's their specialty in my opinion.

The have a tiny bar that you can sit at, but unless it's crowded (rarely) I usually get a table.  I'm probably not one of their highest valued customers since I tend to go during happy hour when it is cheap, but I'm definitely a huge fan!
author: Lemar H.

description:
I saw this restaurant while I was on a cab one Sunday night -- it was crowded with a short line at the door of people waiting for a table.  As I continue to look and read signs (Happy Hour 5pm - 7pm) on the window, the cab asked me if I have ever been there.  I told him "no" and he started telling me how great the lobster bisque is.  With $12/dozen oysters, I had to find a way to try it out...

The minute my friends suggested getting oysters, Hyde Street Seafood House and Raw Bar popped in my head.  And last night, that's where we ended up.  My friends arrived even before the restaurant opened so they chilled on the bench outside.  After half-an-hour, I arrived and my friends already had a table outside; both had a glass of cold Stella Artois.  I sat on my chair, feeling a bit unbalanced -- our table is set on a hill, ordered myself a beer, too!  

Linda and Ronnie both got the Lobster Bisque and I had the Clam Chowder Soup.  Both soups were tasty and de-li-ci-cious -- big portion and filling.  After finishing a dozen of the three-various oysters  on a half-shell, we ordered another dozen, then another beer.  Yumm!

Service is awesome, wait staff is friendly and attentive.  The menu is good, lots to choose from like; snapper, swordfish, salmon, sole, trout and porkchops, steak and pasta.  I will come back, but I'll probably only be back for the $1 oysters and beer during happy hour :-)!
author: Celeste M.

description:
What a great spot to have within blocks of your house.  This is what you'd be saying if you lived in Nob Hill.  The happy hour is about as good as it gets.  12 dollars for a dozen oysters and 2 dollar drafts.  

Let me tell you my order from the other day.

5 dozen oysters
2 bowls of lobster bisque
1 bottle of reisling wine
4 beers

the bill was 125 bucks.  Go to the oyster depot or hog island and you'd be paying 125 for the oysters alone.  This place is moooonnneeeyyy!
author: Tony S.

description: My fiancee and I went here fairly late on a Sunday night and the place was nearly deserted.. hence, we received great service while we were there. The food was very good - but not great. I had the stuffed prawns, which had great flavor but the seafood stuffing was a little too mushy for my liking). However, the lobster bisque was GREAT - 5 stars, for sure! We did not have the oysters, sadly, but will be back again for the bisque and oysters during the highly rated happy hour.
author: Joel D.

description:
OK, you know how you meet people when you are out of the Bay area, and you tell them: "If you are ever in the city, call me and we will go out." Well, dammit, a couple just took me up on the offer, and they were the in-laws of my niece. I met them once at her wedding in Las Vegas just a few months ago.

They were in town for an Electrician conference--it was also the weekend of Fleet Week, the Castro Street Fair and the Blue Grass Festival. Great timing. When I asked what they wanted to eat, they said: seafood.

Shit. Now it is not that I do not love seafood, but what is it with folks coming to the city and wanting seafood? I do not do the Wharf, I thought Aqua was too over the top, so, I Yelped "Seafood" and found Hyde Street Seafood House and Raw Bar, and thought: "cool neighborhood, good reviews--done." 

They loved being out of the tourist zone and they absolutely loved the food. Started with yummy oysters; they had the cioppino and the potato crusted Salmon, and I had the cajun scallops and shrimp. We split a couple desserts and man we were full. I will go back--with or without out-of-towners.
author: Deborah S.

description:
This must be one of my favorite restaurants in SF.  It's very down-to-earth and just focuses on the food which may not be to everyone's liking, but this means it offers great value-for-money and a tasty menu.

The staff are friendly - perhaps too much so for some people as they can stand and chat to you all evening.  I really appreciated their friendliness though when he chased us a mile down the street with my wife's handbag after she left it in the restaurant.  

The `en papilotte` option - fish cooked with potatoes in a paper bag is absolutely delicious and left the fish really tender.  I've never come across this method of cooking before but wish I could replicate at home.  

I'll be back!
author: mark b.

description:
12 for 12 oysters and 2.50 beers.  I swear i'm gonna get mercury poisoning or something like that from eating these so much and so often, but it's totally worth it!.... i think

oh, the other stuff on the menu is just okay... but who cares... OYSTERS
author: Ivy S.

description:
Service is very slow - 2 stars - they were short on staffs and not very friendly

Food - 1 star - we were giving cold white bread.  We got there 10 minutes before 7PM but by the time the sever came to our table it is 2 minutes passed 7PM, and he said we can't have the half price oysters because it is over at 7PM?

My husband ordered the fish and it was super  thin thus they over cooked it.   My son ordered the chicken (he does not like seafood) - it was dried and has no flavor.  The rice was uncooked.   Overall, we would never come back here again!!!!
author: We A.

description:
Oysters are my crack so the crackwhore within gets very excited when it gets treated to $1 oysters.  Tonight they had three varieties, all which I had never tried before (but alas, no Kumomotos).  Each type of oyster was excellent, with varying degrees of sweet and mild or salty and metallic.  I made the mistake of ordering their sauteed cajun calamari (blech) and had to order another dozen oysters to refresh the palate.  I doubt I'd come back for their dinner menu, but their raw bar is a good deal.  

One beef: Someone in the kitchen needs to take a refresher course on shucking 101 because all the oysters came out with too much shell attached to the meat and the juices were a bit grainy.  This, sadly, slowed down my ability to just gulp one sucker after another.  

As a comparison point I would say, despite the request for better shuckeres, Hyde Street is on par with Hog Island because here they offer you bread and butter so you don't leave really hungry, and you don't have to eat your oysters standing or rushed by the hairy eyeballs of those waiting to take your table.
author: Helen C.

description:
Hyde St was great. If you're looking for straight up good seafood, this is your place. Papilotte style very unique.

Ordered:

Dozen oysters on the half
King salmon

Ambiance that of a local joint. Sat at the bar and waitstaff was not only friendly, but helpful. Really enjoyed my time there. Took the cable car from the wharf and hopped off at Johnson to avoid one of the biggest humps in SF. Def a re visit!!
author: G B.

description:
On-the-cheap oyster & beer daily happy hour + super friendly staff + charming nautical decor = A KEEPER! 

Did I mention the oyster and beer special?? So great...I'll take 3 dozen please! After you and your honey get an aphrodisiac fix, hop on the cable car, go home and get it on...
author: Danielle S.

description:
Last nights Valentines Day meal was pretty damn disappointing, and the seating was ridiculous.  My lobster tail was dry as a cracker, my girlfriend's scallops were like rubber, the wait staff was constantly squeezing by our table to get to the other cramped patrons, and dinner took nearly 3 hours...  no joke.  I've never before finished a bottle of wine before I received my main course, but last night... boo yeah!  I did it.

The only saving grace was the fantastic company I was with...  oh, and the fillet and oysters were pretty tasty too.

The wait staff for the most part was friendly.  Our waiter in particular was nice.  However, watch out for the one Asian lady, I think she's lost all her marbles... and won't ever find them either.

I'm pretty sure on any other night, it would be a decent restaurant.  However, for the good money that was paid last night, I wish I kept my original plans of going to the Grand Cafe.
author: shaun l.

description: I have live up the street from this place for a year and a half now and never ventured in. I decided to give their bar a chance. I ordered a viogner and took a look at their menu. Ordered a dozen oysters with 3 varietals and a cajun prawns and scallops. The wine was delish and the food was beyond fantastic. The service was great and the bartender helped me pair wine with my dishes. I would go back everyday for the cajun prawns and scallops it was AMAZING! I will absolutely be going back and I hear they have an awesome happy hour.
author: Adrienne P.

description:
- Good service
-OK prices
-Fish is good
-Oysters are OK
-Nice ambiance
author: Nick S.

description: Great place to eat. Highlights, highly recommend the oysters, they have 4 different varieties, the small ones, starts with a K were really good. The Lobster Bisque was also quite good. Potato salmon was decent. Staff were friendly. Good for a casual date place if you're looking for good seafood. Parking can be tight at times. Would recommend and come back here again. Thanks!
author: Jason L.

description: I've been here three times now... twice within a week and once last night.  This place is pretty good and the service is very friendly.  When we come here, we always order a plethora of items and share. It's all about seafood!
author: Noneya B.

description:
What a fantastic little place this is.  The multitude of oyster shooters, the ambiance with the Cable Car outside the window, the Christmas lights in July....need I say more? 

Definitely a great spot for a romantic evening for two or more!

Thanks for the wonderful meal.
author: A H.

description: Came here for their oyster happy hour.  A dozen raw oysters for $12.  Really nice little place for a quick bite to eat and the oysters were fresh and creamy.
author: Mike L.

description:
We arrived at 9:20 PM on Labor Day and were greeted with casual, friendly service. We were seated immediately, made our selection, and dug into the bread (very hungry, it was 9:30!). 

The food came pretty quickly. I got the salmon en papillote (house specialty, parchment paper-wrapped goodness, big portion, delicious) while he got stuffed snapper (also good!). Even though it was a holiday, and the restaurant was scheduled to close at 10:00 PM, we weren't rushed to eat, weren't pushed on wine or dessert, and had a good, relaxing meal to round out the holiday. 

Overall, I'd say it was good portion for the price, and a nice atmosphere for a lower-key date night or dinner with friends.
author: Madeline N.

description:
I love visiting San Francisco as there are so many great seafood restaurants.  This one was exceptional.  I originally wanted to check out the happy hour where they feature $1 oysters, but ended up having to try the entrees.  I had the seafood fettuccine.  If you are a seafood chunk person, you would love it...rock shrimp, smoked salmon and baby scallops all in a yummy chardonnay cream sauce.  It was heaven in every bite literally as you had seafood in every bite.  
Try this dish...you will not be disappointed!
author: Rachel S.

description: Came here on a double date while my friends were visiting from Germany--It was their 5th anniversary. Great service, okay food: Escargot was terrible: gritty, with a grassy flavor. Dungeness crab mornay en croute was tasty, but the crab flavor was overpowered by the cream sauce. Stuffed rainbow trout was yummy, as was the special seafood pasta; but for the price, neither warranted returning.
author: Alex W.

description: I come from Essex, land of fresh lobster, mussels and clams. The sea food here was stale and loaded with cheese- how can you make seafood stodgy? I ordered the stuffed rainbow trout, I was presented with a trout stuffed with a thick, odd vaguely fishy filling, three green beans, and three tiny carrots of the type you find for snacking on in supermarkets- as well as three small potatoes on an inexplicable pile of sour cream. My friend ordered a $20 plate if seafood pays which was essentially a very cheesy carbonara with some bits of salmon in. I am so disappointed I want to cry.
author: Emma H.

description:
Wow.  This place is worth the 10-minute lap trying to find parking.  

The lobster bisque is always a hit.  They have a good variety of oysters at reasonable prices - even outside of happy hour.  

Clean bathroom - with a nice framed picture of sailing knots.  You can tell a lot by a restaurant's washroom.  

The waiters and bartender are always friendly and helpful.  I always leave feeling satisfied and full after leaving here.  

Oh yeah if you're in the mood for coffee after your meal, theirs is great.
author: Young C.

description:
The paper wrapped fish was SENSATIONAL.  On a bed of julienne vegetables, the sauce was light, buttery and a perfect compliment to the delicate fish (of course, the name of which escapes me.  I know it started with an "E").  My sister ordered the crab, which was tasty.  I ordered the cioppino, which was only "ok."  I don't know what the big fuss is about this dish.  I've tried it somewhere else and will probably not order it again.  It never quite rocks my world the way I expect it to.  With Giada and Tyler raving about it on TV, I always expect it to be the "cat's meow."  Far from it, more like a kitten's purrrrrrrrrrrr.  Maybe I just haven't had it done right?  

I completely forgot about the lobster bisque.  I should've ordered that instead.  My brother in law and I shared the dozen oysters. And boy were they YUMMY.  I didn't realize that the happy hour menu consisted solely of draft beer and dozen oysters.  I thought there was more.  :(   All in all, I was very satisfied with my meal here the night before Thanksgiving.  I will def come back and order the paper wrapped chicken myself and try the lobster bisque.  For a no-nonsense meal with great service at a reasonable price, I highly recommend this place.  Thanks, War!
author: Christie X.

description: The service is good and it is a nice looking venue. Unfortunately however the food is overpriced (eg $19 for a scallop entree with only 4 scallops) and the seafood is overcooked. Out of a table of four, the only meal we enjoyed was the clam chowder starter. The restaurant was fairly full though and everyone looked like they were enjoying themselves - so maybe it was just us.
author: Lucy C.

description:
Fantastic happy hour oysters!  Service is friendly and efficient.  Their fish dishes cooked in parchment paper is flavorful and moist.

Ambiance is a bit dated for me but I keep coming here for the food and friendly service.
author: Lev E.

description:
4 stars for:
-Great service
-Great Happy Hour (doz oysters for $12 from 5-7pm)
-Great food (Lobster bisque and Garlic Prawns were delicious)

Minus 1 star for:
-I ate a bad oyster and had my real first taste of bad food poisoning.
author: Jocelyn W.

description: The lobster bisque was BOMB! My boyfriend had the clam chowder which was pretty delicious too...but did I mention lobster Bisque!!  The service was OKAY...we had reservations and had to wait a few to be sat (after the reservation time)  and the servers seemed extra in a rush and not very personable. Heads up, parking was a DISASTER! We had to circle around the neighboring blocks for about 20 mins before finding a spot...it was crazy!!!
author: Mika B.

description:
Whenever I find myself in SF, I make an effort to get here.  The staff and food are wonderful, and the selection of oysters is consistently good.
The lobster bisque is absolute manna - rich, creamy, velvety and exquisitely seasoned.  The clam chowder is also right up there.
I hope to move back here some day, then I'll have a real sit down with the menu, and be back nightly until I have tried it all.
I can't wait to be out there again!
author: Kyoko W.

description:
We found this place on yelp and thought it was great. Service was ok because it seemed like they were way under staffed so we waited for a while before being served. Once we did get to ordering, the food was good. We started with the "raw sampler" which came with capers, onions, creamed cheese, two pieces of smoked salmon, two prawns, two raw oysters (delicious!), and two raw clams (ok) for $13. My wife got a cosmopolitan not made with vodka but with sake and it was amazing. For entrees we got a steamed lobster (delicious) and a new york strip steak. Total bill for that was $86. 

The only real negative was the seating, its pretty... Cozy... You hear all the conversations around you because you are sitting so close to other parties. We were sandwiched between two loud parties. If you are looking for a quiet dinner with quiet conversation, than make a reservation so you get a booth or try another place.
author: Steve D.

description: I used to love this restaurant especially the fish cooked En Papillotte. Went in for a casual dinner last night and tried the lobster bisque (decent but too creamy for my taste) and the Blue Nosed Sea Bass (cooked en Papillotte). However, the flavors that I remember from my prior visits was sorely lacking. everything came across as bland even though the jalapenos and tomatoes were supposed steamed with the fish. Didnt spend a lot of money so wasn't terribly disappointed but I am sad that I have lost another neighborhood gem. Service was very attentive, corkage is reasonable at $15, just hope the cooking improves.
author: Rumesha A.

description:
I'm giving Hyde Street Seafood five stars because for what they do, we had a terrific evening and delicious dinner. This is a cozy, neighborhood restaurant. The service was outstanding. I couldn't decide on a wine and our waiter was really patient and brought us 3 to try until we found one we liked. The wine selection is not great...but it's also moderately priced. 

My husband loved his oysters and the price at $14/dz was great. Our green salads were crispy cold with a tangy dressing (maybe just a bit too much dressing).  Two of us had the cioppino and I'm shocked to read a previous reviewer who said it was too watery. really? Wow...our broth was *very* rich....it tasted like a recipe I have at home that has a lot of butter in it....it was a beautiful dark roux - very flavorful. We loved it. Two others in our party had the potato flaked salmon and another had the steamed mix seafood mix. Everyone cleaned their plate! 

This is not SF's finest restaurant....but they are a friendly neighborhood restaurant that is welcoming; has great service; tasty food at a reasonable price. 5 stars. cheers!
author: Annie N.

description: Delicious lobster bisque. Great service. Prawns!
author: Michael C.

description: Most oyster happy hours only have one type of oyster, but those place has three depending on what is fresh and available. Those was also the only place with $1 oyster happy hour available after work on Friday and without crazy lines. We got a table no problem and it is totally worth the hike out to nob hill.
author: christine l.

description: This should be your neighborhood seafood place.  Afforable prices, lots of different fish , and great papillote preparation.
author: Geoff C.

description: Folks who work here are friendly, but the restaurant was severely understaffed. Waited 15 minutes after seating before anyone approached the table. Cioppino was mediocre.
author: Noah S.

description:
The service at Hyde Street Seafood House and Raw Bar is awesome. The prices on the wine, awesome. The food? Its OK. I had the Lobster bisque as a starter because all of the rave reviews but I have to say that it was just OK.  My wife had the lobster but it was way over cooked. The Kumamoto Oysters were the highlight of the night. Creamy and man oh man do they do the job :)

Tons of tourist so that kind of sucked (too many Kansas Sweaters, yes Sweaters to a restaurant) so not the most romantic place to go out but stil worth your money.
author: Edson C.

description: The food is pretty good.  The nautical decor was fun but because we were there early (before sundown) with not-so-many patrons, I think we missed some of the ambiance.   The service was attentive and friendly though it seemed to take a while for food to arrive.  There were no "OMG" moments with the food but there wasn't anything to really complain about.
author: Dave B.

description:
I didn't expect this place to be a fancy, white table cloth atmosphere.  But it was.  We came in at 6pm and there was no line, and we were seated immediately.
I would definitely only come here for oysters and beer again.  It's 12 for a dozen oysters and $2.50 beer.  The oyster service was fast.  However it took forever to get our other order or clam chowder and steamed clams.  We tried the new england clam chowder and I thought it was too sweet. There was just too much sand in the steamed clams or me.  My friend hsaid the wine/broth that cooked it was very salty.

Perhaps there were other things on the menu...
author: Bess N.

description:
Great deals on oysters during happy hour (a dozen for just $12) and a staff that is very knowledgeable about their wine list.  They were very accommodating to my weird food allergy as well.

I enjoyed the fish I had as did the rest of the party I was with, but I think there are better seafood restaurants in the general area for the same price or even a little cheaper (I'm specifically thinking of Yabbies). Good place to take visiting relatives though -- all my family thought the food was good and the decor was charming.
author: Rebecca H.

description: The Ling Family does a fine job of Western styled seafood and rich desserts all made in house with a fine wine list and warm friendly service.  Sofie is behind the bar and Johnny and Brian are your waiters.  I came with Old Time SF Italian neighbors from Potrero Hill and they know chioppino.  Also, had the house special parchment baked butterfish and it came out tender and delicious. We shared the chocolate cheese cake and key lime pie, both excellent and rich.  The lime pie was light and fluffy, different than the usual.  Oysters were fine for me! Good room for a conversation and watching the cable cars pass by.  Don't drive, take a cab or the Hyde Street Cable car. Closest parking is garages near Polk or on the other side of Van Ness.  Tim and Cathy
author: Tim L.

description:
I've run past this place so many times that I finally decided to check it out. Lured by the happy hour of $1 oysters, my mother  and I decided to give it a try. 

The oysters were delicious, and we ate a lot of them! The lobster bisque was okay...a little too rich for the size of the bowl. The service was okay, although our waiter swung back and forth from being too attentive to MIA for a long period of time. 

This is worth it for the oysters...and thats about it.
author: Jenn G.

description:
I was looking forward to some REALLY good seafood.  Instead what I got was really slow service (-1), overpriced (-1) and they got my order wrong (-1).  

We waited a LONG time for the waiter to come take our order -- but maybe he was doing that so we wouldn't feel rushed.  Fair enough.  Then we place our order and wait a LONG time for the appetizers to arrive.  I got bored poking at the cold bread. 

The seafood is fresh.  I ordered the dungeoness crab cocktail for 12.95.  Hubbie ordered the cajun prawns/scallops for 12.95.  My crab was fresh, his cajun dish was very good.  Unfortunately the portions were so small that we felt completely ripped off.  After we finished our appetizer, it took a real long time before we got our entrees ---  ridiculous amount of time like maybe they had only one really slow cook back there.

For entree, I got the seafood fettuccini specifically requesting a marinara sauce (instead of the cream sauce) and no cheese or dairy on my dish.  No problem says our waiter.  Hubbie ordered the pepper crusted ahi tuni.  After waiting a long time (see above) we got our entree and there was cheese all over my fettuccini.  I should have been mad but I calmly told the waiter to take it away -- I had asked for no cheese or dairy.   He said he'd fix it ... 

Hubbie starts eating his Ahi dish which came with some green beans and  cheesy scalloped potatoes.  He could not eat the potatoes because it was just too weird a pairing: Medium-rare Ahi and cheesy potatoes.

10 minutes or so later my dish comes arrives looking like there was no cheese in it -- I start digging in and find stretchy bits of cheese intermixed in my pasta.   I call the waiter who took several minutes to come back and told him .. uh, no cheese -- I can't eat this.  The cook had cleaned off the cheese as best he could and sent the dish back out to me.  (Is that against health code or something?)   By that time my husband had finished his entree and we asked for the check.  I wasn't about to wait 30 minutes for them to make me another entree.  

Our bill for 1 entree, 2 appetizers and a mediocre glass of red wine (syrah):  $68.  Rip off.

With the slow service, overpriced dishes and inability to get orders right -- in addition to close to impossible to find parking in this part of town (-1 for location) -- we would never go back.

We walked across the street to a Chinese Take-Out joint called U-LEE....
author: Spicy T.

description:
I grew up in Seattle and vacationed almost every summer on the water with my family. We eat clams and oysters on the beach most nights. I love seafood.

This restaurant was terrible. I would never come back.
author: Angela K.

description:
I would go back for sure. I went here on a Friday night around 8. It was surprisingly not that busy. My boyfriend and I ordered the raw bar sampler which came with smoked salmon, 2 clams, 2 shrimp, 2 oysters, capers, shallots and bread. It was quite tasty. We ordered a whole crab but then were informed that they had just run out. That doesn't bother me so much as Dungeness Crab is not in season and since that makes them more expensive, restaurants probably only buy as much as they know they can sell. ANYWAY, we split a bowl of clam chowder and the cioppino. The chowder was great and they cioppino was awesome. It was really a great value considering the amount of mussels, clams, fish and shrimp packed into the bowl. We couldn't even finish it. 

Our meal + a $30 bottle of Viogner came out to about $77 before tax. It was definitely worth it :-) I think I'll go back when crab is in season again and try the garlic crab. Yummm. My only complaint is that I wish the atmosphere was a little upbeat. The music was really low and un-fun.
author: Natalie G.

description: I Live in SF and thought I would give this place a shot...prices are very, very, fair for SF...Food was ok to good...service was very good...Nice diverse menu and portions were small to moderate...I would go back...
author: Mark P.

description: A lot of the reviews i read were positive about this place but my husband and I were not impressed at all. The employees were super nice and the restaurant was neat and clean. There was a smell that lingered the entire time we were there and I thought it was a fish smell, but whatever it was it was not pleasant.
