I got lobster bisque soup and it was good, but i like my lobster chunky, not minced. My husband enjoyed the clam chowder but he doesn't complain about food unless its terrible. For dinner I had the Cajun shrimp and scallops. Don't waste your money because all they did was put a butt load of Cajun powder seasoning on it and broiled it. Too hot to enjoy and not worth what we paid. The vegetables were too hard to enjoy as well. My husband got the trout (which I read by many was a favorite dish) and it didn't have any seasoning. Go figure! $100 down the drain in my opinion, but a nice time with my husband. Oh, there was a older apparently wealthy couple next to us that argued the whole time that were there. People...take your issues to the car or at least leave so paying customers can enjoy their time.
author: Dixie T.

description:
We love this place!!  I just moved to SF and have already been here 5 times.  If your looking for a good seafood joint that has a lovely neighborhood feel, this is the place. Nothing fancy on the menu but they do it all soooo well.  Try the parchment baked veggies and fish, yummmm.  Also, the lobster bisque is one of the best I've ever had (and I've lived in Boston for 3 years). 

The fish is always cooked perfectly and the service is always friendly.  It is always busy but you don't have to have a booking. 

Raw bar is excellent and they have a brilliant happy hour special with beer.
author: Andy U.

description: Started with some wine and a plate of fresh, tasty oysters.  Then, the boyfriend and I both ordered the baked stuff rainbow trout and were in absolute heaven.  The service is great and the decor made me feel like I was having a romantic dinner on a boat.  This place is amazing!
author: Lainey D.

description:
My brother, sisters and I all went to Hyde Street Seafood for an early dinner.  We were all practically starving and didn't have much to eat the whole day.  Dinner was awesome, and after talking with the server and realizing what I initially planned to order wasn't great, I changed it to the special salmon entree they had. 

On top of this we ordered two clam chowders, some variety of oysters, and bread.  Seriously, this was some of the best seafood I've had in a while in a restaurant.  I would recommeded this place, the only thing about it is it's kinda pricey.  Taken, it is a slightly upscale sit down restaurant.  If you live in the city, you have to try this place at least once!
author: Kenny P.

description:
We've been here twice, once the day after Christmas with the family, and for my wife's birthday when we were staying in SF for the weekend.  We really enjoyed the atmosphere, service, and food, from watching the decorated cable cars going by every few minutes at Christmas, to the unique cooking style, all prepared gluten-free without sacrificing quality.  We were early enough for happy hour, enjoying a dozen oysters for half the normal price.

Closest we've found to the atmosphere of a small french bistro, with attentive staff, great food, a decent wine list, and the unique atmosphere away from the tourist spots, all at a very reasonable price.  

Only complaints are that parking is next to impossible (we tried, gave up and went back to our hotel, then jumped in a cab for a wild ride back in time for our reservation), and the same abandoned Mustang convertible that was sitting out there in December (thought everything in SF got ticketed 2 seconds after the meter expired; guess it's different on Hyde.)  

Really enjoyed this place and intend to make this a regular stop after our move into the city.  Highly recommend.
author: Bob B.

description:
Ok at best. The place/neighborhood is extremely cute, the service was very friendly...it's just that the food was just ok. The lobster bisque was pretty good - it was great that it had chunks of lobster - but you couldn't really taste the lobster over the cream. Tried the lobster ravioli as well...tasty, plump raviolis, huge serving...didn't think the onion pieces were necessary in the sauce. Fiance had the stuffed prawns which were pretty good but drowning in butter.

From the reviews, it sounds like this place would be much better for HH versus dinner. I haven't been to HH but after eating dinner here I'd probably agree.
author: Adrienne C.

description: Delicious seafood!  Must order the oysters! I'm definitely going back for more.  Only downside is the parking situation in this neighborhood, it might take you a bit.  Casual but romantic ambiance.
author: Lina S.

description:
* One star for the amount of time we sat and waited to be noticed. 
* One star for being out of Oysters...= ( 

* * Two Stars for the Service, this place is seriously understaffed. Not exactly rude but very occupied and not really efficient. 

* * * Three+ Stars for the Food. 

I had the blue noise sea bass with tomato and jalapeno seasoning. Boyfriend had Seafood combo of Jumbo Prawn, Scallops and Fresh Catch. Yumm-0. 

Bread was a little on the cardboard side. 


We brought our own wine - $15 dollar corkage. = (

Could go back, we want to try the Happy hour Oysters and hopefully they are more attentive next time. Our neighbors waited like 20 minutes for there check. They need to be more ATTENTIVE and hire more help!
author: Kristina A.

description: Love this place. Always go when I visit San Francisco. Great service, good food, reasonable prices (a bit on the high side... but worth it). Daily special sounded boring (salmon) but was great. Only reason I'm not giving 5 stars is that it is a bit painful to wait for a table here and the prices/value is a bit on the low side. Service is definitely a 5 star. Get reservations!
author: Olin H.

description: Service was excellent, the shiitake mushroom appetizer was great but the main entrees left a little to be desired.  The rainbow trout was plain and a little dry and the garlic prawns were overly simple
author: Sean W.

description:
I am soooooooooooo glad that I had dinner here.  I ordered the $33.00 Whole Crab, two glasses of house wine, Cesar Salad, Oysters and Creme Bruller, and you know.. it was wonderful.   I also got the opportunity to food share the paper wrapped salmon which was so intriguing, and not enjoyed it at another restaurant that I had been too.  These guys know ...exactly know, how to cook.  I am sitting here digesting this food, simply happy that I went there.  The crab was delicious and an adventure to eat rather than like some restaurants they try to make it easy for you.  Even the weapons to get at the crab were very well suited to get to the thing, always a challenge for the uninitiated.  
The room full of sailor items were mysterious and charismatic at the same time. It reflected the fact that their menu is really about 90% seafood and only 10% other meats.
author: Tito Y.

description:
This place deserves 5 stars all the way!!
The service was awesome..we were helped right away, our water glasses were never empty, and the food was delicious.. We started with a scallop appetizer wrapped in bacon..and I had a shrimp scampi type thing with lobster, potatoes, and veggies. The bf had the cioppino.. for desert a tasty banana baked little thing we got with ice cream. Perfect way to spend our anniversary. Oh ya the waiter even paired our food with the perfect wines..I have nothing bad to say about this place, reallllly good bang for your buck (or your bfs buck) ..highly recommend it!
author: Mariangeles C.

description: I will from here on consider this city to be the capital of  lobster bisque.  If you ask me, I would only consider this place for oyster, lobster bisque and a cold Stella artois which is serve in a stella mug ( WAY COOL).  Other than that I was not a fan of anything else here but those three items.
author: George V.

description:
I feel bad for giving this place 3 stars because the service really was spot on, and the food had lots of potential, but was just bland and poorly prepared.

What can I say?  The happy hour oysters were a tasty deal, but were gritty and sprinkled with big shell shards.  My dining partners stuffed trout was so-so.  The flavor of my papillote was pretty nonexistent and the accompanying potatoes were under cooked.  I was left with that "I could have made this at home and way cheaper" feeling, but luckily our waiter and the service salvaged it all.  He kept the $6 blended drinks coming and extra strong. 

I'm completely willing to concede that maybe Hyde Street Seafood House and Raw Bar was having an off night or I ordered the wrong entree.  Boo on me for not having the lobster bisque.
author: Margaret L.

description:
They really know how to do an en papillotte preparation here. The fish steamed perfectly inside the parchment paper infusing the herbs, wine, and butter into the fish while keeping the meat tender. 

The oysters were fresh and plump and served with a well balanced mignonette. 

Prices are really reasonable considering similar menus along Union Square could easily be 2x the prices here. 

The service is a little rough around the edges, but that just makes it feel more like the neighborhood restaurant it is.
author: Seth L.

description:
Hyde Street Seafood has everything going for it: great service, great wine, great venue, and great food.  In fact, food so good that as my friend put it, she "even ate her vegetables."  I ordered the mahi steamed in parchment and most of the table ordered some sort of other fish steamed in parchment as well.  We were all just amazed with how perfect our fish was.  It was an overwhelmingly delicious experience.  

They also took reservations for 9 of us at the last minute which was fantastic.
author: Lauren L.

description:
A bit buzzed @ the Johnnie Walker Tasting event @ Dogpatch Studios, Mr & I made our 8:30 dinner reservation @ Hyde, our 1st time.

Parking it's a bit tough. Our server named Johnny was great. He gave us a window seat, opportunity to people watch & see cable cars pass bby us. I find it a bit intimate & romantic. We had Raw Bar Sampler, Lobster Bisque, Broiled Petite Maine Lobster Tails, Atlantic Smoked Salmon & En Papilotte "Fresh Catch of the Day" Halibut. Mr had beer while I tried a soju margarita. Love the oysters except for the Canada one, it's too watery.

Prices is reasonable + I used one of my $25 certificates from restaurants.com.
author: jubi l.

description:
This is the spot! Quaint little place thats pretty excellently priced for the quality of foods.
5$ clam chowder is the best.
10$ Oysters at Happy Hour rulez. There are soo many different ones to choose too!
Everything on the menu is pretty good, where can you get such quality foods for 14-18$ an entree?

Only negative is parking sux like no other. Good part of it is that you can walk off *some* of the yummies eaten here!
author: ToAsTy T.

description:
This is one of those times I wish Yelp allowed us to give more nuanced ratings. I went to Hyde Street last night with a few friends and left with mixed emotions...

The food was tasty. I started with the soft shell crabs, which were a bit small, but delicious and served with a perfectly dressed mixed green salad. For my entree, I tried the special lobster ravioli, served with crab meat, shrimp and scallops and once again, I was pleasantly surprised. Dessert let me down though. I had the bread pudding, which was prepared in a way I've never seen it before- essentially chunks of break doused in a super-sweet, marginally banana flavored  sauce. It was so sweet that it was almost painful...and I likes me some sweets. Some pretty decent wines and tasty english breakfast tea rounded out my experience, landing them a 4-star rating from me for food.

On decor, I think others have nailed this. Cute place, good for a date night, but not so overly romantic that you couldn't go with friends and family.

Service, however, was a whole different beast. When I drop $70 a head for dinner, I expect 4-star service and here, our friends at Hyde Street greatly disappointed. We had a 7:30 reservation and weren't seated until almost 8:30, only to wait another 15 minutes before being acknowledged by a waiter. When all was said and done, we left the restaurant at about 10:45. I'm sorry, but I just can't see spending 3+ hours at a restaurant that you had a reservation at unless you're being served 5+ courses or have a party of 10 or more. The amount of idle wait time we experienced was truly unacceptable and will likely keep me from going back, despite the tasty food. There are so many good restaurants in San Fran and I'd prefer to go somewhere that offers the full package, especially at this price.
author: Daniel M.

description:
I found this place to sort of a mixed bag.

At first our waiter was a bit surly.  We sat down at 6:50 intending to take advantage of the oyster happy hour (I suppose it's not so happy for the oysters).  By the time the waiter came it was 7:15 and he told us that "happy hour" was over.  With a bit of instance we were able to convince him to honor our request.

I was somewhat concerned, but shouldn't have been.  The oysters were fresh, very tasty and an interesting variety.

I had prawns in garlic which was really butter and garlic, but what's not to like?  The vegetables on the side were a bit over cooked, but passable.

My girlfriend had a house salad of mix greens and a house dressing that she enjoyed.  She then had the lobster tail on the appetizer menu.  It had been broiled and for a bit too long.  It tasted overcooked and wasn't particularly attractive.

The wine list was varied and contained some real bargains.  We eat out often and this was a reasonably priced restaurant.


I would recommend d this place for appetizers and a casual evening out.
author: Stitch H.

description: Always a pleasure to dine here. Brian, a server, is always attentive and friendly. He remembers our names, where we sat last, and even what we ordered!
author: Peter S.

description:
I have been passing by this restaurant for months, waiting for the right occasion to warrant a fancy seafood dinner.  Finally my boyfriend and I decided to come here for our Christmas dinner.  It was fantastic!! The food was melt-in-your-mouth delicious, the service accommodating and friendly, and the prices reasonable considering the quality of the meal.  
Since we rarely dine in fancy restaurants, we went all out ordering the raw bar sampler appetizer, Caesar salad for two and ample entrees. I had an array of seafood cooked in parchment paper with spices and white wine.  The mussels, clams, prawns and shrimp were so succulent.  My boyfriend had a peppered NY steak that was too peppery for me but he loved it. We also had two glasses of the house wine each, which was very good considering it was the cheapest wine by the glass on the menu.  We left full and happy.
author: Kristen C.

description:
I took my wife here for a special dinner, and it was great. 

First of all, the place looks like it was ripped from the pages of some idyllic San Francisco magazine. It's like a postcard. It looks like a cozy neighborhood restaurant, and with the cable cars going by, it's very San Francisco (or at least, what tourists think of when they think of San Francisco).  The interior was as nice. Yes, those are old maps on the walls, and I saw (but did not sit in) the plank wood booth seats. It's not a brand new building, and it looks like they did the best with what they had.

I strategically arrived in time for the end of happy hour, and got a dozen oysters and a beer. YUM. The oysters were fresh and briny. I did have a few pieces of shell in the meat and liquid though. My wife doesn't eat oysters (I know!!) so she had the lobster bisque which was equally divine. Oh, and they brought us bread & butter, which they were not stingy about refilling.

For our main course, I had a whole steamed crab, and she had seared scallops in a ginger cream sauce. Both were yummy, and the steamed vegetables that came with our meals were fantastic. There was a great cream cheese & chive sauce with our potatoes. 

For dessert, she had the key lime pie and I had the creme brulee. Again, both were really great.

We got out of there for just over $100 with tip for two. Ironically, it wasn't my beer that drove up the price -- my wife (who doesn't drink) had three cokes and they charged her individually for those. That's such a downer for a restaurant that is clearly making bank from us.

As we paid our check, the server asked if we would like him to call us a cab. I have never been asked this before and it was quite a nice surprise. A DeSoto cab (my favorite) arrived within 5 minutes. 

The place was about half filled with tourists, but I would not call it a tourist trap. We're locals and felt just as much at home there as we do at some of our other favorite restuarants.

Everything was good, but it wasn't over-the-top fantastic for 5 stars. A good, solid, 4 stars and we'll be back. (I'll absolutely be back for happy hour!)
author: Kellie P.

description: I think this place is quirky. It's a very multi-cultural staff serving 1970's French/seafood in a wood paneled place covered with nautical maps, drawings. Not to say you shouldn't go - at all. Very comfortable, excellent service, reasonable prices. Fish en papillote is their "specialty". We've been with groups of people and as with just two and had a good time.
author: jen n.

description:
What a disappointment!

The food was bland and ingredients obviously of low quality. This might be a good place to take grandma when she doesn't want anything too flavorful or interesting but just wants some whitefish and broccoli.  


The place might be ok for happy hour oysters (not when we went) but everything else was over cooked, bland as hell and very disappointing for the price.

What we ordered:

Shrimp cocktail - the shrimp were incredibly rubbery (a sign of overcooking?)  meh   

raw bar sampler - fine. The shrimp on this one were also rubbery but oysters and clams seemed alright.

Crab - This was a special of the night. Garlic roasted crab.  What came out? A steamed crab with a little garlic in the butter.  Not a great crab either. 

NY Steak - kind of a weird piece of beef that wasn't as much steak as a flavorless piece of meat with a ton of gravy

Scallops wrapped in bacon - hard to mess this one up. This and the oyster  is why I didn't give it one star 

Sides - the vegetables were either over or under cooked and lacked flavor

Overall - avoid this place unless you are explicitly here for oysters and a Guiness on happy hour.
author: Dmitriy K.

description:
ONE DOLLAR OYSTER HAPPY HOUR!

The End

PS: Marin's oysters are like the size of my pinky fingernail....go with Washington or B.C.
author: Stacy L.

description:
$1 Oysters from 5-7pm!!

We made a reservation for 5 people at 6pm (my Grandma was coming) and when we got there, there were about two other people in the restaurant. We ordered a dozen oysters to start (for $12) and glanced over the wine list, which was very decently priced. 

My Dad was running late and my sister claimed she didn't like oysters, until she had the first one and realized how good they were. My Dad showed up in time for the last of the dozen and we knew we had to order another round. 

My Grandma, sister and I all ordered the Rainbow Trout stuffed with shrimp and crab and some other yummy-ness. It was great. My Mom had the Escolar special, which was a hit, and my Dad ordered the seafood salad. We left full and happy.

I think I will be bringing my boyfriend back for happy hour oysters at the bar!
author: Jackie G.

description:
I come to San Francisco every year on my birthday, and this place is just one of the reasons.  Johnny is AMAZING, he remembers me every time.  
I always get their lobster bisque.  It is deliciously chunky, filled with shreds of lobster meat.  Ugh, just talking about it makes me wish I was there.  They have two pasta dishes, one has scallops, shrimp, onions and salmon.  Wash this all down with a Kamikaze Martini and finish it off with a sinful chocolate desert.  When you leave you can trek the hilly streets and work off your meal.  Love this place!
author: Christina G.

description: Very intimate setting. My fiancee and I had come here because of the of the comments submitted by Yelp members. We started with the lobster bisque and an order of mussels. The bisque was good but mine was a little cold. The waiter took it right away gave us a fresh bowl that was fine. The mussels were excellent. The wine sauce at the bottom of the bowl was amazing. Glad they provided us with good bread to really get all the sauce. For dinner I ordered the broiled snapper which was topped with tomato, olives, and basil. Very Mediterranean style dish and the fish was cooked properly. The veggies and roasted potatoes were good also. My fiancee ordered the King Salmon en papillote with veggies and rice. Fish was fresh but how can you screw up salmon in parchment....overall I would check out this spot again when in San Fran....I was mad because I'd just missed happy hour but maybe I will catch it next time.
author: Henry B.

description:
Another neighborhood fave!

I came here earlier this week to take advantage of Hyde Street Seafood's $1 Oyster & $2.50 Beer Happy Hour (5-7 pm) and I couldn't have been more pleased!

Highlights

-Perfect window seating: We were seated in a cozy, romantic nook with the perfect view to watch the cable cars chug on by. Bonus points!
-Stella on the Happy Hour menu?? Yessssss.
-Their Lobster Bisque! It wasn't over-the-top creamy, but was well balanced w/ evident pieces of yummy lobster.
-Top Notch Service: Our waiter couldn't have been more attentive!

The oysters were pretty darn good. We selected a mix of the 3 on the menu, but in comparison to the amazing Hog Island oysters I've had before, they just couldn't beat em' out. I heard that they actually feature Hog Island Oysters from time to time, but we must've visited the night they weren't serving them.

The interior has a lot of character w/ navigation maps, an old skool cash register and wood paneling everywhere. You can't help but visualize an old, crusty seaman walking through the front door. It reminded me of a much smaller version of my San Leandro restaurant fave, Horatio's.

Some think of it as a tourist trap, but I honestly never see it stuffed w/ tourists. It seems like more of a neighborhood/locals spot to me.

Overall, I'd go back in a heartbeat for that Lobster Bisque and a tall glass of Stella!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
The rating system is a little wacky when it comes to the merits here.

For the oysters, 12 for $12 and DELICIOUS BEAUTIES at that.  This was a savory, wonderful place.  I'm in love.

For the lobster bisque: YUCK.  Too creamy.  I'm beginning to notice a trend forming among my taste for soup.  Anything too creamy and too salty makes me want to hurl.  

Should have stuck with the oysters.

The only way I convinced the BF to drive me here was the $2.50 Stella on tap.  It made him happy which made me happy.  But having him watch me slurp down those briny packets of orgasmic creamy dreamy makes me indebted to him in unspeakable ways.  So ladies, if your boyfriend does not like shellfish at all, don't eat oysters in front of him.  I think I've grossed him out in ways reserved for human autopsy.  

The funniest thing was we met this total nutter while there.  She came in waving and smiling and greeting people (us).  I looked at my BF and he looked at me and we both had the same thing going through our heads, "oh, she knows you?  Because I don't know her..."  It was a fantastic and funny conversation.  We had the bartender rolling his eyes.  Not always in wholesome ways.  Good to know we can still banter like a stand up routine.
author: Christina C.

description: Crab was killer but pricey for how much you get.  Make sure to get the sourdough bread bowl with clam chowder.  It is as authentic as you can get.
author: Eric L.

description:
Such a great place! Every time I have been I have never had to wait....whether there is just 2 of us or 6 of us. 
This place has such an awesome variety of seafood and you can either go for a nice sit down dinner or just drinks and appetizers. I was there this evening and had a nice glass of wine, some fresh oysters of the day and some AWESOME dungeness crab cakes! 
The prices are reasonable, the service is great...and food is delicious. You really can't go wrong with this place! 

Note:  Parking can be difficult so taking public transportation or wearing very comfortable walking shoes are good options!
author: Holly K.

description:
1st- Parking is not easy around here, so don't drive! Take a cab, bus, walk, whatever, just don't hope to park a car here! 

2nd- This is not a hipster, funky style place. It definitely has a seafood restaurant feel, you know, like what you would find at the Jersey shore, or other East coast beach restaurants. 

3rd- The food is awesome! Fresh and flavorful. I was here once with 3 others and we all tasted each other's  food, and everything was incredible. 
The fish en Papillotte is always a hit- the fish is steamed in veggies and is served to you in the paper, keeping all of the flavors inside for each bite. 
The lobster bisque was creamy and tasty, seared ahi, almond encrusted salmon, all of it- so good! 

You should stop by sometime with someone who is willing to share, so that you can taste more than one entree.
author: Amy J.

description:
Last minute stop for dinner with my girlfriend... I was looking for another place I found on YELP but found out it was closed when I got there, in our haste and dying of hunger after our brisk walk I found this place. I could've done better. There was no wait which was great but I soon found out why. 

BOTTOM LINE-- Way over priced for the quality of the food. $96.00 I'll never get back.
author: Jose P.

description:
Hyde's Seafood House 


SERVICE: NOT GOOD AT ALL, they ran out of LEMONS..( how go you run out of LEMONS' at a SEAFOOD HOUSE?) so you must have patience's going there!

LOCATION: NOT a lot of street parking so go early!

FOOD: OMG . it place its Yum Yum GOOD! Really .. I took my friend visiting SF and it couldn't be better! They have the best HAPPY HOUR. M-F 5-7 pm; We had a DOZEN oysters for 12 bucks ( GOOD DEAL )  GOOD WITH the FRANNY BAY OYSTERS. 

WE had the potato wrap salmon.. SO GOOD!  Must try! 

PRICE : reasonable good for happy hour!
author: Char K.

description:
The best (quiet) happy hour in the city! 

In my opinion, a good happy hour has little to do with cheap well drinks, a crush of people and poor service. You need to focus more on the word 'happy' when choosing a place to wile away your early evenings.

What makes me happy is good beer cheap, a place to sit and relax, somewhere you don't need to yell to be heard, somewhere that if you happen to end up staying and eating has more than one thing on the menu that isn't fried or doused in cheese. Finally somewhere you don't walk out of feeling cheated.

Hyde Street has all these things in abundance. They have $3 beers, $12/dozen oysters that are fresh and grit free, one of the greatest interiors in San Francisco, warm, well mannered and welcoming staff, oh and the food is pretty good.

When friends come to visit, one of my best tricks is to sight see and then end up here for happy hour. We can then choose to eat there (the stuffed trout or anything 'en papillote' is great) and continue chatting, or get on the cable car and end up in Union Square to go dancing or to a play. By the end of the day, I've normally got them half talked into moving here.

Can't say enough about the staff ...
author: Ali N.

description:
We went for happy hour (on a Saturday!) for the $1 oysters, which were really fresh (although the exclude the Kumamoto oysters from the HH special - sigh). I prefer my oysters with lemon, cocktail sauce, horseradish and tabasco - instead of with a fancy mignonette - which is the way they serve them here - yay! We also tried the raw sampler (prawns, oysters, clams and smoked salmon) was delicious, steamed clams were well done with a really tasty broth and the cajun prawns and scallops app was SO good thanks to the sinful pool of butter and oil it sat in. The atmosphere is old skool maritime and the service was super-friendly at the bar.

If you're looking for a place to hang out and eat some good no-frills seafood and oysters in a cozy, unpretentious neighboorhood joint, here's your place!
author: Kate S.

description: Fantastic seafood!  I took a first date here, and we both had an excellent meal.  In addition to having great food, they are reasonably priced.  I'll definitely be heading back.
author: Bryan G.

description:
I would give it a 4.5 stars if I could.  I really, really liked this place.  My boyfriend and I passed it in a cab last night and decided to stop in for dinner.  The prices aren't low, but they're not unreasonable either, especially since the portions are large compared to a lot of the other restaurants I've been to in the city.

We ordered:
-A bowl of clam chowder to share (as an appetizer, but we probably didn't need it, since we were stuffed and couldn't even finish our main dishes)
-Potato crusted king salmon
-Pasta with shrimps, scallops (and something else? It was my boyfriend's plate)

The clam chowder was YUM.  Some of the best chowder I've had, to be honest.  And the king salmon fillet was HUGE, and melted in my mouth.  My boyfriend said it's probably the best salmon he's ever tasted, and I would say the same too.  I wanted to finish it so badly, but I was stuffed.  The pasta we ordered was good, not that special, but it was still good.

I liked the cozy, intimate setting of the restaurant.  The service was great too, and they had a cab waiting for us when we left the restaurant!  

I'd like to go there maybe another time to try it again before I give it 5 stars. :)
author: Sarah T.

description:
Wonderful atmosphere.
Great, friendly and attentive service.
Salmon was delicious and Halibuy was, too!
Great for couples or dining alone.
author: OC L.

description: Rated one star after having had dinner here with my wife on 7/18/13 due to the potato crusted salmon and scallops tasting like very old and rancid cooking oil and finding hair in food.  Server was very inattentive as well. OK atmosphere but was very disappointed; especially after paying $83.00.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Excellent find thanks to Yelp!
Went there with my husband and my mom on Sat night, sat in the window table, and had a fantastic seafood meal for an affordable price.
We loved the lobster bisque and clam chowder and the seafood combo was to die for. 
Staff is very friendly as well! 
Yum!
author: Marisa B.

description:
I went here with my parents and I had the hugest salmon steak ever. it was crusted with potato and came in a really good pinot noir sauce. the waiter was nice. my parents are nice. drank white wine which was called Seabiscuit. I like to base wine choice on label and name only. taste? meh. my dad seemed to enjoy his scallops (I think they're nasty). all were happy. i'm still happy just thinking about it. that's probably because i only eat $1.50 tamales from a liquor store when they're not in town taking me to dinner all the time. 
the vegetables were really green. i liked that too.
not crowded on a thursday night. nice environment. 
big time fish explosion.
author: dinah h.

description: This is a great spot to get oysters for a good price.  We came towards the end of happy hour 5-7pm, and ordered 3 dozen oysters for only $36!!  I love happy hour there, cheap, but good oysters.  My girlfriend had the butterfish special, and it was pretty good.  I had the NY Strip.  I had ordered it Medium Rare, and it came out pretty much Med Well.  The wasn't that great (but then again, I did order red meat at a seafood place).  I would definitely go back there for the happy hour oysters...but nothing else!
author: Kev N.

description:
The bf and I had dinner here over the weekend and were thoroughly satisfied. With less than $100 spent, we had 3 beers, 2 appetizers (two orders of the raw oyster combo), 2 entrees (sea bass en papillote & stuffed prawns) and a full and satisfied tummies. I do have to say, though, that my entree was better than his! The stuffed prawns were really flavorful and though it only came with 5, it was the perfect amount of food. 

The place is small, intimate and the service was excellent. We'll definitely be back - can't wait to check out the happy hour!

Only downside: took almost half an hour to find parking :(

Tip: If you're in the city already, take a cab. If you're outside the city, take BART to Powell and you can take the Hyde St. cable car for the ultimate SF date :)
author: Melissa P.

description:
This is one of the best kept local secretes in San Francisco. The Lobster bisk, the home made key lime pie and everything in the middle. The garlic prawns are off the hook at this great restaurant. 

If you want a slice of heaven on earth you will find some of it here at Hyde Street Seafood. A great wine list to complement the food as well. Great service and food.
author: don h.

description: We were so disappointed in this neighborhood restaurant that had such promising reviews.  The vibe was too quiet as the restaurant was virtually empty on a Saturday night at 9 p.m. While we were there, two more parties were seated, but there was no excitement.  The meal started with off-the shelf stale bread (not even heated), that was so bland we chose to forego it. The second course of  lobster bisque was barely warm enough to eat and bland. The best course was the entrée of mixed fish (monk, shrimp (2), and scallops (but just 1) in a creamy lemony sauce.  The other diner had grouper in parchment, which was well-seasoned but missing salt.  Dessert looked promising - fresh berries and cream, until we tasted it and immediately put our spoons down. The cream seemed to have absorbed all of the tastes in the refrigerator. When we told our waitperson that it wasn't fresh, she protested that it had only been there "for two days."  REALLY?  We definitely cannot recommend this restaurant.
author: Carolyn C.

description: I was going to dinner with a date - we were attempting to go to the Hyde Street Bistro - it was closed.  So, we decided to try this place right next door...it had 'Hyde Street' in the name, so we figured, "what the heck?"  I'm so glad we did.  All of the food was delicious (I ordered the salmon - it was huge) and my water glass never went empty.  We did have to flag down a waiter a couple times, but they were otherwise extremely friendly and helpful.  Not my usual 'hood, so I felt a bit like I was on vacation.
author: Mac M.

description:
A good happy hour is worth its weight in gold. $12 for 12 oysters is a great deal, especially in this city.  And to have them not be mediocre is a nice deal for my palate. 

For me and my girlfriend, a dozen oysters each as well as the lobster bisque is the bee's knees and no more do ye need. The only thing that I could hope for is that it'd be say a block or two farther from where I live so that I could burn off all the coma-inducing goodness that comes with our usual post-happy hour fare. 

Good Stuff!
author: Roy M.

description:
Some of the best seafood in the area.  You can't go wrong with Hyde Street Seafood.  The owners are wonderful people.  So friendly and kind and have a great menu.  

It's rare to find such a place outside of Fishermans Wharf.  None of the crowds and all of the flavor.  The decor is very cool with the wood everywhere and the nautical theme just exuding from every corner.  The beer is fresh and who doesn't love anchor steam?

Must try when you're huffing it in the snob hill! ;)
author: Harry H.

description:
I came here with a person visiting from Atlanta.  I pretty much chose the place based on the Yelp review.  To be honest, I wasn't incredibly impressed.

The decor is nice enough, murals on the walls, good use of wood and such and standard white table cloths.  The service was decent as well, but a bit overt in an effort to be nice (don't blatantly interrupt a conversation to ask if everything is to our liking).  The food was the most underwhelming thing.  I had the potato crusted King Salmon.  The salmon was good, but it was swimming in butter and the it honest looked and tasted like a salmon fillet covered in hashbrowns.  That is fine if I am going to the Waffle House for the 2am seafood special of canned tuna, hashbrowns and grits, but for $19 I expect something a bit more presentable.

I guess this place has far more redemming benefits, but I didn't find them on my visit.
author: Eric M.

description:
It was okay.....

We didn't go for happy hour and we met two people there. 
I really liked that service but what was a minus for me was that they don't have a liquor license but proceeded to have Margarita's and Como's on the bar menu.

I ordered the steak and it was delicious.  Everyone else liked their food.
I think if I go back I would like to go to their Happy Hour since everyone else raves about it.
author: Christine S.

description:
I went with four other friends and everything that was ordered was DELICIOUS!

I had the Stuffed Prawns Bearnaise (lobster, scallops, shrimp & crab meat stuffing) with roasted potatoes and we split a bottle of Viognier. It was a wonderful mix of flavors and the stuffing was so rich. My friend's lobster bisque was more chunky than most bisques I've had before but it was so creamy and tasty. Everyone else's dishes were so good! I highly recommend this place.

Note: parking is a horror! we made reservations an hour before and it was fine for our 5 person group.
author: Anna R.

description:
if your'e in the neighborhood....check this quaint place out! it's my dear friend kiko's friends' family restaurant and it really does have one of the freshest seafood and a very yummy menu to suit any taste bud! the oysters and lobster bisque is a must and i've also gotten the gianormous garlic crab...yum! service is wonderful..if you go, ask for brian and tell him jane sent ya!

fyi...finding parking in the area is uber sucky!
author: Jane Y.

description:
Great little restaurant - the variety of seafood they offered was impressive.
I had their "en papillote" New Zealand blue nose seabass (say that fast 5 times) and my friend had their special of the evening - a seafood combo w/prawns, scallops and monkfish, lightly breaded and pan fried.  It all was just GOOD - familiar/typical flavors very well prepared - everything was tasty, tender, tasty.  
It's the perfect casual none-too-budget-busting-get-togethers-with-close-friends sort of place. Friendly staff that'll keep your glasses filled but otherwise not bug you too much while your chattering away.
author: CINDY K.

description:
I didn't get dinner at this place, but the happy hour was pretty good.  The waitstaff was friendly and attentive, and we got the $12 for 12 oyster deal and topped it off with a few cold beers along with it.  

From what I saw, the inside was decent but having a happy hour with people outdoors (on a rare, warm San Francisco evening) was perfect. 

I'm no oyster expert, but I definitely know what I like and don't like - and these were pretty good.  Would I come here again?  You bet.  Next time, I hope to try out the food!
author: Shay F.

description:
Ok inside the place needs some help, badly! The over done & out dated/weathered nautical theme is just over! I know it's seafood and it's "suppose" to be that way, but this is just BLAH!! Service was eh, almost felt like we were being pushed through a Chinese Cafeteria.
That was the worst on with the better! The Lobster Bisque, YUMMY!! Oysters, AWESOME!! The Stuffed Rainbow trout TASTY TASTY TASTY!! The wine list, surprisingly not bad! Happy Hour sounds GREAT, definitely going back for that one! And will be back for more!!!
author: Rob L.

description: Mediocre at best. Not a full bar, by the way. The food was just meh. The desserts, on the other hand, were awesome. The banana bread pudding is the stuff of legend.
author: Cassie D.

description:
I had so many high hopes for this place since it's located in such a beautiful part of the city. 

But sadly, it is a Tourist Trap. 

Ordered the New Zealand Blue Nose Seabass with jalapenos & tomatoes ''En Papillote" and it was bland; portion size was small. Wine selection was subpar. 

Can't complain about the service for a Saturday night though. They even called us a cab.
author: Regina A.

description:
I came here a couple weeks ago for the first time and was a little disappointed.  I have been walking by this restaurant for the past year and was very excited to finally try it out so perhaps the high expectations contributed to my disappointment.  Either way, it's not a place I will be frequenting on a regular or semi-regular basis.

We started off with oysters - which were fresh and that was pleasing.  I ordered their halibut en papillote which was tasty except for the fact that it was very undercooked - I had to send it back to be reheated. After  it was reheated I really enjoyed it - the simple flavours really worked well together.  My friend got the stuffed shrimp which was good but sort of bland.  Not something I would necessarily pay over $20 for.  The waitress also forgot to give us one of our side dishes.  We tried their escargot and it was on the dry side.

For the amount you pay to eat here, you're better off searching for another restaurant in this city where you get more bang for your buck.
author: Mahogany G.

description:
This review is for the oysters only.  
After a non-filling dinner date...I stopped by  this place on my way home.  None of the entrees looked too appealing so I settled with 2 dozen oysters. Pretty good but nothing above average.  I still prefer Hog Island in the Ferry building.
author: The Beef T.

description:
The oysters are very fresh, with the unbeatable price. I really like the fanny bay they have. I like their old-school style menu.

I feel this is not very PC, but it's very interesting that a Russian Hill seafood restaurant is run by solely asians. And they're good at what they're doing.
author: Pei-Chin W.

description:
The happy hour is clearly the biggest catch. Dollar oysters and $3 draft. The service is wonderful, the waiters are extremely friendly and helpful. Though the oysters themselves are just sub-par. For dollar oysters, I'd recommend Hog's Island over Hyde Street. 

The mussels are not so recommended. The lemon flavor was overpowering , and takes away the natural sweetness in the broth coming from the mussels. Quite a shame.
author: Fiona S.

description:
W. O. W. This unassuming haunt on a quiet tree-lined street (save for the rumble of iconic cable cars) offered us the best dining experience we've had here in SF. 

Service: accommodating, super-friendly, attentive without being annoying (thanks, Johnny!!)

Food: lobster bisque (with plenty of pureed goodness!), Ceaser salad (eh... nothing exciting there), Dungeness crab (huge and meaty!), crab cakes (no dipping sauce even needed on these amazing chunks of seafood!), a couple glasses of white wine (cheap Seabiscuit for $8 ea -- delish!), Key Lime pie (small and tart with yummy berries and sauce), and HEAVENLY banana bread pudding (not your typical blob from a pan; this was cubes of bread, crisp and caramelized in a simmering bowl of amazing sauce that I could drink for eternity). 

Cost: $100 before tip -- well worth every penny!

Final Word: I'm contemplating coming back for a lunch of bisque and banana bread pudding -- yum!!!!
author: Danielle P.

description: Finally got to try this place out yesterday with my boyfriend . We came during happy hour and had 2 dozen of oysters ... we tried all three of their daily special .  Their oysters were very fresh . The oysters from Canada and Washington tasted pretty good . The oysters from local were good too , but not as good . We also had their pasta which was pretty yummy . We ordered some kind of crab dish on the menu ... we thought it was crab because we only read the beginning of the name of the dish and didn't read the rest haha . It turned out to be crab pot pie which did not taste good at all . Will definitely be back to try more oysters !
author: Eileen L.

description:
The decor is charming, the location is convenient for Russian Hill residents, and the food is delicious.

The seafood is great, always really fresh, but I really want to wax lyrical about their lobster bisque... Oh, it's like silk velvet in soup form. In tomatoey, seafoody love. Like so good, that I'm about to change my yelp profile to name it as my pick for last meal on earth. When I had a really big work achievement, and a friend wanted to treat me, this was the soup I insisted on. Seriously, a spectacular specimen of the bisque soup genre.
author: Natalia M.

description:
We dined here on New Year's Day and had to order from their Pre Fixe Menu. I was really looking forward to ordering from their regular menu but they would not accommodate. I wish the person who answered their phone had told me that a few days before. Luckily for them... and me... the Pre Fixe selection ended up being verrry delicious. 

Parking:
Tough... it is a residential area so good luck. We managed to park on Jackson St. between Leavenworth St. and Jones St. which was a miracle. There were several other spaces open at 7:50pm on a Saturday night so maybe that helped. Journey to the restaurant was downhill and uphill on the way back (helped us work off that dinner). Get here early if you have reservations so you leave enough time to find parking.

Service: We were very worried about service based on the other yelp reviews but were pleasantly surprised by the extremely attentive service. We had 3 servers helping us and they were all very kind. We were seated promptly by the window and offered drinks and bread multiple times. Other diners seemed to get pretty good service too but I did notice they were extremely nice to us.

Food:
-Lobster Bisque was amazing. Deep, rich, lobster flavor with some chunks of lobster.
-Kumamoto Oysters were so fresh and delicious, almost sweet. There were two sauces- a horseradish cocktail sauce and a vinegar based sauce, both complemented the oysters well.
-Filet mignon and lobster tail dish was a surprise. The steak was cooked perfectly despite this being a seafood place. The lobster tail was the most tender I've ever had it.
-Chilean Sea Bass En Papillote. The BEST Chilean Sea Bass I've everrrr had and I've some some amazing variations. It was so fresh and tender-almost felt like butter melting in my mouth. It was a very large portion and the white wine sauce was soothing.
-potatoes and veggies that came with both entrees were perfectly cooked. The potatoes were surprisingly buttery and moist even though they were just steamed.

I definitely plan on coming back everytime I visit SF. I sure hope the food is amazing again!
author: Jenn M.

description: Came here Friday night with another couple for oysters and drinks.  I was expecting more of a happy hour place, only based on my friend suggesting we go there, but it is definitely a quieter restaurant.  Still very cute.  Menu looked yummy, however we were only having the oysters that were on special.  4 dozen oysters for 4 people, at $1/oyster is a pretty good deal!  The oysters were good - not amazing, but definitely good.  I'd go back to try other items on the menu.
author: Kristen V.

description: we came here for the happy hour after we checked out nook's happy hour. definitely worth coming to, if you like oysters. for 12 oysters its $12. not too bad. put a bit of tabasaco and you have a fresh and yummy  oyster! we also tried the steamed clams, those were good. not over cooked but nice and tender. the creamy sauce was good and fantastic to dip the bread in. the bread wasn't warm like other places, but it was just a-ok, but i didnt come here for the bread. the clam chowder was creamy yet tasty. there was a good amount of clams, which is always a good thing!
author: Stella J.

description: This place is wonderful.   Great fresh fish, excellence service and a charming décor.  I love their chowder and the prawns béarnaise.
author: Jeanne B.

description: Slightly weird vibe.  Someone below said it had a chinese restaurant feel, and it did in a way.  But the lobster bisque was loved, and my halibut in papillote was good (actually the veggies were the best).  I think the scallops wrapped in bacon were overcooked.  It did not blow me away, but I also didn't walk away wishing I'd never gone.
author: Dan G.

description:
Came here with my boyfriend a few weeks back.  
We ordered 3 dozen of oysters and the escargot.  

Before I review the food, lets talk about the place.  A few other yelpers have mentioned it, but the place is rather chilly even though I was in a super thick sweater, I was freezing by the time I finished.  Because I was cold from the start, I found it sort of difficult to enjoy my meal.  

As for the oysters... it was cheap.  $1 a piece.  Started with the oyster sampler, and my oh my, were some of them small!  They weren't as cold as I would've liked.  Another downside was that every time I swallow an oyster, there would be bits and pieces of the shell with it.  It'd also be nice if the person shucking the oysters would cut the muscle out for us to eat too.  Compared to Tomales Bay, these are incomparable, but I guess these will suffice if I want a quick grab.   

Now the escargot... was NOT WORTH IT.  They were overcooked and was just soaked in oil.  It'd taste a LOT better if they would just put more garlic and seasonings on it and lessen the butter/oil/whatever they put that's making it super greasy! 

ARGH, overall this place is okay.  i'd come back if I'm desperate for oysters.  otherwise no thank you!
author: Emily L.

description:
the oyster combo was delicious - 3 types of oysters. the happy hour deal is great ($12 per dozen). you can also get kumamotos but not at the happy hour prices. 

the lobster bisque was really good. creamy and full of delicious chunks of lobster. much more lobster than in most lobster soups ive ever had before. 

the escargot were not good. ive had much much better ones at chapeau, cafe de la presse, and twist in campbell. 

the walls are covered in old maps. 

i will be back for happy hour oysters, the lobster bisque, and to try fish cooked in parchment paper.
author: Yevi A.

description:
We were recommended this place by someone at Macy's Westfield Mall (didn't have any smartphones or access to the outside world).

I ended up ordering the garlic dungeness crab (first time) and was disappointed while chomping down on the dry, right portion of the animal, but the centre and left portion made up for the garlic that was missing on the right.

I also ordered fresh oysters as my appetizer and was not disappointed.  How can you go wrong?

The restaurant specializes in a type of fish preparation where the fish is wrapped in a thin piece of paper - I'm going try that next time.

Parking was a bitch.  But that's nothing new.
author: That's For N.

description:
Been here 2x and only went back because the first time was very good.

The first time, service was attentive and very knowledgable about the oysters.  They had a special fish that was being served that night, that I got, which was soft, moist, and flavorful.  My  bf got the potatoe crusted salmon, which he absolutely loved.

The second time, however, to our dismay, on a slow night, the service was not attentive and whoever was serving us, was not caught up on the kinds of oysters they were serving.  The food was also only subpar that night, no specials that caught my eye.

It's worth trying but may be a hit or miss.
author: Winnie L.

description:
If you like Oysters, Beer and friendly service, you'll love this place!

The trick to this place is knowing how to order AND when to go. I'm a sucker for sitting at a bar, sushi or otherwise, and being able to order food as my appetite demands is perfection to me. This place is one of those unique restaurants that you can order one dish at a time and not feel guilty.

Come early, around 5 or 5:30, deny the table, and sit at the small bar and chat it up with one of the friendly employees. Go a few times and you'll be family. Ask them for suggestions, they won't steer you wrong.

As for ordering, start with oysters. During Happy Hour (5-7 Monday-Saturday, I think) you can get a dozen for $12. They rotate their oyster offerings, but always have three to choose from. It's rare that their oysters aren't up to snuff, so go for gold and get a mixed plate. Then, when you get seconds, you can choose your favorites.

I rarely order anything other than appetizers. Although solid, the entrees don't have the same appeal to me as eating a bunch of small appetizers. Try the cajun seafood combo, a bowl of clam chowder, or a salad. Check their daily menu for what's in season. You can get a bunch of small plates for the same price as one entree, plus it keeps your taste buds fresh and allows you to build a perfect meal.

I highly recommend the lobster bisque. This creamy soup along with a beer and a dozen oysters is almost enough to act as a meal. It's rich with lobster and perfect on a rainy day.

After you've had your fill of dinner, please try dessert. They have an amazing banana bread pudding with enough butter to stop your heart, though surprisingly easy to enjoy. If the banana bread pudding sounds too rich, they also usually offer fresh berries with whipped cream which is a much gentler ending.

It's easy to imagine this place as a fairly ordinary place if you do the three-course-sit-down thing, but if you like eating small plates, this place is extraordinary with one of the most enjoyable Happy Hours in the city.
author: Timothy P.

description:
Good solid seafood restaurant. 

Had the escargot to start which was flawless. Main course of the scallops in ginger sauce which were good, but not great. Would definitely have them again though. Sauce was good and very light.

They have great happy hour specials. Good neighborhood vibe and a good experience. Would recommend it.
author: Anita B.

description:
The food here is very fresh, but I feel it could have had a little more flavor. There is not a very big wine list either. It is a good place to go for a quick bite. The staff is very attentive and friendly. for the price I would rather walk to Yabbies on Polk st.

Cute atmosphere.
author: Aubrey W.

description:
After six years of eating out in San Francisco, this is by far the best sea food restaurant  i have been to!!

Food was amazing!!
totally the best lobster bisque in the city!!!! mmm mmm!!

I give this place a four stars cause though the food was just perfectly timed, and presented the service was lacking. Took over an hour to get a table when told only going to be a short wait. Make sure to call ahead for reservations. Our server was very nice and took time with us, he was spread way to thin, i am assuming it was a off night and that they were short handed. 

All in all great evening and totally shocked at how reasonable the prices are. Though i do have to say not the best wine list, and  they do not have a full bar, which not a huge issue but would have been a plus. 

Love the down to earth feeling of this place. A great neighborhood spot great for dinner with friends are a nice night out with the lover. Took my aunts here for dinner on their last visit, and they were both in love. 

Hope you enjoy this place, cause i know i will be going back again and again.!!
author: Danny B.

description: We came for the happy hour, but it was not what we expected. We envisioned a crowded pub with lots of stools. What we had was a really romantic dinner at a window side table. So, right off the bat, we were impressed. Our server (I wish I had gotten his name) was the most attentive guy ever. He made sure we were happy, and we definitely were. We sampled the three happy hour oysters (so sad that kumomoto was not an option) and decided that hama hama was the best. We also had the house salad and ended the night with a key lime pie and coffee. I wanted to try the lobster bisque, but we were already full from the dozen oysters we each had. Maybe next time, and there will be a next time.
author: Mary T.

description:
thanks Hyde Street Seafood House! *high fives*

the parents came out to SF for a little visit in july and when i asked what type of food they wanted to eat, they both immediately said "seafood". realizing they don't get off-the-boat fresh seafood living in the middle of a desert, i wanted to take them somewhere i knew would not disappoint. 

and they loved, they loved! the lazy stroll down quaint tree-lined hyde street. twinkle lights in all the trees. the cable cars dinging by. the smell of the ocean mixed with great food cooking in all the neighborhood restaurants. they were excited before we even got there.

you step inside and it's set up the way a good seafood spot should be. small tables, dark woods, candles on every table, weathered nautical maps all over the walls and detailed replicas of old ships displayed on shelves.

i can never resist fresh baked sourdough bread with butter or a creamy lobster bisque, so my mom and i shared some of that while my dad opted for a salad. 

for dinner my dad got the grilled swordfish and ate the entire thing! i couldn't finish my Stuffed Prawns Bearnaise, but i really wanted to. (it has lobster, scallops, shrimp & crab meat stuffed inside. lightly topped with bernaise sauce-- soooo good!) my mom ordered the garlic roasted prawns, and said they were perfect.

we're not a dessert family, so we savored over our wine for a bit before stumbling happily back down the hill to their hotel. 

once again, a great experience here. 

mom and dad happy = successful night
author: Michelle I.

description: Lobster Bisque is the bomb!!  The butter fish had melted in my mouth just the way Johnny explained it!  I don't know how they cooked the fish with the tin-foil wrapped around it but it was cooked perfectly.  Oysters were awesome with a great price of $1 a piece.  I will definitely be back and try the rest of the menu very soon...
author: Patrick C.

description:
Casual dining area with horrible parking..cliche I know :)

Raw baby oysters - MUST ORDER!!!!!!
Seafood sampler - 2 raw clams, 2 oysters, 2 smoked salmon = once you've tried the oysters, you'll order a dozen cuz we did :)
Smoked salmon - YUM
Baked escargots - very bland and overpowering butter less garlic taste....I was literally drowning it with tabasco sauce
Lobster bisque - extremely creamy and the lobster was chopped too tiny 
Cajun sampler - 2 shrimp & 2 scallop - pretty delicious
Sea bass "parchment paper" - partial of the veggies and fish were slightly under-baked 
Accompanied with a bottle of Pinot Noir "Viridian" - YUM!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Katy N.

description: I've had nothing but great experiences here. $1 oysters and $2.50 Spaten for happy hour is hard to beat. The shellfish combo was also a fantastic experience and the bill wasn't too unruly. This place good for fresh seafood at affordable prices, also it's not bad for dates.
author: Devin A.

description:
I went here on Superbowl Sunday and it was no surprise that it was a pretty slow evening  in there. 
We started with a dozen oysters (half-price happy hour...YES!!!) and they were very fresh and delicious. The sauces they came with were pretty basic but good.
I ordered the stuffed shrimp which were competently prepared but not original either. They had a béarnaise sauce over the top which unfortunately "broke" because it looked like it was put on before being set under the broiler. They were moist, buttery and good.
My friend had the crab en croute. I thought it was a bit soupy inside and too rich for me. It was buttery and creamy with a hint of nutmeg in the sauce. Perhaps if I was eating it with the puff pastry the sauce wouldn't have been so overwhelming. He enjoyed it so I think I may be judging it too harshly.
We ended with the chocolate torte which was dry and not well prepared. I assume they do not have a pastry chef on staff and it shows. I can forgive them for this.
Overall I would return for the oysters and to try the selection of fish prepared en pappillote.
author: Rob C.

description:
It's all about the happy hour seven days a weeka dozen oysters for $12? $2.50 pints? Yes please! The oysters were fresh, the beer cold, what more could you ask for?


 Well, maybe one thing - better entrees. If you go to Hyde Street Seafood make sure and stick to the oyster happy hour; I haven't been impressed with anything other than the oysters.
author: tvham

description:
You know those times when you know you are going to be craving the same dish until you go back and eat it again? - well this is what the  En Papillote dish I had last night was like.  

For those that don't know En Papillote translates to 'wrapped in paper'.  The fish is cooked/steamed in parchment paper and then cut open right before you eat it.  I had the shellfish combo.  The serving was huge!!  Not only did I love every peace of shellfish -the veggies mixed  in were just as mouth watering. 

Before I get to some negatives, I'll say the service was excellent : friendly and my water never got less than half way full. 

There was also a few negatives, but my main dish was so good - I will likely go back and know what to expect in terms of the negatives.  They include:

-Bread wasn't that great for being a somewhat nicer restaurant.  Some nice sourdough would be better.  Or a good baguette. 
-We got oysters to start.  While the oysters were good, many of the shells were cracked, indicating the person shucking was not doing a good job.  If you call yourself a 'raw bar' - I expect the oysters to be shucked decently.  
-We didn't like any of the wine  Granted it might have been bad picks on our part - but in general it detracted from what could have been a perfect meal.  

All in all - I'll be going back.  I also really like this small enclave in SF.
author: Josh M.

description:
This is one of my all time favorite restaurant ... for several reasons.  1. Service is the best!  Johnny one of the waiter/owner knows all his customers by name and has great recommendations if you are unsure what to have orun decided between two dishes.  2. Raw oysters there are the freshest I've even eaten and selection changes daily!  3.  Happy hour EVERYDAY from 5-7pm where you can get $1.00 raw oysters and $2.00 pint beer (hello!)  4. French style cooking (parchment paper - don't find that often) so the fish & veggies are extremely moist. 

I've been bringing friends here for years!  After trying it out once, all my friends have brought their friends and family.  Everyone's consensus is that they LOVE this restaurant and will also come back.  

I can go on and on but my recommendation is head over there and try it yourself ... you wouldn't regret it!  Oh, warning - parking sucks since it's in Nob Hill so give yourself (and courtesy to restaurant) plenty of time to find parking or better yet - take a cab!
author: Lily W.

description:
Very reasonable prices and great food.  The only downer was the fact that they double booked reservations and had twice as many people as they could sit standing around at 7:30. 

All in all we had smiles all around with the entrees. I would definitely go again.
author: Adam M.

description: Oysters.. maybe its not oyster season... it tasted kinda weird.. but still managed to hve 2 dozen oysters with my friend.. keke!
author: Monika T.

description:
Decided to try a new place last night.  What would my life be like without yelp? 

We started with 6 kumomotos as an appetizer they were very tasty and fresh but just a tease.  I was ready for some serious seafood after that.  For my entre I ordered the potato crusted king salmon with pinot noir sauce. It was excellent.  I've tried several potato crusted fish dishes in the past and I've had the same issue with each of them. It's a difficult technique to cook the fish properly while keeping the potato adhered to the fish and cooked all the way through.  Often the dishes are under-seasoned or just plain boring b/c of that fact.  There was absolutely nothing I could complain about with my dish.  The potatoes were slightly crispy on the outside and the entire package was perfectly seasoned in a way that worked wonderfully with the slightly sweet pinot sauce.  My vegetables were cook al dente - just the way they should be.  The waitstaff was attentive and polite.  I enjoyed every aspect of the experience.  

Hyde St Seafood House is an extremely good value.  We ordered oysters, 3 entres, a bottle of wine, and a creme brulet for $106!  Definitely goin back.
author: Bassman Z.

description: Food was light, a bit small proportions but overall decent place.  Atmosphere was nice and service is good.  Food is good overall, price could be a bit cheaper but for light seafood and good ambiance, this is a good neighborhood place.
author: Michael H.

description:
This is definitely a 4-star place. I booked a reservation through Open Table on Thursday for last Saturday night. The three of us were seated right on time with a nice table in the front room. I chose this place because my sister is somewhat of a picky eater but loves seafood. The hook for Hyde St. Seafood House was the "En Papillote" preparation...parchment baking of fish with potatoes and veggies. Sister and gf both had snapper and salmon that way. I went for the seafood special of Scallops, Shrimp, and Escolar/Butterfish. The food was fantastic and reasonably priced too. This is a perfect place to get your seafood fix (and the oysters hit the spot too). One gripe I had was we sat with our finished dinner plates in front of us for 10-15 minutes which is a pet peeve of mine. In terms of food I wouldn't put this place in the same group as Farallon or Kokkari...but it also doesn't charge the same prices. That said, I'll be coming back.

Oh yea, Swensen's Ice Cream is a few blocks up Hyde Street. Even though it was cold, who can resist Peppermint Stick Ice Cream??
author: Jonathan G.

description:
What a steal to find the dozen oysters for $10 happy hour deal at this quaint restaurant.  Service was attentive and personable.  My BF dined here before and spoke highly of the Trout en Papillote, so I tried the Snapper en Papillote.  I was expecting a burst of flavor, with its beautiful arrangement of veggies, but I got none. :(  I NEVER add salt to my dishes, but I just had to this time.  My BF tried my dish and was shocked as well - maybe it just wasn't their night.  He had the Cioppino, which was good, but I have definitely had better at other restaurants.
Overall a good experience.  The oysters will have me coming back for another attempt in finding a good entree.
author: Sylvia T.

description:
Wow!  I used to live across the street from this place in 1996 and even back then, $12 for a dozen oysters and $2 pints (now $2.50) was an unbeatable deal.  I'm so happy to see it's still there and doing well.  I would eat there about once a week, and became a regular quickly during the early years.  They would have great parties there as well, and expanded into the space next to it early 1997 I believe.  Awesome staff and the freshest fish made it hard to go anywhere else.

I recommend getting the fish cooked in parchment paper.  Your server will open the dish table side and the aroma is amazing.  Enjoy!
author: Josh F.

description:
"Good, but not great." said the food spoiled chick in SF.  

I like the happy hour oysters...and piles of lump crab.  There's just so many other excellent places to eat in San Francisco.
author: Christine W.

description: Great service, non-fish seafood is just OK.  Avoid seafood salad unless you like those tiny shrimp.  Intimate nice atmosphere.
author: Phil O.

description:
the food was ok.  the service was good, there was one waiter servicing the a majority of the restaurant. for the same amount of money i would highly recommend everyone going to sotto mare. 

elite yelper in training
author: Mike C.

description: We had dinner here last Saturday night and were not disappointed!  Our neighbor had recommended it, especially the fish cooked in parchment paper.  Since we are not fans of oysters (one of their specialties), we each had salmon.  I had the potato crusted salmon and it was delicious; crispy potato coating, delicately seasoned and a large portion of fish cooked perfectly between the potato crusts.  My hubby had the salmon in parchment which was melt in your mouth.  He even ate the onions, which he normally never eats.  The staff was very friendly and the happy hour prices at the bar kept our bill down to a very reasonable price.  We had a window seat and enjoyed watching the cable cars going by with their Christmas lights.  We will definitely be returning with friends.
author: Laylee D.

description: Tucked into a neighborhood and very quiet area. I simply adore this place. Had oysters and escargots here. Mmmmnnn. Server was really nice as well.
author: Lola D.

description: We found this cute neighborhood restaurant last weekend for dinner.  Unfortunately we missed the happy hour $1 oysters.  We ordered oyster sampler as appetizer, sole, and salmon cooked in parchment paper.  The oysters were fresh and tasty.  However the fish dishes were just so and so.  The salmon was a bit bland.  However we would definitely come back for the oysters.
author: Ling Ling Z.

description: This is by far one of my favorite restaurants!  I try to go every time I'm in San Francisco.  A place that was shown to me while on a business trip, I now go to while on vacation and always recommend to people that I know are going to SF (as long as they love seafood).  Their Lobster Bisque is superb.  I've had various "En Papillote" fish that they make and it's absolutely amazing.  Make a reservation, this place is small but the service and food are well worth it.
author: Sheila F.

description:
Excellent place to eat.

Went with my sister and wife on a Saturday night. I got the seared tuna, which is my staple to judge seafood places and was very surprised with the portion size. I got a really nice sized piece of fish. It also came with potatoes and veggies. Good size plate for $20. The wife got ciopinno with tons of fish. It was a little to stewy for me, I like cioppino a little more brothy. Now onto my sister (get your mind out of the gutter)... She got the crab, $35, but fuck it, dad was paying. Worth every penny. We aksed if it was fresh and it sure was, did not have a hint of that previously-frozen-saltness. It was soooo meaty. Seriously way more than was expected. I will say they cooked it with a ton of garlic, but we like that so it suited our mouths. 

It was also nice that it wasn't all touristy, nothing like a Wharf restaurant. It had a good local feel.

Be warned that this is not an in and out type of place. We were there for over two hours. The waitstaff is really nice, but pretty slow as well. 

All in all, great place and worth the money. We also had three drinks and still got out of there with just a $100 bill.
author: Brian S.

description: I was really excited for this spot when the hotel told us about it. I've grown up on seafood and love it like a fat kid loves cake...but I have to say, I thought this place was just "ok". The raw oysters were good size and served as expected. But other than serving bad oysters, it's kinda hard to screw it up. The mussels and clams in a white win sauce were on par with what you would expect. And the lobster bisque was pretty good. Overall it was an average seafood meal. The part that stuck out most was that the waitress went out of her way to call us a cab and let us know when it arrived.
author: Greg G.

description:
As an out-of-towner, I have no idea if this place recently had an ownership or chef change, but I am surprised, actually shocked, at the other reviews here on Yelp. We recently went to Hyde Street Seafood based on a recommendation, and I have to say, without a doubt, this was the worst seafood meal I have experienced outside of the midwest. Where to start?

The appetizers. For me the lobster bisque, which was surely unlike any bisque I have ever experienced before, but in a decidedly bad way. It tasted like the bisque equivalent of Campbell's Clam Chowder, compared to the really great chowders you have tasted. My wife suffered through some crab cakes that were short on crab, barely warm, and of a gooey texture reminicent of mochi. 0 for 2.

On to the main courses. I was served some sea bass covered in a very sweet cranberry sauce, alongside some basic steamed brocolli and green beans (seriously? is this 1982?). The fish was overcooked but edible, but the sauce was completely overpowering and way too sweet. 0 for 3.

My wife's dish was quite a bit worse - various seafood cooked in parchment. Again, severly overcooked. The scallops were as hard and rubbery as hockey pucks. The halibut was bland and dry. The herb mix was not enough to disguise that this was low quality (likely frozen) seafood that was cooked at least 5-10 minutes too long. She barely touched the dish - it was simply that bad. 0 for 4 with 4 swinging strikeouts.

At this point, we decided to cut our losses and pay the bill, skipping on the weak offerings of dessert (key lime pie? - again is this 1982?). Overall, this was quite a bit worse than what you would receive at a Red Lobster, and appalingly bad for a city I assumed to have good seafood.
author: Ryan A.

description: Tried Hyde Street out after seeing the 4 star rating on Yelp and reading a few reviews. Def has the locals vibe and is not in a touristy part of town. The server was very nice; he may even have been the manager. Bread was great. Caesar was ok. The clams menuiere were too fishy and had a strong ammonia smell. My hubby had the halibut special cooked in the parchment. Fish was cooked just fine but the other items on his dish were lacking in any flavor. I ordered the pepper ahi and it was cooked to medium rare which was great - I did ask if I could have it rare and was told that the chef doesn't like to be told to cook to a different temp, he doesn't like to change things. So ok - we went with medium rare. There was way more garlic than pepper and it was tough to finish it without picking off the pepper and garlic coating. Overall it was not an unpleasant but a bit out of the way to come just for the restaurant. My kids were still hungry so they ordered chinese food from the hole in the wall across the street, U Lee, and I have to say that was awesome!!
author: Julia B.

description:
We went here on a Saturday night for dinner and I was surprised that it wasn't full.  We went around 630 so we could do the happy hour special.  $1 oysters and $2.50 beers...that was great.  We also had the lobster bisque which is seriously awesome.

We also had a caesar salad and some trout that were just ok....kinda bland.  

So I will definately be going back to this restaurant  for the happy hour special with some lobster bisque.
author: Luci B.

description: The food here simply put, is just bad.  We gave it a second chance after a bad first impression, but it was worse.  The only thing that keeps me from saying the food is terrible is that the Bisque is actually pretty good.  We ordered the Halibut and the Cioppino and both were a waste.  The Halibut had absolutely no taste at all, and the Cioppino tasted if it had come out of a can.  I have never written a review before, good or bad, but I felt that I needed to.  I didn't have any problems with the service, but the food is just plan bad.  I wish I could give it no stars...
author: Matt B.

description:
Thank you Yelpers for not steering me wrong once again! Dozens of oysters, lobster bisque, and their special scallops wrapped in bacon starter for dinner, plus key lime pie* and creme brulle dessert and we were stuffed. Service was excellent! 

The scallop was a little pricey for the serving size (but made up for it in taste) and the *key lime pie was disappointing completely, but it will not stop us from going again. 

How can you beat the $1 oysters at Happy Hour and the great service?
author: Tommy B.

description: This place is in one of the more intimate neighborhoods for restaurants in San Francisco. Russian Hill makes for a romantic opportunity any time of year and this seafood house has excellent seafood. The focus is on the raw bar options and their french specialty the "En Papillotte". They have a good wine list and are not pushy. You can also have a great meal at the bar if you're just with a friend and want to open a bottle of wine, share some oysters and great conversation.
author: Darin A.

description: Excellent! The freshest seafood out there.  Worth the walk up the hill!
author: Martha C.

description: I think this place has the best cioppino in SF, hands-down.  But watch out: the serve escolar, the olestra fish that gives you orange waxy anal seepage.  Do not eat the escolar.
author: Asteridae A.

description: Went here for Happy Hour on a Monday (happy hour 5-7) and of course had the oysters. Fanny Bay were the best of the 3 I tried. They serve the oysters on ice with 2 lemon wedges and 2 sauces. One sauce was a vinegar sauce with garlic and the other was a cocktail sauce with horseradish spooned on top. The horseradish was old to say the least, coloring was brown and flavorless. I really enjoyed our server until the end when he was nowhere to be found to get the check. Overall it was a good deal and I will be back for oysters... May smuggle in my own horseradish.
author: Ashley M.

description:
There was a long wait for every other place on Hyde Street, so I certainly wasn't expecting much from this place since it was pretty empty on a Saturday night.  However, I was pleasantly surprised!  I had the seafood combo special, and aside from the brussels sprouts in the vegetable medley, I ate everything on my plate.  My husband got the lobster ravioli which was rather rich, but still very good.

I live just a few blocks away, and am always looking for reasonably priced places to eat  in the neighborhood that still deliver good quality.  I have definitely had better seafood, but for the price and the convenience, I will be back!
author: Alison P.

description:
Came here for Happy Hour with my favorite partner in crime. We had a few glasses of yummy Fume Blanc, 2 dozen oysters, Cajun calamari, escargot, and Cesar salad. 
All of the food was excellent with the exception of the escargot. I've had some divine snails at Ralph Lauren's Restaurant as well as Mon Ami Gabi in Chicago and these little suckers tasted like...well snails. Somehow at the other places I've been they managed to elevate the status of these small slug like creatures into an exultingly high gourmet standard, but alas this was not the case at Hyde Street. I'd say stick with the oysters. 
The oysters were fresh and briny, the Cesar salad had a nice vinaigrette style dressing, and the Cajun calamari was tender and well seasoned. A+ 
Service was great and very friendly. We enjoyed our happy hour and escaped with only a $100 bill. Not shabby considering I paid that much for 2 dozen oysters alone at Hog Island.
author: Stacy T.

description: Love the lobster bisque!  Great local, neighborhood restaurant with friendly service.  Seafood is excellent and definitely will make it a regular neighborhood haunt.
author: Helen T.
