description: No way that was seafood! Service a zero with the food coming out after an hour from placing our order. My scallops looked like a hockey puck and the wine was the wrong vintage! No way anyone should eat here!!!
author: Jordan K.

description:
Tasty food at a reasonable price. Recommend for anyone with a craving for shellfish. Service was good and staff were friendly. Nice quiet neighborhood restaurant.

We had two seafood salads, which were loaded with fresh bay shimp, crab and smoked salmon. I ordered the ciopinno which was delicious! My friend had the salmon with vegies and potatoes baked in parchment paper and the clam chowder.

The entire meal was under $60.00!!! Would have been 5 stars except the salmon was a little undercooked and had to be refired, but all in all, a tolerable mistake considering the cost of the meal.
author: Duane L.

description: The last time I was here at this quaint neighborhood attraction was 15 years ago.  At that time, I didn't live in California and I felt like this was a place I wanted to live at some point.  Well, 6 months ago I moved to the City and tonight I had a reunion dinner here.  It was as cool as I remember it being back then.  Danny, the host and possibly part owner, is very accommodating and pleasant.  Had the Fijian Sea bass en Papillote.  It was fabulous and the fish was like butter.......  Now that I live 3 blocks away, I will come much more often than every 15 years.
author: Jeremy S.

description: This is a hidden gem!  The food was great....lobster bisque was fantastic, potato crusted salmon was yummy and the crab pot pie was to die for. The only reason I didn't give them 5 stars was because the scallops were over done.  The service was really great and friendly.  When my husband didn't like the wine he order they brought him two small glasses of other wines to try.
author: susie h.

description:
I suppose I should preface my review by stating that until 2009, I'd never really been to San Francisco before, perhaps a remarkable thing for being 24 years old and a native of California.  Anyway, I ended this 24 year drought torrentially, visiting SF three (3) times in a span of six (6) months. During each stay, I visited Hyde Street Seafood House.  

Fittingly, I found Hyde Street Seafood House on Yelp, when my friend and I were on what was essentially my maiden voyage into SF while on a cross-country road trip to Boston.  I'm a big seafood fan, and I simply wanted to eat some good seafood during my first stay in SF, and after scouring Yelp recommendations, I settled on Hyde Street Seafood House.  I had the salmon en papillote, and about nine (9) or ten (10) glasses of ice water.  The king salmon was awesome, and the food and dining experience made the approximately one mile walk to this place worth it.  

The second time I visited this place, three (3) months later, I'd driven up to SF on short notice for a job interview and figured I'd return to the only place I'd ever eaten at in SF, even if I was going to be dining solo.  The salmon en papillote was great, but the service was second-rate this time; even though it wasn't that busy, simple things like bread and water refills took forever.  I also noticed that they apparently raised the price of the king salmon en papillote in the three or so months since I'd last been here, which vexed me a bit.  Still, my meal was good.  And this time, I took the cable car to and from the restaurant, which made for a decidedly San Franciscan experience, at least in my mind.

The third time I visited Hyde Street Seafood Cafe, I did so in the company of two high school friends and a mere month after my second visit. We made the same mile or so walking journey to Hyde Street Seafood Cafe that I'd done months earlier.  For the third time in a row, I ordered the same entree (king salmon en papillote) and wasn't disappointed.  Same solid meal.  And this time, the service was considerably better.  Both friends seemed to really enjoy their meals and the experience, and one of them said so explicitly.

Anyway, after three visits here, I think I've gotten a pretty good appreciation for Hyde Street Seafood Cafe.  The bottom line, at least in my mind, is that this place serves really solid seafood and is in a great, picturesque location.  Service is generally pretty good but occasionally mediocre.  Anyway, next time I'm in SF, I'll head to Hyde Street Seafood Cafe again.
author: Lance M.

description: I've never yearned or dreamt of such beautiful lobster bisque. If it's not crack they are putting in it, I just won't believe it was made naturally that good. And I can't leave without their creme brulee. Their happy hour deal with the dozen fresh oysters and a bottle of wine is a death trap. It hurts just thinking about it.
author: Marilyn N.

description: It is a legit 3.5 stars.  The people are nice, food is pretty good and the restaurant is unique.  Good neighborhood restaurant.
author: John N.

description: Listen, the food was delicious but our food took two hours to come out. No alpolgies. No food comps. It was a big damper on our evenimg plans. I only give three stars because the food was great. Sigh.
author: Lisa K.

description:
My then gf (we are now married, still newlyweds), lived just around the corner from this place.  I kept pestering her to go there as it looks, from the outside with the tiny white Christmas lights, like a good cozy place for dinner.  She kept telling me to forget it, it is not worth going there.

Finally she gave in one evening.  

Why  didn't  I  listen to someone that lives 300 ft away from this place!!!  What was I thinking!!!

The Hyde Street Seafood House is an establishment that catches tourist off the Hyde street cable car line.  What tourist could resist jumping off for a seafood dinner at such a quaint looking place?

As a dining experience, well, forget about it.  There are hundreds of better places to go...anywhere!!!

The interior is tacky, no big deal, but the food shouts out 'frozen and cheap'.   The fish I had (snapper) was bland - En Papillote because it is an easy way to cook frozen fish which they probably have a freezer full of.  .   I can see it now... order comes in for snapper en papillote, no problem, grab a frozen stack out of the freezer, get a knife, wedge it in between the fillets that are stuck together, bang bang bang, ahhhh, separated!!! Wrap it in foil with a dab of butter and toss it in an oven (or steamer for all I know) and voila!!!...off to the fool at table 12.

Vegetables?   So over steamed  they were like mush. 

They may be better than the meals at the Pacific Medical Center hospital on Castro & Duboce, but if you ask me I say it is a toss up.  If you think highly of Red Lobster or Olive Garden, I would say give it a shot, but I would never recommend this place to anyone - I would get voted off the island if I did that!!

I guess my gf figured that the only way to get through my thick head was to let my find out for myself.  Ok, ok, I am an idiot!!!
author: Ron B.

description: Good quality seafood prepared simply (ie not drowned in spices or sauces or trying too hard). The service was really slow and the atmosphere is a bit old fashioned, but I would go back anyway as the food was excellent and I find it hard to find a place where the preparation doesn't overwhelm the delicate taste of the fish .
author: Christine H.

description: Had a reservation at 7:30pm. We were seated and it took about 20 minutes for them to take our order after we flagged someone down to remind them about taking or order. We had a small child with us that was accommodated for but the service seemed less than ideal for a what seemed like a slow Friday night. The food was amazing, I had the Crushed potato king salmon and would highly recommend getting it. Other than the little flub in service I'd return again to give it a second chance.
author: Ernesto F.

description: Wow. $1 oysters??  I'm in heaven already!  I had the catch of the day (mahi mahi) en papillote.  It was delicious.  (Might be a little bland for some people?)  The atmosphere was great, the service was great. Loved it and will be back every time I visit San Francisco.
author: Jone H.

description:
Everyone was right, happy hour oysters were a fantastic deal. My mother in law had not had a raw oyster in her life, and I could easily down a dozen so we got some. She loved them so much that she acually had 4. I love sharing the joys of the raw bar with an oyster virgin!

My wife got the lobster bisque and it was pretty darn good. I had the mixed grill, and must say that anytime I can get a butterfish I am a happy boy. My mother in law got the shellfish en papillote which was fine. She loved it but I am not a huge fan of en papillote in general. 

So why the three star rating. My fish was drowning... no sinking in a vat of an overly salty greasy (broken) beurre blanc. Yes beurre blanc can be a velvety slice of heaven, but even with a good one I do not need 2 liters of it to enjoy fish that was perfectly cooked and VERY fresh. Don't hide behind sauce! That is one of my serious pet peeves. Also the scalloped potatoes that came with it were one solid glump (that is a conjugation of gloopy and lump) of reheated slop. 

Fish + Oysters + soups = 5 stars
Sides + Sauces + attention to detail = 0 Stars
Total 3 stars. I would give them another chance... but mayber just for pints and oysters.
author: Seth H.

description: Went here last Friday for happy hour, and surprisingly it wasn't as packed as i thought it would have been. Score! Parking wasn't terrible, but it's not plentiful either. As for the oysters, I can't really complain since they're only $1/oyster, but the shell shucker was definitely an amateur. Not that I know how to shuck shells myself, but I definitely know when i taste them in my oysters!!! Out of the three oysters listed on the menu that day for happy hour, the Hama Hama was my fave!
author: Kristen C.

description: Super food at reasonable prices in nice neighborhood. We'll be back!
author: Peter A. H.

description:
I have a soft spot for this place. I'll tell you why:

- $1 oysters, $5 lobster bisque (yummy!) and $2.50 beers between 5 - 7 PM every day of the week. 

- Kitch decor: It's like walking into a boat. I hate it but I love it.

- Friendly staff with a neighborhood feel.

- I may be disenchanted if I ordered the expensive stuff off the main menu, but with such a generous happy hour deal, it's hard to not love this place, quirks and all.
author: Sarah G.

description: AMAZING happy hour every day from 5-7. Dozen oysters for $12 and $2 beers. I've eaten in the restaurant a few times and have loved every dish I have gotten. Perfectly cooked and delicious! Great date spot :)
author: Linda K.

description:
Thanks Yelp and Yelpers. Had we not yelped onto this spot we never ever ever would've known. And the knowing... is good.
If I could, I'd give this place 4 n 3/4 stars. From finding a free parking spot across the street, to stepping in and getting a table a half-hour before our reservation, to polishing off 5 varying seafood dishes: this place delivered.
We were seated during happy hour, allowing us a dozen assorted oysters for 12 bucks, to start. 
*of the assortment, our favs were the steam boat oysters: give 'em a try. Meaty, clean, and delicious.
*lobster bisque: I've never had lobster bisque. Infact, my tummy rejects cream in a most uncomfortable way and yet, I could not stop eating the stuff. This is a MUST-ORDER. 
*crab cakes: lovely crab flavor. A little softer than I prefer, but I do not regret the order.
*prawns bernaise: prawns swimming in melted herb-butter stuffed with a puree of scallop, lobster, and crab (I believe). Rich and heavy. Not as unbelievable as it sounds, but the prawns were cooked perfectly.
*shellfish en papillote: I guess I forgot how appreciable the true flavor of seafood is. I was thoroughly impressed with this simple dish, and savored the taste of clam, mussel, prawn, and scallop. The julienned veggies that accompanied were nice, steeped in all the shellfish liquor. 
-- All with a few glasses of white wine. Good service. Tucked into an intimate and distinctive spot. 
--Very reasonably priced menu. $$ without drinks, $$$ if you don't feel like sharing. (You totally can without feeling deprived).
Not so fancy-pants that you couldn't walk in off the street, neither would you feel out-of-place in your "goin-out" clothes.
Again, thanks Yelp, I've found a new go-to seafood house.
author: Rachel C.

description:
Why Hyde Street?  Why can't you have some better restaurants?

This place is a stand-out on the street, but it's still not very good.  Like being the tannest albino in the albino colony.

Vegetables that came with the papillote halibut were stale and tasted of nasty freezer burn.

Cioppino was not so nice to look at (rusty red color-- probably stewing in the pot for a few days) and not so nice to taste-- salty, not fresh, dull spices.

Why Hyde?  Why?
author: tim p.

description: It's all about the happy hour seven days a week...a dozen oysters for $12?  $2.50 pints? Yes please! The oysters were fresh, the beer cold, what more could you ask for?
author: phil h.

description: This review is just for their happy hour.  I have come here several times on a Friday night and their happy hour deals are pretty superb.  Oysters for $1 each, fantastic.  A Sierra Nevada for $2.50, yes please!  I personally love their lobster bisque and their crabcakes.  The crabcakes are a little different, heavier on the crab, as opposed to more filling, which makes them different but really good!  It's not hip or trendy, just a great spot for a cozy happy hour.
author: Lauren H.

description:
3.5 stars

it must have been some raging happy hour weekend because by the time i got there, they were out of oysters.  bah.

still, the call of seafood was beckoning me.

the seating was slow out the gate but thankfully it was not a sign of what was to come for service.

surprisingly the lobster bisque was so rich and creamy that it felt closer to a chowder and it was chock full of lobster chunks.  just delicious.

the next tables ordered the seabass and that smelled just wonderful.
it made me regret my following orders of the scallop and shrimp.
the shrimp was perfectly seasoned but the scallop was overcooked and dry.  unfortunately, the broth was almost non existant in the mussels dish so they too were dry.

i'll chalk it up to an off night and i'll be willing to give this small neighborhood spot another shot.
author: Anh V.

description:
The service was curt and expansive at the same time.  Our server attempted light small talk but seemed to tire of that before finishing his sentence.  Then with a weak smile he enticed us with happy hour specials before we touched the menu.  Smart move.  For having dinner on an early Sunday evening we were rewarded with a selection of 12 oysters for $12 and a $2.50 pint of Stella and Sierra.  A soft, "Cheers" was whispered as he dropped of our pints then gave us a brief explanation of a couple dishes.
Not to be ignored, and not on happy hour, were the garlic steamed clams.  They were tender and garlicky with plenty of sauce to soak my bread.  We were full before we ordered dinner, but the gluttons we are, we ordered two more dishes, cioppino and a fettuccine Alfredo.  
The cioppino was delicious with mounds of luscious seafood, crab, scallops, shrimp and clams.  Each cooked to perfect buttery firmness.  The tangy and slightly spicy broth warmed my tummy on a blustery summer evening.  The creamy seafood pasta was slightly smokey with similar perfect seafood atop.  
I was extremely happy with everything about our dinner, from the nautical atmosphere to the full window view from our table to the reasonable prices ($19 for cioppino).  I whole heartedly recommend this place.
author: Shelley H.

description:
four stars for their oysters and their service.

...three stars otherwise. 

This place is a small, cute, very quaint place. It's nestled in a predominantly residential neighborhood so parking is pretty tough. Their service is friendly and helpul. The waiter even went so far as to tell me what NOT to get, as well as his favorite dishes.

 So this place is supposedly famous for a particular way they prepare their fish, which is wrapping the fish and some veggies in parchment paper and baking it. This is supposed to retain flavor and moistness of the fish. So we ordered the halibut and the fish was very moist, not dry by any means. Other than that though, the fish was ok. It tasted fresh, but was pretty bland in flavor. The veggies in the parchment package were also not very flavorful. 

 Their seafood salad was good with really fresh tasting baby shrimp, lump crap pieces, and smoked salmon. A pretty small salad for ~12 bucks though. Their lobster bisque was pretty good...it tasted like their base was pureed corn, and the bisque was yellowish in color. It didn't have a strong lobster aroma to it...the pieces of lobster were almost like the consistency of crab since it was a lot of little itty bitty pieces in the bisque. Tasty, but not amazing. 

 The stuffed shrimp was pretty good; a little salty and quite buttery. The cioppino was good. The soup was tasty, the shrimp in it was ok, the mussels were pretty good, the big scallops were good, but the baby scallops weren't so good.

Overall, good ambiance, good service, great oysters, everything else is pretty standard for a seafood place. Their menu is pretty eclectic from cajun style scallops and shrimp to steak to their french preparation of fish. Wouldn't mind coming back for the oysters. Three people with three entrees, a salad, a soup, oysters = $100.

P.S. Happy hour between 5-7. Dozen oysters for $12 (SO WORTH IT) and a few types of beers for $2.50.
author: Christine L.

description:
let me start off by saying i dont go to places without easy parking. i dont valet.... i had friends that were valets and also had a few bad experiences with valets.....

im the type that drives around the same one block radius over and over and over again to find parking close by. 

that being said, i parked over TWO WHOLE BLOCKS AWAY when i came to hyde street. for you nonmathy types, that means walking more than four entire whole blocks to eat here. even with this minus five star parking situation, i must say i really liked the place. that first time i went, i was VERY pleasantly surprised to find everything to be pretty damn freaking good. i blogged about the night on my other online crack, xanga....

http://www.xanga.com/home.aspx?user=euge_415_w210&nextdate=5%2f5%2f2005+23%3a59%3a59.999

and found out through that medium that the place belongs to a friends friend. go figure. fast forward about a year, we all had dinner in the marina. 

the food is excellent. i am a seafood snob. i liked this place. the xanga link has a good description of the entire meal but i will just recap the meal with my main course. i had the ciopino. EVERYTHING in the ciopino was pretty freaking good. the fish was FLAKY!!!! the crab was actually fresh as well with the shrimp and everything else. seriously, you find terrible ciopino more often that good, let alone a pretty freaking damn good one. id say this one was pretty freaking freaking damn good.

minus one star for making my lazy ass walk. WALK!!!!
author: Euge L.

description: My substitute for the Monday night happy hour at Hog Island Oysters which has become impossibly crowded. They have local oysters at $1 a piece and 2.50 drafts until 7pm and the rest of the menu is respectable if safe seafood. Very attentive and friendly service and an OK wine list makes this a solid choice.
author: patrick g.

description: This Russian Hill gem has an appropriate nautical ambience featuring walls papered with old maps and covered with framed photos of ships. I'm not a fan of raw shellfish, but there's plenty on the menu to keep me satsfied. You can't go wrong if you order the thick clam chowder, moist crab cakes, or creamy lobster bisque as a starter. As an entree, anything ordered 'en papillote' - the traditional French technique of baking julienned vegetables, fresh herbs, white wine, and a selection of fresh seafood in parchment paper to seal in the food's natural flavors and juices - is guaranteed to be outstanding. The cioppino is a delicious blend of clams, mussels, prawns, fish, scallops, and crab meat in a rich marinara sauce. Your carnivore companions will be satisfied with pepper-crusted New York steak or pan-roasted pork chops with sauteed onions. You might regret the warm banana-bread pudding or chocolate cheesecake in the morning, but live for today and order one of them anyway. The staff is friendly - and seems to remember everyone they've ever served - and prices are affordable.
author: Gourmet G.

description: Awesome oyster deal for happy hour!  I think there are better places to get the rest of the dishes they offer, and I ordered a papillotte dish that was undercooked and it's their specialty!!!  Disappointed in that, but if you're going for the oysters and beers, you're in good hands.
author: Angela C.

description:
yum yum yum! My honey and I last Sunday decided to yelp around and found this gem through here. We made reservations, found decent parking and went in to enjoy ourselves with the happy hour of a dozen oysters for $12.00!!! Well, our reservation was not on the book, however we were setted promptly. Our waitress was very hard to understand. And, she had a hard time understanding we were going to make a meal of small plates! She kept on trying to push the special of the day. " You no want seafoo spechale?"PLEASE! We ate 2 dozen oysters, which were luxurious! Fresh, sweet and lovely. Then 6 raw clams, the bf liked them more than me, Scrumptous steamed mussles in such a wonderful broth we were putting our bread in it to soak it up, and shared a bowl of delicious lobster bisque. Needless to say we were very happy clams! haha. But the "waitress/hostess, made this date a little less memorable. The rest of the waiters seemed to have their act together. She kept asking if we want to order dinner now! Our water was hardly ever filled, bread empty, and basically ignored tho it wasn't very busy. When she did come by and say something, we just nodded, having no idea what she said. We ended this fabulous seafood meal with a very ho hum teeny slice of key lime pie that tasted like it was made at safeway.
I give it 4 stars though for the very wonderfully fresh seafood! And we love Tony Bennett and we aren't old!
***We were going to go to Swans, but after such horrid health score, employees not washing hands, dirty prep areas, etc, we decided against it until they clean up there act! :P
author: Christine E.

description:
Let me preface this review by saying that i am fully aware that i was not in the best of moods when we visited this place.  However, a glass of vino and a friendly server can usually turn me right around. Not the case last night.  My bad for not looking @ the menu before sitting down.  It felt like an old school cheesy fishouse divey restaurant - something you would find down in Fishermans Wharf.  And thats how the menu read too.  Is this place trying to be "french"?  a french seafood restaurant?  sounds like that could be charming... but SO not.  I did get my glass of wine and that took the edge off a bit.  I wasnt super famished so just ordered the escargot. Usually, that and some bread can be just fine for a lite dinner.  I have never been so grossed out - the snails (yes - snails, not escargot) were garden variety - litterally. They tasted like something my mother could have wrangled up from her yard. They were soaked in oil with no seasoning AT ALL. (UGH... just thinking about it...i think i just threw up a little in my mouth)  They were so nasty that i actually had the waiter take them away. He didnt bother to ask if everything was ok or wonder why i requested he take them away.  I guess,  to be fair, i could tell from the moment we walked in that service was not going to be stellar - just a hunch - and it proved to be correct. Although the guy next to us was getting the red carpet treatment. All through our "meal" it was "oh how is everything Steven" and "what can i bring out for you Steven" and "would you like another drink Steven" and so on...  and EVERYTIME the server/manager/owner? went to "Stevens" table, (which by the way, they had to squeeze by ours to get to),  she didnt even glance our way.
Just really bad bad bad... dont go people. dont go.
author: nicole w.

description: I stopped in once for oysters and champagne.  Delivered on both just fine.  In general, I am a sucker for restaurants on this tree-lined portion of Hyde Street.
author: L W.

description: Yes, the seafood was pretty fresh, but I think I'd expect that from better seafood restaurants in the bay area period, right? Well this place was definitely overpriced in my opinion.  The best thing was probably the oysters which were a great deal I'll admit.  But everything else our table got was just kind of bland and not that tasty.  I was really disappointed considering it was one of the first seafood places we ate at since relocating here.
author: Jen T.

description: Great raw oyster happy hour from 5-7pm every night!!!  We tend to go on Friday or Sunday nights and there is always room at our cubbie table by the window.  Well-seasoned dishes, friendly staff and reasonable prices make this place a regular or a special occasion.
author: Haru K.

description: Go for the happy hour: $1 oysters and $2.50 Anchor Steams.  Everyday until 7pm.  Lobster bisque is quite good too.
author: Brooke S.

description:
I will always vote for food above ambience, wait and other factors. But this place is AWFUL. 

Starters. We ordered - Cajun combination of Prawns & Scallops . Took 20 minutes to arrive. Adding red pepper to Provencal spices does not make them cajun. Dish was just ok.

Main Course. We ordered - Broiled Local Snapper with tomato, olives & basil and my friend also got the Snapper baked in parchment paper with fresh herbs, julienned vegetables.

My dish was WAY oversalted. But the veggies were tasteless. Just boiled and thrown on the plate. My friend's dish ( baked snapper ) had NO salt at all. The restaurant was 1/2 full , but the dishes took way long to arrive and were awful.

Its so hard to go wrong with snapper. Its a great fish. I'd never go back here again.
author: Rooibos T.

description: The freshest seafood and oysters! The sea bass melts in your mouth and the seafood pasta is to die for...Yum! and the best lobster bisque I have ever tasted!  I always crave it! The service is efficient and the staff is super friendly.  I've been here a few times and enjoyed every single visit :)
author: Kymberli C.

description:
We came in early on a Sat. night in the hopes of meeting up with some others -- got a table for 5 and then 25 min. later had to let the staff know it would only be 2 of us.  Staff was very gracious about accommodating the change.  They have a HH seven days a week so the BF got a super cheap beer (cheap in price, not in taste!) and the HH price for oysters were a dozen for $12 (what a steal!).  
I got a cesar salad which was OK and the potato crusted salmon in pinot noir sauce - quite tasty.  The BF, having the luxury to be more decadent in his ordering because he has an insane metabolism, got the crab something or other.  Essentially it was a crab pot pie and it was AMAZING.  I couldn't help but take bite and bite of his because it was just so good.  Wine list is great too - lots of choices.  
Surprisingly for eating at 6:00 on a Sat. night the tables began filling up pretty quickly.  Cute restaurant, nautical theme - not tons of ambiance, but great service and yummy seafood.
author: Katie P.

description: It's interesting to walk by the bustle of Hyde Street Bistro and into this hidden gem.  The food was fresh and simple and the clam chowder was excellent with chunky potatos.  The best service in the city.  They take excellent care of you and I think they only staff four at a time including the barkeep.   It's one of those places you should take people to let them know you know what's up.
author: Mz M.

description:
A group of us went to catch the tail end of happy hour.  The owner said they stopped serving it and instead of leaving which we should we decided to stay and get dinner.  

All 8 of us ordered different things on the menu and not one of us was impressed with the food.  I will never go back here.  Even the oysters had pieces of shell in them and were underwhelming.  

The service took forever too.
author: Peter F.

description: Yelp has led me so wrong for the first time.  This place had some of the worst seafood I have had.  I would bet so much $, that 3/4 of our food was previously frozen.  Why have so many of you rated this place as 4 and 5 star?  The food was poorly prepared, everything had too much onion (big chunks) and the lobster bisque was loaded with pureed carrots.  The scallops and shrimp had the consistency of cardboard.  The faults of this place are in no way due to an off night.  I will say the service is very friendly and the bread they serve is excellent.  Atmosphere and cleanliness are also up to par.  If you want seafood, go to swan oyster depot.  Parking situation is terrible.  Leave plenty of time to park if you have a reservation.
author: C B.

description:
yeah, yeah... this maybe a biased opinion, but it definitely is the best seafood restaurant in the city!!!!

hyde street seafood is one of my favorite restaurants!  not only because of the staff, but it could be the lobster bisque! It is to die for... trust me- once you have some, you'll be craving more! I also enjoy the selection of fish... always a delight in my tummy.  I have recommended the place to many of my close friends and all of them love it!  In-turn they recommend it to others, return wanting more and call me to let me know that they are craving it, too!!

Hopefully you'll try it...  just ask for Brian, Johnny or Tuan!
author: kiko v.

description:
Went here for happy hour - not a fan. 

They have a 12 oyster/ $12 dollar special. We (the 3 of us in attendance) for two plates = 24 oysters.

I LOVE oysters.

There were not good oysters.

An assortment of 3 kinds. Only a few were smallish and tasted ok. Majority of the oysters were super large, phlemmy, and tasted nasty. Not at all fun to eat. I hate the phelly, mucussy oysters. Especially large ones. Ick. no where near the ones we had from hog island. 

i will not ever be going back!
author: Kay T.

description: I really love this place. While it's expensive, their seafood is so fresh, the options seemingly limitless, the wait staff helpful and attentive and the ambiance very cozy. Delish!!!
author: Sadia J.

description:
We made an 8:30pm reservation on a Friday night. We were forgotten about until 9:00pm, then IGNORED for another 15 minutes before leaving. Literally, the wait staff avoid looking at us!! We asked twice to be seated during that time. (We're a nice normal Nob Hill couple... )

We got up to leave, and expressed our frustration (tactfully). The waitress was going to offer to buy our drinks (one spring water, one wine), but wouldn't until she knew what wine my boyfriend ordered! TACKY.

We refused her offer to buy my water and paid our drink bill.  We are foodies and eat out almost every night, but this place is off our map permanently. Unbelievable!
author: Cynthia P.

description: I'll be honest; the food was pretty good. The reason I have to give it only two stars is because they told us they needed our table and we had to leave. We were not dawdling. The four of us in the party were enjoying appetizers, drinks, entrees, and dessert when the manager walked up to our table and told us to wrap it up. We were stunned. There was no "would you mind moving to the bar", or "we are so sorry, but..." It was just "get the f**k out". The restaurant was busy, but really? Kinda rude.
author: Seth H.

description: Went here with the BF for a nice dinner, and that's exactly what we got.  It's reasonably price, and offers decent-sized portions. After an appetizer, wine and bread (which was really good) we both still cleaned out plates. I'm not sure we'll visit this place again, though. It has character but wasn't overall memorable.
author: Lara L.

description: I live right up the street from Hyde Street Seafood. Though so much of Nob Hill is prohibitively expensive, this place is like a little bastion of family in the middle of an otherwise yuppified neighborhood. Not only is the food consistently fresh, innovative, and delicious, but the wonderful owner often visits the tables personally. Surprisingly, my fiance and I can get a table at 8:00pm on most weekends - it's a true neighborhood gem. In short, fresh crab, oysters, a wide variety of seafood, perfectly cooked vegetables, and definitely go for the Papillote. The best part is that it is completely affordable (before drinks, $15-30).
author: Bruceroff U.

description: I really enjoyed this place.  We had a party of four here on a recent Friday night, and though we stood around for a good 20 minutes for our 7:30 reservation, the wait was worth it.   I had the Cajun combination of shrimp & scallops and it was delicious.  I would have maybe liked a larger serving of vegetables on the side, but that's OK.  I'll definitely be back to check out their oyster happy hour special.
author: DD B.

description: Hyde Street Seafood has a very special place in my heart because I went here on my first night in the City that I have grown to love.  I sat at the bar by myself and the very friendly bartender Brian happily chatted away with the guests (I think there are between five and ten seats at the bar).  I got the lobster bisque (SUPER TASTY) and something like the seafood extravaganza (can't remember the exact name) lots of tasty shellfish and pasta.  It's just a lovely place to have a tasty seafood meal.  Good for dates too.
author: Heather R.

description: This place has the best happy hour!!!  The oysters are wonderful and the parchament paper cooked fish is really good!!!
author: Philip L.

description: I believe the past review have allowed for improvements to their cuisine since my experience was nothing short of a pleasure cruise through seafood heaven.  Nothing charred here. The King Salmon was almost to large to finish. Lying in a bed of fresh steamed veggies all wrapped in a wonderful parchment that when cracked open emits a flavorful aroma of light fluffy filet waiting to be mashed between pallatte and toungue. It was great. The oysters were magnificent as well, the best choice would be from Washington, small yet most perfect taste and texture. The Creme Brulee was made perfectly to top off but i could have chosen something more balancing to compliment the salmon, maybe something chocolate.
author: River W.

description: This is one of my favorite places to get crab (big enough for two)! it is SO GOOD. The service and ambiance are on point...the only thing that sucks is the parking. Definitely order the crab, lobster bisque, crusted salmon, and oysters. Deserts are yummy as well.
author: cristina s.

description: Awesome atmosphere, great spot for romantic dinner for two. Food is pretty fresh and tasty, price is fair for the portion & quality. Would definitely go more if the parking situation was better.
author: Susan X.

description:
although we were pressed for time, the service and food were exceptionally good.  the search for parking was a pain - but what else is new in the city.  great little neighborhood if you live there though.  the oysters were fresh and invigorating - go, go happy hour!  and the lobster bisque was delicious - although, this was my first experience tasting it.  the decor was interesting - gotta love the very large, carved wooden spoon and fork on the wall over the pick-up counter....flashback from the 70's?  

will have to try it again for a proper meal and not just a sampler dinner.
author: Grant T.

description: Clients, who were in the meat industry, liked the fish here.  I'm not sure that's necessarily a compliment, but I enjoyed my two visits.
author: Kevin S.

description: I was underwhelmed by my experience at Hyde Street Seafood House but I'm willing to give it another shot again.  The evening kinda went downhill in terms of food - the oysters started out great, then the new england clam chowder was good but a little too starchy, and then the seabass en papillote (wrapped in paper, their specialty) was overcooked and quite bland.  It felt like everyone who worked there was trying very hard though.  Maybe next time I'll try the cioppino and see if it's any better!
author: l c.

description: A good place for a date or a mellow dinner with a couple of friends.  The food was excellent.   The lobster bisque was swimming with tasty lobster bits, and my potato crusted salmon was super moist.  M. had stuffed trout, which I also tasted and it was very good as well.  (one benefit of being in a relationship is when I'm torn between two things, M will almost always order one of my choices so that I can try both.) The server kept a close eye on our progress but didn't interrupt our conversation or try to move us along.    We'll be back sometime soon for happy hour.
author: Amanda B.

description: During happy hour, their oysters are only $1 each! I always have a dozen just for myself along with their lobster bisque. Their oysters are delicious. Lobster bisque is great too but sometimes it's too milky. Their fish is okay. Service ranges from decent to fantastic.  Stay away from their house wine; it's gross.
author: Faye S.

description: This place is a must! I always crave this place, but never go because of the lack of parking in the neighborhood. If you're not driving definitely go here if you're in the mood for seafood, it is excellent..
author: melissa g.

description: I couldn't tell you what was memorable about the food as it didn't leave an impression, however, the decor did. It was as if a nautical supply store had threw up on the inside of this restaurant. Seriously, just because you're a seafood house doesn't mean that you have to find every anchor, braided rope and sailing map and attach it to your wall. Just sayin'!
author: Shane P.

description:
this review is just for the happy hour oysters and beer.

that being said, the oysters were yummy - $12 for dozen - and $2.50 stella. you can't go wrong with that. the service is great - especially our waiter brian. 

i am definitely heading there again - soon!
author: Dot K.

description: I have only gone for beers and raw oysters, but they are worth four stars.  $2.50 ice cold beers, and $12 for a dozen oysters is a steal.  If I make it home from work early, I often run over here before happy hour ends at 7pm.  I have no idea what the rest of the menu tastes like.  The service has always been good (very curteous, quick), and they give you bread and butter even if you are just having oysters at the bar.  Not sure if this is a plus or minus, but it is generally dead at happy hour.  This is great if you want to read the paper while drinking a beer on your own, but not a date place.
author: Brendan M.

description: Great little neighborhood seafood place.  Cozy atmosphere, charming ambience, friendly staff.
author: Rose Q.

description: Yesterday afternoon (9/14/2011), I realized just how powerful my craving for lobster bisque had become.  And so, I convinced a friend to join me for dinner at what was said to be (so says the Googleweb) the best lobster bisque in San Francisco.  We enter the restaurant near 6:30 p.m., which was apparently early for their dinner rush; as we were one of two tables seated.  The interior of the space felt clean and did not at all smell like fish.  The dining room is separate from the waiting and restroom areas, which made me feel even more confident about the cleanliness.  I ordered a glass of Prosecco, my friend a white wine; and both of us order a bowl of the lobster bisque.  Soon, a bread basket with an ample amount of butter (in a small dish) arrives to the table.  The bread is served at room temperature, and tastes fresh.  It is not chewy or too moist like a dessert bread (which was nice!).  On the table is a candle in a small decorative storm glass.  The candlelight makes me notice that the linen table cloths are actually covered with a white butcher paper square, which doesn't really make sense when you are at dinner at an expensive seafood restaurant.  At any rate, the soup arrives and is served in a white stoneware bowl with a typical soup spoon.  Upon my first spoonful, I am delighted to find that not only could you taste the lobster, but you could see the pieces of it throughout the dish.  The temperature of the soup cooled-off quickly, which is my only complaint.  The temperature of the restaurant was comfortable to me as I wore a short-sleeved blouse.  By the time we left, each of us paid about $20 (including tip) for the meal, and the restaurant was full.  I would feel comfortable taking a client to this restaurant, and would be interested in going back for an entree.
author: Alisha F.

description:
I don't like raw oysters, but I had them here, and they were good. 

Ok, so I'm a foodie, so I will review the food 1st, and service, ambiance, convenience, etc. later. 

Food:
-- Raw Oyster Sampler of 6: Came in a silver tray filled with ice, a center cocktail sauce topped with something yellow (ginger?) which we did not get around to eating, as the waiter recommended we use the alternate dipping sauce of what looked like red wine vineagrette with shallots (can't be certain on the sauce) which was such a good complement to the fresh oysters, we dared not overpower the oysters with it. But, it's nice to have the choice. 3 types of Oysters were on the menu... so we sampled them all. Our favorite ended up being the "Washintonian"-- very plump, rich, and juicy. Two other types- one from the Bay Area was very briny/sea like...still good if you like that, and the other from British Colombia was more neutral, ok. My friend said,"Should have trusted the waiter and gone with all Washingtonian... ".   
Appetizer: Ahi- Sesame Seared: fresh, on a bed or greens, with a cheerful cherry tomato garnish, and pink ginger. Slightly chewier than I'm used to, but then I ate the more cooked ends and my friend ate the more raw middle. (Note: I actually don't really like raw fish, so maybe I'm not the best person to review this dish.) Good, but I've had better. 
 
Soup: Clam Chowder... creamy, perfect, with chunks of potato and clams, a good aroma, garnished with a sprig of parsley, artfully placed not so that it looked like I had a small tree or piece of moss in my soup-- like most places have-- but like a welcoming coat of arms resembling the "Fleurs de Lys". It was also first class delicious. I have had MANY clam chowders, and this restaurant has THE BEST CLAM CHOWDER very. My friend tasted it too, (she didn't want any at first... said she was stuffed) but the chowder was that good that she ripped off a piece of the bread from our bread basket and dipped it in for a few more tastes. 
Main course: Shrimp Bearnaise- 5 BIG shrimp topped with a lobster/crab/scallop cake type thing in a tarragon sauce accompanied with potatos, cute little carrots, green beans, and yellow squash. Exceptionally unusual, and rich. Yummy.
The sea bass with tomato and jalapeno pepper baked in parchment paper, their specialty, was well presented, and came on a bed of julienned squash and various vegetables and a side of potatos. It was mild, not as rich as what I'm used to having sea bass taste like, and healthy. Some yelpers have complained that the fish in parchment paper is bland or tasteless...mmm, sort of... I would call it 'healthy'. What you see is what you get... the fish was fresh, portions generous, and it was a good match for the shrimp bearnaise which was a bit too rich.

Ambiance: Cute, cozy. Good for a date or special occasion or for happy hour oysters (I've heard, but not yet made it to happy hour) We went for my friend's b-day. Mellow, not uppity. 

Service: Really nice, generous, friendly waitstaff. They let you taste the wine if you're not sure what you want.  Let us sit in a comfy booth in the back with room for 4 instead of a small table in the middle of the room for 2 upon request.  

Convenience: Easy to book a table on opentable.com Also, they were friendly and took my restaurant.com certificate. This made up for the fact that street parking is pretty much nonexistant in the Russian Hill Neighborhood and the closest garage at Pacific and Polk costs $10. That's fine, but lest you circle the block in vain, and in pain, trying to find an open space, the parking garage is about 2 blocks way, is actually for a Sports club, and if you want to eat late,( when we went they said they locked the doors at 8 PM), you have to go over to the nearby Paint store parking lot, pay for a ticket to some guy in a jacket, and then cross over the street again and park at the Frame store's parking lot.  

So... in summary:
Food Highlights: Excellent Raw Oysters and the BEST CLAM CHOWDER in the world. 
Service: Excellent
Ambiance: Charming
Parking: A bit of a headache.. but the cable car also stops near by. 
Would I go again? Yes.
author: Karen W.

description:
Okay-while I'll admit the happy hour oysters and anchor steam is awsome, the service there made me cringe.

My boyfriend and I went for the happy hour before heading to another restaurant. While we sat at the bar, the bartender began to chat with us about what we had planned for the evening. After my boyfriend metioned where we were eating( a decently expensive restaurant) the bartender said, "oh you must be doing the dine about town," ( a month long pre-fix speical that restaurants do in the winter to generate business). Now, there is nothing wrong with dine about town, it's a great way to eat at great SF restaurants for less, but it put us off that he would just assume that we could only be going to this restaurant if they were having some kind of deal. Then, a few minutes later the manager/ owner came over and joined the conversation. After mentioning we were students she said her daughter was comming into town and wanted a cheap place to stay. She went on to say that we must know a bunch of cheap places to stay. Umm no, sorry lady. Yes, we are student but neither of us is even close to being poor-We were really insulted, and not even the great happy hour could lure us back.
author: sarah jane l.

description:
hands down one of the best old fashion Sea Food places i have been to. Some place you would expect to find on the Oregon coast, not in the heart of San Francisco.

Only draw back is no liquor, just Wine & Beer.
author: Mark P.

description: Started off bad when we had to seat ourselves after waiting up front for 10 minutes.  We then had to grab a waitress who took another 5-10 minutes to come get our drink orders.  The happy hour deal is a good bargain, however, some of our oysters were not so swell (I'll skip the details on the consistency, but she ended up telling us they were supposed to be very "creamy"; what?).  I would rate this one star, but the beer any oysters were so cheap at happy hour, I guess I should have expected it.
author: Christian C.

description: Dozen Oysters for $12. Awesome. They had Local Oysters from Marin, they were the best, along with the Hama Hamas. We also had some from washington. Very good. They have a great happy hour for beers too. I wish they had wine on there though. Oysters do better with wine. They also have a very good Lobster Bisque.
author: Sarah S.

description: Even with reservations I had to wait 30 minutes. Waiters were very harried but also very nice. Food was tasty but 2 of the 3 people in our party got sick afterward. Incredibly hard to park in the area but found a parking garage.
author: Paul D.

description: I had a really great time here.  The service was good, the food was great and the ambiance was really nice.  I just got the seared ahi because I'm a non-adventurous seafood consumer, but I tried a little bit of everyone's meal in my party, and I liked it all.  Everyone was very pleased.  I will definitely go back.
author: Carolyn H.

description: Cute, small and bistro-esque.  The fish en Papillotte is AMAZING!!! I think I've had the seabass numerous times, and the mahi-mahi on a few occasions, and wow- you just want to eat every juicy morsel!  The ceasar salad and steamed clams were quite tasty and the service has always been good to us, even on Friday evenings!  To top it off, they often serve this chocolate lava cake that is out of this world! Yum-wah!
author: Alicia W.

description: This is my favorite place for raw oysters!  You can't beat $12 for a dozen oysters - seven days a week!  I love the Marin bay oysters (I think they refer to them as the "locals").  The clam chowder and lobster bisque are great too!  The first couple times I came they had something called the seafood dinner on special (escolar, shrimp and scallops if memory serves) which was a great deal.  The paper wrapped fish is also wonderful - I tried the seabass which is cooked with tomatoes and jalapenos - a surprising combination that works really well!  The service here is great, very friendly service and they remembered us on our first return trip (and every one since).
author: wingless g.

description: This place is a GEM! I took my boyfriend here for his birthday and we loved it. Everything from the food to the nautical decor is sure to make even a New Englander feel right at home. I suggest to you all the bacon wrapped sea scallops, they are out of this world (bacon makes the world a better place). Sadly, this is a dish that rotates on their specials but if you are lucky enough to go when it is on the menu do not pass up your chance. We also moaned over the mussels and fish dish and ended the orgasmic experience with a slice of key lime pie. Simply a treasure in Russian Hill and dangerous when you live as close as I do!
author: Sugey G.

description: Came here for their happy hour on a Friday, wasn't as busy as I thought it would be.  Cool nautical stuff on the walls, friendly staff and the happy hour special: dozen oysters for $12 and $2.50 beers, it made Hyde Street an easy place to like.  A little note on the happy hour, the special on beers is for the first 4 beers per person and is good for Anchor, Sierra, Stella and Spaten.  They had 3 types of oysters that night, Hama Hama, something from Marin and something else, I wish I'd remembered which, because one of them wasn't as good as the others, but I was told that they have different oysters at different times so definitely want to go back and try some more.
author: Mike U.

description: Very good food.  Everything my husband and I ordered was great.  We had the lobster bisque, which was creamy but delicious, and the crab cocktail, which was also very good.  The meals were even better - sea bass and seafood stuffed prawns.  I hope to go back soon and would recommend to anyone with a craving for seafood.
author: Rise G.

description: This quaint little restaurant is pretty romantic and perfect for a date, as I've had one of my best dates there. Seafood and champagne = yum!
author: kristin e.

description: Very good dungeness crab...enough to feed three (but yes, I ate it all myself!)  The oysters looked good, but didn't try them this time around.
author: Angela T.

description: Lovely, quaint, local dinning spot.  Perfectly kept secret for us Hyde Street locals.  Warmly lit, with unique decor - old maps with a non-tacky fishing motif - friendly service, attentive when they needed to be and distant when dinners where in midst of conversation.  Food was splendid. I had the baked escolar with julienne vegetable. Fabulous.  The fish was full of flavor with the perfect consistency.  Vegetables were cooked at the perfect point where each still had their unique flavor and crispiness.  Great dinning experience.  Five stars if it wouldn't have taken so long to get the check.
author: Amanda L.

description:
$12 for 12 oysters?!  and they were very good, we were given a variety of three kinds.  although, some weren't shucked too cleanly (for $1/oyster, i don't mind picking shell pieces out of my mouth too much).

the rest of the food...we had the cioppino and the sea bass parchment-paper dish that i can't pronounce (it's french).  decent but not *wow*.

the waiter was very friendly, but he was a tad inattentive at the end, maybe because it was starting to get busy.

i'll be back to order a few rounds of oysters and to try the dungeness crab.
author: Jolene T.

description: Excellent lobster bisque!!  Wow. Dip the bread in it and it's lobster heaven!!  Oysters are fresh, which is good since they are an oyster bar.  Their fish (escalot?) was cooked wrapped in paper over a bed of veggies (zuchinni, cucumbers, squash, carrots, etc) was great!!  The fish flavored got simmered into the veggies, but still retained the freshness, softness and flavor.  Crab cake was also delicious.  Soft, creamy and good.  I was not disappointed by this visit.  I would def. come back.  I want to try their happy hour!  Staff was attentive, friendly and knowledgeable about the menu.
author: AhLin C.

description: I just moved to Russian Hill and am anxious to explore all the restaurants in my new neighborhood, the boyfriend and I decided to go out last night and just walk and find a place we thought looked good. We walked by the Hyde Street Seafood House and were enticed by the delicious smells wafting out their front door. We walked in and it smelled even better! The food here is great, really fresh and simply prepared. The place has a great old school ambiance and the service is particularly exceptional, our water glasses were never empty and our plates were cleared quickly. I had the stuffed rainbow trout and my boyfriend had some kind of prawn, scallop and monkfish dish that was really good. We finished up with the chocoate torte which was rich but really satisfying. I am definitely adding this to my list of neighborhood food joints.
author: Cathy T.

description: I definitely don't care about the decor as much as some folks seem to, the point is the food, right? I had lobster bisque, bacon wrapped sea scallops, and shared a bottle of the house white wine with my companion. All in all a pretty damned good meal, and a great place to take my out-of-town guest.
author: Darren M.

description: This place is great.  I am still shocked that it wasn't packed on the Saturday night we went.  It's well-priced, has excellent, fresh fish, and decent wines available.  We had oysters, lobster bisque, the spicy shrimp appetizer, and two of the en papillote preparations.  While I am not a huge fan of en papillote, they were both tasty & had tons of fish.
author: Shannon H.

description: After a long day on the water we ended up at the Hyde Street Seafood House. We were very tired. The food was excellent, the waiter was friendly and efficient and we caught the next cable car down the hill to Union Square, The end of a great day in San Fran. I had the Scallops with Ginger Cream Sauce. Delish!
author: Daniel M.

description: My man and I discovered this place randomly while walking around the neighborhood.  Turns out to be one of the best seafood places I've tried in the city!  The prices are totally reasonable and the friendly wait staff give it a great feel.  The lobster bisque is so perfect and doesn't leave you feeling too heavy.  They always manage to pick out the best oysters, too.  An overall awesome find.
author: Victoria G.

description: You would think finding excellent seafood in San Francisco would be easy....but of course Fishermans Wharf is a travesty....and there are not that many seafood restaurants in other areas.  Hyde Street offers very good seafood in a casual atmosphere, with excellent service and no attitude.  You can walk in 90% of the time and be seated --- FR's and Sat's may have a short wait...but may not.  The specials are always hits, the bisque is outstanding and the salads are also nice.  I like the salmon in potato crust --- but it may be an acquired taste (it's like hash browns on salmon).  Best of all is the service which is so friendly.  Only minor nit -- prices are a *little* higher than they should be....but ultimately worth it.   This and Yabbies are my favorite seafood restaurants in the city.
author: Anna S.

description: Generally speaking I'm a bit skeptical of any seafood restaurant that actually has "seafood" in their name. However a friend and I went to Hyde St Seafood House on her recommendation and it was excellent! The service was incredibly welcoming and friendly and the food is some of the best I've had. My choice was the escolar cooked in parchment paper with fresh vegetables and herbs, which was incredible. My friend had the seafood fettuccine which was also excellent, and both wines we ordered were great. I'd give this place 4.5 stars if I could, and after a few more visits I may just have to bump it up to 5.
author: Will A.

description: Happy hour oyster prices are cool but rest of menu was pricey for the amount of food you get. We tried stuffed prawns and they were so tiny!! We had to stop and get a pizza elsewhere after. The lobster bisque was really good.
author: Mickey Z.

description: Warm and cozy inside, with walls neatly wallpapered with maps and maritime hodgepodge, but open-aired and not overly-cluttered all the same.  One of their specialties is their "parchment" method of cooking fish, cooking the fish wrapped in parchment paper together with vegetables, white wine and thyme, so it all steams together.  It was nicely made, tasted fresh and clean, and looked pretty.  If you're craving fish, you can count of finding something satisfying, good, and not overpriced.
author: Today Y.

description: I lived in SF for nearly 10 years, and frequented the Hyde Street Seafood House and Raw Bar for the last 4 of those.  The lobster bisque is outstanding as is the dungeness crab.  The wine selection is only okay, the parking is aweful, but the staff and ambiance wonderful.  As another reviewer put it, this is quintessential San Francisco.  You will enjoy it.
author: Jaime B.

description: We took my girlfriends parents to this place- good food and location in the city. But I was disappointed with the atmosphere and clientele at this place...for what it SEEMS to be on the web, its not as nice inside and while we were dressed business casual most people had on jeans and sweatshirts or the like. But as I said the food was good- its a tradeoff.
author: Rob J.

description:
I haven't been there in about 1-2 years.  The only thing that deters me from going there is the parking situation.  It's really bad.  There's only one parking lot on Polk street that is fairly walking distance.  Otherwise, it's all street parking.  

The food is excellent though and so is the service.  Johnny and all is brothers & sisters are great folks.  I have not had anything there that I didn't like.  I think it's long overdue that I go there and pay them a visit.
author: Maryanne D.

description: Great little place. Good for couples. My bf took me here for VDay this year and it was AMAZING. The staff made me feel okay for staying there chatting and having a romantic evening for a couple hours. There was no rush to get out and go, they were very friendly and awesome. The lobster bisque is TO DIE FOR! Best I've ever had, EVER. AND my creme brulee was FABULOUS!
author: Brenna R.

description:
This is truly a 'neighborhood' place. If you live in the area and are wanting some decent and fresh seafood, your choices are limited. However, Hyde Street Seafood House is not a bad choice.

Being that my dinner buddy had some dietary restrictions, we were relived to see that their specialty, En Papillotte, was a good option. She had the Butterfish, fresh herbs and veggies - she loved her dish and kept commenting on how the flavors were so simple and yet so delicious.

I had the seafood fettuccine, featured a surprisingly lighter and tastier cream sauce than I had anticipated, small bay scallops, shrimp and smoked salmon. It was quite good!

I did notice that most tables around us had ordered the fresh raw oysters to start with - I felt like I had missed out and am planning on going back. They have a happy hour of special drinks and $1 oysters!
author: Caryn L.

description: One great place to eat fresh seafood...  Even if you don't like seafood they have other stuff on the menu like beef and pork...  One place which won't charge you a arm and a leg to get good food...
author: TERESA L.

description: I will be redundant for the sake of making a point. The oysters are fresh and wonderful and the lobster bisque is unrivaled. I tried some at another establishment a few days later to compare and could barely eat it. The service is great, I always feel welcomed. Overall a great neighborhood spot.
author: J A.

description: Great fish house and good prices.  The staff was fast, efficient, and gracious to our party of 8.  The food is very affordable for what you get.  I would skip dessert, though.
author: Jen T.

description:
So far definitely one of my favorite restaurants in the city. Excellent service, fresh and often local seafood, and cute-somewhat elegant atmosphere. 
I highly recommend it for happy hour!
author: Jess B.

description:
On a girls' night out last Friday, we decided to indulge ourselves with $1.00 oyster and champagne and lots of delicious seafood.  We were at Hyde Street Seafood Restaurant.  2 of the girls do not like raw oysters so the 4 dozens of oysters were split among the three of us.  Yum!  I could have more of the oysters if we did not decide to have dinner at the same spot.  I think my record was having around 60 oysters at Hog Island in the Ferry Building.  That was a company event so everything was free.  I guess it is true that people tend to eat a lot more if it's free.  Anyway, besides oysters, we also had the scallops wrapped with bacon.  Everything with bacon tastes super delicious!  For entree, I had cioppino, which is not too bad.  I did not enjoy it that much because I had way too much food before the entree was served.  I had some fish baked in the parchment paper at this restaurant before.  It was really really tasty!

I wondered why the restaurant uses soju for the cocktails instead of vodka or any kind of hard liquor.  The bartender told us that was the ordinance of the City.  All restaurants along the cable car line, from California to Lombard, cannot serve any hard liquor because they don't want some drunks cross the street and hit by the cable car.  Funny, huh?  Some people get so drunk from drinking champagne...  Anyway, I learned one thing by dining out and had a great girls' night out.
author: Michelle H.

description: Husband and I ate here by happening upon it since our hotel was nearbly.  What a find!  The food was exceptional and fresh (maybe the best lobster bisque ever), service was prompt but not rushed and prices were fair.  Highly recommend.
author: Bonnie G.

description: Excellent service. Order the fish wrapped in parchment paper with julienned veggies and the seafood fettucini alfredo was the best of it's kind that I have ever had!!! The Calamari app is yummy, too. The lobster bisque is to die. Delightful and fresh seafood, and not bad on your wallet either.
author: Hilary P.

description: Excellent Food, service was good.  I would eat there again.  Parking is hard to find, but it's San Fransisco...you should expect hard to find parking.
author: John P.

description: We were kindly greeted with friendly welcome at the door. We immediately sat down after circling for parking for over an hour. Parking was just ridiculous in this area. All their seafood is extremely fresh..i enjoyed their clams alot ....biggest clams i ever had..yum! Going to take advantage of their happy hour next time 5-7pm= $1 oysters and $2.50 beer
author: stephanie n.

description: One of my favorite local spots. Family owned, great food, and awesome service!
author: JA R.

description:
This place is OVER-RATED.

I'm not sure how this restaurant has gotten so many five star reviews.  Maybe yelpers are inexperienced with good seafood or maybe they're "sucker[s] for restaurants on this tree-lined portion of Hyde Street," as one yelper put it.

I've been to the restaurant twice, once with a friend and her family and once on a date.  The first time I remember thinking that the fish was okay, but nothing special.  The second time I was looking for oysters, it was late at night, and I didn't want to go far.  The restaurant is conveniently located in relation to my apartment, and I'm also magnetically drawn to the restaurants on this quaint block, so I figured I'd give it another shot.  After visiting, it's been decided that the fish is reliably mediocre, and not worth the price.  The restaurant isn't ridiculously expensive, but it still isn't worth it.  It's worth noting that the oysters were delicious, and I would go back for the happy hour.  I believe it's 5pm - 7pm every day, with $1 oysters and cheap beers.  My date liked her clams, so maybe you're safe if you stick with the appetizers in general.  However, the caesar salad was no better than one you'd pick up pre-made at Trader Joe's for $4, the bread is white, (read bland), and the fish is boring.  Stick with the raw bar and you'll be ok, but avoid the entrees and anything else between the appetizers and the drinks.

I give the place points for friendly service and, again, for the oysters, but that's about it.  The christmas lights out front in the trees are cute, but the cheesy decor inside contributes to my assertion that this place could be much better, if only the owners strove for a more substantial dining experience rather than relying on the cuteness of the location to bring in customers.
author: Michael F.

description: I ate here for the first time last night and I loved it!  The happy hour is definitely worth the trip.  My friend and I split the oysters, which were excellent,  and we each got a bowl of soup.  Her Lobster Bisque was wonderful, as was my Clam Chowder.  The staff was friendly and attentive.  The bar area is small and cozy.  I would like to go back and try some of their seafood entrees.
author: Sara H.

description:
great happy hour (5-7 pm) deals seven days a week! divine oysters & refreshing beer.  a perfect combination after work or late afternoon on a weekend.  

overall rating: 4 stars (excellent oysters & beer for your money, friendly staff, & bad parking)
author: E S.

description: So... after some shopping in the city, wanted to have a light starter and was always curious to go here since we were looking for some good raw oysters! They have a DAILY happy hour for the oysters at a buck a shuck and they usually offer you whatever amount (1/2 dozen or dozen) with mixture of the 3 kinds they have. I'm a bit picky about the kind of oysters I like - I'm not into creamy big ones, I like small, light but a tad briny ones like (gasp too expensive) those Kumamotos! Unfortunately they didn't have any of those but they did have some light ones and were nice enough to let us have another 6 of just that kind since the other 2 kinds were creamier. I appreciated that adjustment and their cocktails were ok but they were only $6 so can't complain (we had margarita and appletini) but did taste a tad watered down. Parking is a royal pain... we must have circled the area 5 times on a Sat afternoon. Alas, comes with the territory I suppose. I would like to try their cioppino in the future since I'm looking for a place to call my favorite still in SF for this.
author: Kuishingal F.

description: We came here with some friends over the Holidays and really loved this little place. Oysters are good, scallops are the best. Servers are friendly. Arrive early to make sure parking is not a hassle. The atmosphere is something to enjoy, and it takes you in a time-warp to the 1940s. Good for conversation and dining.
author: Peninsula F.

description: My favorite seafood restaurant in SF.  The fish in paper is a must!  Cioppino and key lime pie are also delicious.
author: Larissa W.

description:
Two things you need to know.
1. Lobster Bisque
2. Papillote

Very reasonable, excellent food, it's our new neighborhood seafood spot.  Can't believe I've never been here before!!

We took my parents when they were in town.  Our server made some great suggestions and they were very willing to accommodate special requests.  Want the Papillote but with a different fish? No problem.  Can I get the special but with different potatoes?  Absolutely!! 

Skip the Caesar Salad and Get the Lobster Soup.  
You'll thank me later
author: Steve S.

description:
I had the lobster bisque and the so called "butter fish" served their famous style. The lobster bisque was more of a watery consistency than I like, but it tasted great with pretty large chunks of lobster. They also gave me a cup since I couldn't eat an entire bowl ($1 off the regular bowl price).

The service was great. The waiter was very attentive.
But for almost $60 for two glasses of wine, a cup of soup, and a main dish, it's a bit too expensive for my tastes.  From reading the other views, it sounds like happy hour and raw foods are the thing to do, so next time I'm going to give that a try.
author: M S.

description:
What more can I add?  This place is awesome.  It has a Wharf feel without the noisy crowds and tourists.  We did not get there in time for the $1 oysters, but I'll be sure to go back and try them.

Our order of crab cocktail was tremendous- I forget sometimes how fresh the crab can be in SF!  I am a lobster fan, but this crab made me lean back towards the other direction.  Nice horseradish sauce accompanying the crab, although for those with low heat tolerance it might be wise to ask for it separated from the cocktail sauce.

I got the Halibut en papillote and my girlfriend got the stuffed prawns, and we were both very impressed.  My halibut was flaky, tender, juicy- everything you could ask for.  The veggies were crisp, but could've used a little less butter.  My girlfriend's stuffed prawns were just as good, with a really sweet and tasty stuffing.  

We were treated on the house to a crispy and delicious creme brulee as it was our anniversary, which pretty much sealed this place as somewhere I will return to.  There was some lag time in service but nothing too bad; I think it was just busy and they're a bit understaffed.
author: James S.

description:
Well this was our most recent escapade and cannot for a second say we regret it. We had read other reviews for the restaurant, and so booked our table for Christmas eve with little hesitation, only to find out later that given the holiday, the menu was set and oyster happy hour would not be an option. This raised some concerns, but we decided it couldn't hurt to try, and I am seriously glad we did. 
I had the whole lobster with drawn butter, with a smoked salmon starter and my boyfriend an oyster starter with their seafood special for the main, and divine is not the word. Cooked to perfection the lobster brought out the less elegant side in me, and so perhaps is not a good option for a first date, but if you are comfortable with your co-diner, I can't imagine you can go wrong with this option. 
As for the seafood special, a pleasant medley of sea delights cooked in parchment paper, my boyfriend, an adamant non-sharer of food in general was insistent on me trying everything - in my eyes a definite sign of its superior taste and quality.
As it was Christmas eve I cannot vouch much for the atmosphere as it was incredibly quiet, but the staff were friendly, and very helpful with choices, and indeed discussions on food beyond their current menu.
I would definitely recommend this for a nice and tasty San Francisco sea food experience.
author: Michelle C.

description: Yelp had never steered me wrong before - I don't think - until this place.  I read the reviews before visiting and honestly I agree more with the negative reviews more than the positive ones.  Lobster Bisque was NOT the best by any means.  I think the bisque at the Nordstrom bistro was a far better bisque.  The one here was a decent soup - but it was more of a mixed seafood (maybe crab?) creamy chowder than a bisque.  The halibut special was dry and not flavorful.  The seafood salad was a tiny little plate with many shells mixed in with the seafood.  Someone else in the party had the seafood fettuccine which was so disappointing - the sauce tasted exactly like the jars of pre-made alfredo sauce that you can buy yourself.  I had the mixed shell fish in parchment paper which flavor wise was ok but out of the 4 mussels that were in there 3 was completely clammed shut.  All the clams had something crunchy in there - either sand or parts of the shell.  The only reason why I didn't give it 1 star was because I got there before 7pm and was able to get 2 dozen oysters for $24 and the oysters were fine.  But I will never return to this place again.
author: Jean T.

description: the food was fantastic ! i had the cajun shrimp and scallops and  wished for more when i was finished. i was thrown back when i asked for a refill on my coke and was told " we dont offer refills, would you like to order another coke ? ". i thought this was on the "tacky" side.after all when your spending the $ for dinner , whats the deal with another coke ?  my wife had the parchment paper wrapped halibut and it was also delicious.all in all i was pleased.
author: Lee M.

description: prices are reeasonable and the seafood tastes super fresh. the waiters are very attentive and since i was out of town they had many suggestions on where to go for night life. getting a taxi outside was also easy.
author: Katherine H.

description: Even though I don't like seafood this place has a great NY steak for me whenever my girlfriend demands to go here.
author: Jake B.

description:
This is the worlds greatest neighborhood joint.  Even though I don't live in the neighborhood...

The atmosphere is very comfortable and low key.  The food is delicious.  The service is forgettable, frankly, but the food is so good you don't care.  The seafood is in my opinion some of the freshest in the city.  The oysters are sper cheap at happy hour and they are delicious.  I always get the sampler and love every kind, no matter what they are.

They specialize in fish cooked en pappilote, which means baked in parchment paper with various herbs and veggies.  It is delicious and totally healthy.  My favorite is the sea bass with tomato and jalapeno.  Yum!  The cioppino is also excellent, as are the specials of the day.

The only reason they don't get five stars is that they only have beer and wine, no liquor.  The beer and wine is both good and affordable, but when I go out I do like atleast the option of a makers mark and ginger ale, you know?

Check this place out, very cute and great, great food.
author: Sara G.

description:
Good food and friendly staff, but a seasonal complaint: the restaurant was ice cold. We kept our jackets on the whole time, and it looked like a lot of other diners were doing the same. We couldn't finish our meals fast enough to get out of there. Silverware was cold to the touch, and our meals had to be scarfed down if we wanted to eat warm food. It made the whole experience a little unpleasant.

I'll go back when the weather is warmer, but not before. Too bad, too, because it's a nice cozy atmosphere, just without the cozy part.
author: Hans S.

description:
So comfortable and homely.

I loved the food as everything I ordered was delicious.

I am looking forward to my next meal here.
author: Ziggy P.

description: I came here for a friend's birthday one night and I felt like I got nothing for my money :(  We came for Happy Hour but unfortunately I don't like raw oysters, the main attraction.  Everyone got either a side salad or soup along with raw oysters.  For myself, I had the seafood salad that was simply a small salad with some smoked salmon, baby shrimps and crab meat sprinkled on it.  It was fairly decent but definitely not worth the $18 dollars I spent in total.  Maybe its because I didn't have oysters but this was basically a disappointment.  On top of that, there were only 2 staff members which meant it took FOREVER to get our orders taken and for the food to come out.  They didn't even have our food come out all at once!  Everyone was basically done by the time I got my salad.  I have no idea why my cold SALAD was the last to come out.  If it weren't for the good company, this would have been a disaster.
author: Nicole G.

description: I really like this place.  The snapper in paper was amazing.  The salmon is always good.  I've even had good swordfish here.  Great service, too.
author: The P.

description: we had a great experience here and will be back for sure. so delicious. the parchment paper option for the entrees was excellent. oysters were prepared right and tasty. beer and wine were good. good service, cool spot.
author: mike s.

description: I found this place on yelp after a recent visit to San Francisco. I was quite impressed, great service, delicious food and the location is beautiful. I love San Francisco.
author: karla b.

description: This is the best food in San Francisco and the best service too!  Our service was excellent from the time we made our reservation.  It was necessary to call back and update the reservation, due to an issue at the hotel, and the staff was gracious in accomodating us.  We were seated at a great table that comfortably sat all four of us.  We shared a bottle of Riesling for less than $30.  Our server was available for our every need, checking on us periodically but not interrupting us often.  We all enjoyed the fresh bread and the lobster bisque.  You MUST try the lobster bisque!  It's the best I've ever had, with just enough pieces of lobster in it and smooth taste.  The dungeness crab mornay en croute was HEAVENLY!  It was truly sensual!  I ate every bite, and I'm already craving it again just a few days later.  My other friend ordered the pasta du jour, fettucine with seafood, and she said it was to-die-for!   Truly a fantastic dining experience and a great bargain!  Best seafood in San Francisco!
author: Heather D.

description:
the bf wanted seafood, and we usually go to scomas, but i decided to switch it up and we came here.  
1. complimentary bread - the bread itself was cold, but the butter was room temperature.  meh.
2. clam chowder - pretty tasty actually.  the potatoes were nice and soft and there was a good amount of clams.
3. lobster ravioli special - totally not what i expected.  there were tons of ravioli!  and on top of the ravioli was tons of bay scallops, shrimp, and crab meat.  the only downside to this dish is that it was covered in this really thick cream sauce.  i mean, i like cream based sauces, but this one was just overwhelming and got to a sickening point.  i thought this dish would have been a lot better with a lighter tomato based sauce.  
4. swordfish - not overcooked, which was nice.  it had a caper lemon sauce, which is okay.  i wasn't too into it.  according to the bf, the swordfish at scomas is a lot better.

the total came out to be $50 (without tip), so it's around 25-30$ per person.  
i guess overall it's okay, and this is one of the cheaper seafood places around town.
author: H. L.
